With stunning visuals, immersive sound design, and intuitive controls, it propels players into the cosmos with unparalleled realism. It feels like gravity is a little more forgiving than real life, but otherwise this is a great way to get accustomed to flying FPV. 

I've also enjoyed Liftoff: Micro Drones, but I wish there was a little more focus on the point where the scale of both of these meet. As a primarily cinematic pilot, I mostly fly cinewhoops in the 2-3.5in range and this tends to focus on freestyle quads that are a little bigger and L:MD tends to focus on tinywhoops that are a little smaller. By the same token, Liftoff is by and large outdoors and L:MD is mostly indoors. It would be nice having a middle ground (even if it was a third iteration) where you could practice flying a small to medium sized whoop around a map like Bardwell's House but also fly through the house as well like San Lipo in L:MD.

Ultimately, if you're looking to "learn something today" this is an excellent way to get started without bashing your real life drone into the ground a million times.

Updated after 28 hours: This one has a lot of issues for new pilots just trying to learn. First off in the tutorials after you do a step it asks you to do, it pauses you and shows a message. You then have to TAKE YOUR HANDS OFF THE CONTROLLER to click "next" then get your hands back where they were. Also after you mess up and reset you have to go through the dialog again. I couldn't believe it. It has a feel like no person actually tested the tutorial and they just sent it straight to the public. You also can't skip the scenes where it's showing you what to do which are really long and boring. Every time I want to practice I have to watch it all over again. If I go change a setting and come back.. yup I have to watch it all over again and again.
Parts of the tutorial are supposed to be simplified by giving you a straight ahead course and all you have to do is control throttle up and down. But you don't start out lined up straight with it! It's unbelievable! So you have to try to fix your angle to line up straight with the obstacles as you go. Which is hard for a beginner and the whole point was to not have to.
Also keep seeing a bug where when selecting my drone the stats don't show up. All the little bar graph thingies stay the same as I change selection.
The constant clipping glitches are infuriating. I keep getting stuck in walls and objects and have to restart. I get stuck to the ground all the time. The collision physics are downright awful. 
The difficulty ratings of the races are meaningless. Some tracks on "hard" levels I can go full throttle and finish with ease. Some tracks on "easy" levels are outrageously hard and I can't even finish them. It takes a lot of time and effort to find tracks that are in my skill range because of this.
I think all the hype is from people who already know how to fly and don't have to deal with the tutorial and major lack of low skill content. I can see how experienced pilots will like this but it's really not beginner friendly. The creators are probably experienced and out of touch with nooby needs.
Incredibly satisfying game to learn and improve at, plus I feel like I've learning a real world skill at the same time.
If you want to get better at ACRO/flying...this is it!

I recently bought a BetaFPV Cetus X drone thinking I could fly it indoors over the winter to learn how to fly FPV in acro or manual mode.  I spent the summer learning to fly a DJI Minipro 3 over the summer and had become reasonably skilled at flying it and taking videos.  I had no idea how steep the learning curve is for the FPV drones in acrobatic or acro mode.
I was able to fly the Cetus X inside my home fairly rapidly in the self leveling angle mode. This is the default mode for the Minipro 3, but using the acro mode on the Cetus X for me was impossible.
I bought this software to learn acro mode.  Most fortunately, it allows me to use the controller for the Cetus X.  Perhaps unfortunately, I haven't found a satisfactory equivalent for the Cetus X drone in the software, but that is a very minor matter.  Liftoff does have an equivalent for the Cetus X drone in one of its other products, but that is almost entirely limited to flying in very small places.  I found that flying in such a confined, hazard filled environment in acro mode was similarly impossible for me to make much progress.
This software has a wide variety of maps with wide open spaces and various skill levels that allows me to gradually develop my skills flying in acro mode without constantly crashing.  One HUGE asset is that Joshua Bardwell has a series of YouTube tutorials for the novice FPV pilot that uses the maps in this software: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SpuXqNakP2A&list=PLwoDb7WF6c8lCKhQOTy-Vb9LfW0VAIrTP&index=1&ab_channel=JoshuaBardwell 
Using this software, along with Joshua's excellent tutorials I am SLOWLY gaining some proficiency in flying acro mode.  I have used several of the other FPV drone software offered on Steam, but have found them unsatisfactory on their own.  This combination of software and video tutorials seems to have allowed me enough progress to keep practicing without giving up in total frustration.
In closing, some important points:  Flying drones in FPV acro mode is a complex motor skill for most people to learn.  FPV drones are expensive and easy to crash.  You would be foolish to attempt to fly one without some practice using software, such as Liftoff.  Unfortunately, the tutorials offered in most FPV software are inadequate.  I have found that using a combination of FPV software and video tutorials to be the best way to learn this skill.  Finally, think of learning this skill as similar to learning to play a musical instrument; it is going to take an enormous amount of practice, time, and patience to gain some proficiency.

Addendum
After nearly 75 hours of playing this "game" and devoting much study, both video and written, I would say I am still at the semi-klutz level of flying FPV in acro mode.  Some of the key things I've found is that to enjoy the game, you have to go very slow, master basic skills before moving on to more advanced, and learn to enjoy the practice.  FPV drones are beautifully complicated machines.  One of the authors I have read writes that it can easily take 1,000 hours of practice to gain mastery.  Keep that in mind when you are using this software.

If it wasn't for Liftoff I would have wasted all my money replacing broken parts in my new drone from all the real life crashes I would have had instead of virtual crashes in-game. Before I even took my drone outside I spent 25h in this game learning all the stuff and that made my first real life drone experience very pleasant and even easier than the game because the drone was slower than some of the drones I tried in Liftoff. I recommend every new drone pilot to spend at least 20/25h in this game. It might seem boring because you want to pilot your drone, I get it, but trust me, if you crash your drone first try and break it it wont be any fun at all and actually the game is very cool to learn to control the drone and try to break lap records so you wont be bored. Best 20 bucks I could have spend on this hobby, saved me a lot of money and frustration!

LOVE IT. Getting solid stick time on LO and I'm seeing solid progress. I did take like a year off from flying all together as it wasn't quite clicking with me, and I was worried I just don't have what it takes to be any good at it. I randomly decided to give it another shot and I'm progressing faster than I was before, though still perhaps more slowly than others with the same amount of hours in. Everyone learns at their own pace though so remember that if you find yourself getting frustrated. Take a break and come back.

Anyway, as far as Lift Off specifically goes, of all the sims I've seen it is the best balance of graphics, realism, and having solid courses to fly. DRL might be better in more ways except graphics, I haven't purchased it yet though. Tryp has the best graphics, but needs a lot of work in most other areas. VelociDrone "feels" the best to me but the graphics are a tad lacking and it randomly disappeared from my computer and refuses to come back. Basically if I cant get it on steam, I'm not getting it at all after that happened.

TLDR Great for getting the initial stick time necessary to be competent once youre flying IRL. IDK if its the most nitty gritty in terms of PIDS, rates, customizing stuff like that, but it's def got some of that for the more advanced pilots out there. Also you 100% should be using a drone/RC controller and not a game console control, though it is possible. They are fundamentally different and it's just not worth using a game pad. If anything I'd say it will hurt you more than help, but that's my opinion.

The overall impression is positive, I like most of the maps and how the physics works, but UX in lessons could be better.

The messages are slow, repeatative and annoying after a few tries, it would be much easier to group some of them and show without those s l o o o o o w l  y y y y rolling out background animation for every short sentence.

I can't just skip all that text, demonstrations and it takes a lot of time before the real exercise and if you want to repeat the exercises quickly just by flying 8-loop or the first "race" or other simple steps after some pause - you'd not want to do it, because it'll take a hour just to listen to all that slow animated text that can't be skipped fast (or I didn't find it in the menu, so it's not so intuitive). And yeah, you can see that I spend 1.3 hour in last 2 weeks, that in reality is just today's evening and I just finished all lessons with 2 tries for each exercise. Frankly, when I tried it first time a month ago I hadn't been able to finish the lessons in one try. Had to make it in two days.
Also, I didn't find how to reset the race fast when you drop the drone and all propellers are broken, it takes too long time for game to understand that your drone isn't going to flight anymore :D

Liftoff is a game-changer for anyone passionate about drone racing and FPV flying. As an avid drone enthusiast, I've tried several simulators, but Liftoff stands out with its realistic physics, diverse environments, and comprehensive features.

The physics in Liftoff are remarkably accurate, providing a genuine feel of flying a drone. The simulator captures the intricacies of drone control, making it an excellent tool for both beginners and experienced pilots looking to refine their skills. The customizable settings allow users to tailor the experience to their preferences, ensuring a challenging yet enjoyable learning curve.

The variety of environments in Liftoff is impressive, from urban landscapes to sprawling parks. Each location offers unique challenges, enhancing the overall simulation experience. The attention to detail in graphics and sound further immerses you in the world of FPV racing.

One standout feature is the extensive drone customization options. Liftoff allows you to build and modify your drone, simulating real-life scenarios where tweaking components can significantly impact performance. This feature adds an extra layer of depth to the simulator, making it a valuable training ground for both virtual and real-world drone racing.

Multiplayer functionality adds a social aspect to Liftoff, allowing you to compete with friends or other users worldwide. The competitive community adds a dynamic element to the simulator, keeping the experience fresh and engaging.

In terms of user interface and controls, Liftoff is user-friendly, even for those new to drone simulators. The tutorials are informative without being overwhelming, guiding you through the basics before progressing to more advanced maneuvers.

Overall, Liftoff is a fantastic investment for drone enthusiasts. Its realism, diverse environments, customization options, and multiplayer features make it a standout choice in the world of FPV simulators. Whether you're a beginner honing your skills or a seasoned pilot looking for a realistic training ground, Liftoff is a must-have in your virtual hangar.

Liftoff Review: Great for Practice, Limited Fun

Liftoff is a solid choice for practice and offers some enjoyable moments, but I wouldn't recommend purchasing it unless you're specifically looking for a practice tool. While it serves its purpose well, there's not a lot to do in terms of varied content or gameplay.
it's pretty dope but my hand is aching so bad after playing

In my opinion this is if not thee best simulator, when it comes to realism, for flying FPV drones... then its the second best... Liftoff would be my first recommendation when it comes to somebody wanting to try a FPV simulator

First, it's less of a game than a simulator. I purchased this to help me learn to fly a drone. While it's not 100% accurate, it's still accurate enough to create the basic muscle memory needed to make your first real flight safe or at least far less expensive. Plus, it's reasonably fun.

Ill recommend it just because its still getting updates and I do see why some would like a sim like this. For someone who is just curious about the hobby or someone who wants some "practice" on the off season or when its raining out etc. 

For me though nothing was better then just getting a little all-in-one kit and flying in the grass or in the house. After a few flights and when I was comfy. This simulator is good and i can recommend it BUT:
I am new in FPV and drone flying...
Pros:
Drone building - its fun to build your own drone or download already prebuild
Physics - i would say that the physics feel good, maybe little slidy
Graphic - you can crank this up or down depend on you pc
Setting - a lot of setting to adjust control and drone

Cons: 
Maps - Some maps are boring and there si nothing to do
Racing - HORIBLE!!!!!!!! - worst part of the game. (Some races has no gates and only marked areas. You cant see next area ahead, and the areas are also poorly visible. Just white arrow pointing on it. No bordering of the area.
That mean you have no idea where to fly in race (So struggling always from start to find place i should fly next.) Registration of the areas are so poorly marked that really often you miss the area thinking you fly directly through.) Often happening that after crash (In god mode) you get stuck under texture and has to restart the race.
Tutorial has extremly wierd rates and also extremly sensitive throttle. From beginer experience it was painful to get through tutorial (Funny, because tutorial should be the place where you actually feel comfortable to get in touch with the control for first time)
Textures - really often you crash and you get stuck under texture and has to restart. In races is specially painful. Mainly in tight spots.
just starting out. so far it rocks

Before buying this one, I've played another FPV simulator for about 10hrs (I will not mention it here to avoid advertisement) and then I decided to buy this one.
What can I say after 53 minutes... that's a refund. This game costs ~x4 more than another FPV sim I played. 
And all these points below are really worse. Both games have realistic drone control, so I had no issues with that. But for all other stuff...
Well,
1. Still no way to reset drone. You can reset only the whole race. I've found that a lot of players asked about "drone reset" feature singe 2017. And that's not implemented yet. Why?
2. "Try to guess where is the next checkpoint". Path suggestion is the worst I have ever seen.
- Small white donut is really hard to see on white-text interface. 
- cursed arrows to next checkpoint, but again, you will see them only after you passed the current checkpoint. 
- ... combined with only "race reset", that's the most annoying thing in this game. 
- No traces or any highlights from which angle you have to enter the checkpoint. Except there is someone ahead of you, in that case, you will see the color trace behind him.
3. And yeah, annoying "press-next" tutorial. Another game has MUCH immersive tutorial. This one - read-next-read-next-read-next-move 5 meters - read - next - read - next - another 5 meters behind - read - next... Aaaaagh!
I've started that just for fun, but even these 10 minutes made me sleepy.
Only two things this game has really better than another (and much cheaper) simulator: FPV interface looks pretty realistic and yeah, graphics. That's all I've seen in these 53 minutes. 

Sorry guys, but for that price, it could be much, much better from the user perspective. Huge dislike for missing 'drone reset' feature. I'd say it must be by default here.
I'll buy it again only with 70%+ discount, for now it does not worth more.

The problem with trying to create a good freestyle sim is content, there's never enough that devs can create. Great sim for racing and online though.

This use to be one of the best of the simulators...  in 2000
....but it's fallen way behind and now it is one of the WORST.... in 2023.

I recommend Uncrashed FPV simulator instead.  

The load times of Uncrashed are BLAZINGLY FAST compared to Liftoff.  The unser interface is miles ahead of Liftoff and a pleasure to use and FAST.  Each has about as many maps as the other and they are pretty much comparable.  Liftoff has a very good flight model, however, Uncrashed allows you to use Actual rates which gives you just a bit more fine tuning ability allowing you to tune your rates so much further and better.

Some Problems with Liftoff...

 --Devs are their user interface is very hostile to visually impaired people.  A dark theme with larger text or just inverted color bottons would go a long way to fixing this and would be simple to implement....
--No Dark theme.  Bright "Light theme" with thin small lettering is hard and tedious to navigate, esp. on lower monitors resolution screens and/or witi goggles.
--Interface Tree structure is incredibly slow to load.
--Devs are hostile to constructive critsism and advice of simple changes they could make to improve their sim user experience.
--Devs are hostile to the FPV community and sharing your FPV sim videos in their community.  This is a game and a hobby after all, something you do for fun.  
--Too much fixation on adding what they call "festivites" to the game which are nice, but really add nothing to the game...  when the time and effort could be better invested in creating one more new map.
--Nothing in the way of 3rd party modding support for the generation of user created content maps.   You can do this in Velocidrone and A.I. Drone Simulator.

I actually went way out of my way to type up some recommended ideas and improvments free of charge for the devs to consider incorporating into Liftoff to improve it, but only was met by outright hostility.  

Basically, if they didn't come up with the idea or it wasn't "invented here", they don't want to here it.  Their game to them is absolutely perfect as it is, and anyone that says anything to the contrary is branded and enemy.  

As a former game developer myself I can understand this.. I mean, your creation and product is your "baby", and you think it's perfect in every way just how you wanted and designed it to be...     but at some point you got to grow up and say yeah, there's a few things we could add that would indeed make it better without really changing our original vision or requiring more work.   Like a Dark theme or higher contrast menus and buttons option to assist visually impaired people in navigating our menus.  It's not a big ask.

It's not like I didn't promote them for years and cross post video footage of THEIR GAME in other game threads and forums
 
Uncrashed:

Way better than the free DJI trainer. Great maps. Lots of fun.

It's hard, yes, and often unforgiving.

It does it's best to guide you through but the level of challenge and skill curve is highly uneven at times. For example, the first environment and track has low, small gates and tight turns immediately and a couple of tracks later are much, much easier for beginners. The environments do have a skill level, but the tracks themselves vary and are random in difficulty.

There's not much to progressively increase your skills, to allow you to learn a manoeuvre gradually. It just sort of appears and you have to figure it out, or not (know how to power loop, sucker???). Some of the tracks and levels are just evil.

Too many drone options and customisation for beginners. What are all these propellers and motors (about 40 of each to choose from)? How can I make a drone I can just fly slowly to learn? There are pre-built 'blueprint' options, but again so, so many and not much idea what difference they will make. There's no, try this one first, then this when you need more speed and this for freestyle.

All the elements are there, they just seem to be randomly distributed without any player roadmap.

The game aims more towards a certain realism and less arcade, which is both it's strength for a certain audience and its weakness for beginners. Be prepared to be patient.

I'm loving this game. I'm playing with a TX16S MKII, getting real comfy with flight mechanics before I start flying my wallet around in real skies. 

It's a blast playing online, infinite race is good fun, and a great way to push your limits. 

I have 5 sims on my computer at the moment and this one, and Uncrashed, are getting the most playtime simply because they run so well, and look great too. 

I'm using a Macbook Pro M2 MAX and can easily run "fantastic" with antialiasing, ambient occlusion, bloom, blur, and depth of field at 110-120 FPS. When I'm racing I usually untick some of the extras for a locked 120FPS. 

If you're on Apple silicon I would def recommend Liftoff and Uncrashed as the two best, and most optimized, FPV sims.

As I didn't understand before, I still don't comprehend the widespread affection for this simulator. I ended up buying it solely because of that and regretted it. The only positives were the option to customize drones and the realism of the physics ‚Äì in reality, the physics are close to real only cause of normal gravity compared to jelly in other sims. Everything else is just as bad, if not worse, than in the same DCL, which, unlike Liftoff, is optimally designed for all supported platforms. Customization is just pitiful, ranging from a complete lack of popular frames to outright absurdity. For example, a fully assembled 3-inch toothpick frame in Liftoff weighs (attention!) 1050g - 1 kilogram, seriously? And it's not a number glitch, as the some other bugged drones in the workshop all weigh in the same range, whether it's 10-inch machines or 3-inch microdrones, all around 1-1.2 kg with all the resulting issues, like the drone only taking off at 80% throttle. Furthermore, without workshop mods, the default track selection is terribly dull and monotonous.

UPD: I can share a screenshot of the 1.1-kilogram weight of the 3" drone in personal messages or send it via email ‚Äì it's amusing that the developer denies this.
I also have a video showcasing the worse game's performance compared to DCL on a top-tier setup (i9, MB Pro 16 2019, 32 GB RAM, Radeon 5500m 8GB), which I can also send via PM/email.
Refund was unfortunately declined.

New DJI Avata owner, looking for a simulator to learn acro / manual mode - and LiftOff has done exactly that!  From first attempts (<crash> "What the hell just happened?") to just starting to get a hint at the controls ("Hey - I can SORT OF make it go in the direction I want" <crash>)... to "Wow - can can mostly fly around this race track, mostly staying under the scaffolding" <crash>) - LiftOff has allowed me to learn the basic mechanics of "full manual mode".  This includes UNlearning years of experience with a DJI Phantom (GPS / camera) drone - wherein the controls are COMPLETELY different.

Thanks to the devs, and all the contributors to making this an excellent resource, saving me untold thousands of dollars in costly crashes - not to mention being just a TON of fun!

At first, you think you're crazy because there's no way this game is programmed correctly because you can't make the drone do anything that makes any sense. Everything is too touchy and the controller just doesn't feel right and you can do nothing with it except crash over and over... and then it starts to sink in... you start to realize that everything is a million times touchier than regular video games and the controller has to be thought of completely different. TINY movements and muscle memory are what it's all about. Then you suddenly can make the drone fly a little... then a little more. Now you are on the road to making it all make sense. Months later, I'm flying in the real world and it is THAT difficult but I can do it. And it is amazing how accurate Liftoff is to the real world. It seems impossible at the beginning but it is very possible. It just takes time.

save your expensive toy and play Liftoff first. for some of us even $50 - $100 is expensive and liftoff is so real you may not believe your eyes.  Smart developers left us with 3 levels of difficulties so we can all grow.  It may seem difficult at 1st, but keep at it, you will see progress....and spare your drone!!!

While its not the best looking as far as graphics go and their are better options if you are into cinematic stuff, its more than good enough to practice freestyle. The workbench feature seems to stand out from similar software.  Liftoff's approach feels much more interactive as you swap out different parts to customize your quad as apposed to moving a slider around. I'd like to mention though that the parts are a quite a ways behind the current market so finding specific motors or even equivalents is difficult. For example there are no 1750KV 2207 motors. I'd really like to see more customization on individual parts

Liftoff and Velocidrone are my two favorite sims. Both are must haves if you're into flying FPV in real life and need something to practice with. 

I love the graphics of Liftoff and and the game runs very smoothly. Flying around on the golf course is probably my favorite spot to fly. The trees look amazing and all the colors are very pleasant. 

The physics feel pretty spot on for 5" quads. Close enough that it translates to getting the coordination down for real life maneuvers. 

Couple things I'd like to see in the future are more maps with detailed areas for proxy flying. Most maps are pretty big and a bit sparse. It's really tailored around the bigger, faster quads. So I'd love to see some smaller, more detailed maps. I'd also like more 3" quad options with improved physics.  

Liftoff is a great game and I highly recommend it over everything else that's currently on Steam.

Really good for learning flying. I've got shortly over 10 hours with this simulator, and I do feel confident enough to fly just a little bit. However, I'll give another 30-40 hours before I do the real thing.

I know some people are all about Velocidrone, but this is the best FPV racing sim in my opinion. It's worth the $$, and quite enjoyable. Get a proper radio to use as a controller however. The Radiomaster TX16S works perfectly out of the box.

i've been flying freestyle for over a year now and have played this game alongside it and have some thoughts.

as a training thing: 

the flight model is fairly accurate although i think it's a far too well tuned when compared to actual quads. it's a fantastic way to get a grasp on how acro mode works but doesn't really give much of a look into the more niche flight characteristics. like for instance, the prop wash that's in the game is substantially lower than anything i've felt on even my best tuned quads even when you've got the setting cranked to the max. there's no kind of weather simulation so you don't have any kind of drafts/wind/turbulence. real quads often feel a lot sloppier when you push them harder but every single build i've done in this game except for like the 2s battery setups feel buttery smooth like a well tuned cinewhoop or hex with low rates. there's no simulation of faults that you can experience like motor desync, over exerting the battery, or video issues.

now as a practice/fun thing: 

it's so damn fun. i love being able to fling quads at speeds through gaps that i'd never consider trying to hit in real life because i don't want to have to rebuild and replace parts is really enjoyable. slipstream adding vehicles to chase is worth every penny, it's hard to set up things like that in my experience so just being able to boot a game and practice is so great. not to mention it allows for a lot of practice of tricks before ever putting your quad at risk, i did inverse yaw spins and juicy flicks hundreds of times in game before i ever tried with my quads.

it's by no means perfect but a super fun game and a useful tool for learning the basics :)

Would rate it 4/5. I don't have real life flight experience yet and do not know how well the skills transfer over however at the moment super happy with the flight experience. 

Giving it 4/5 is because damage system is somewhat flawed (or at least it feels like it)
Here is why:

Sometimes when you tap an object (building or something else) with the bottom of the drone (frame or battery), the props get damaged in the process. It feels that damage is completely random on hit. I feel like I should be able to tap or slide on the floor that is completely smooth without damaging props. And other times, drone gets pushed to one side and flip just by increasing throttle from the rest position during race. Even though there is nothing near by to cause that. 

Maybe there are some battery physics in the play that I'm not aware off (if battery mounted on the bottom).

I only wish this game had a counter to tell me how many thousands of dollars I've saved in crashed drones. This flight sim is the only thing helping me build confidence to risk my equipment budget in the real world, and it's a lot of fun, too!

Compared to Velocidrone Liftoff looks great. It has a different feel (some call it floaty) to how the quads fly, but it seems not unreal. Without god mode, it quickly breaks the quad and reduces it's flying capability or disables it alltogehter, which encourages safer flying than in velocidrone which is quite forgiving. The tracks are all bigger more high speed tracks, which are unreal to fly on in real life for most. In comparison Velocidrone has al lot of tracks for example from MultiGP which are used in real races and can be build by local clubs on restricted spaces.

I like it for the nice graphics. Occaionally I fly on the race tracks, but I also like to just freestyle on the nice maps. For a "real" racing experience I use Velocidrone. To date I don't know which physics model ist better :)

Edit: Having lived in and close to Laatzen until grown up, I enjoy flying the hannover fair map (which is in Laatzen) especially. Bardwells ground is very nice too, as everybody knows it already anyway. It is like the personal flying area everybody wants to have for their own :)

This is a simulator, and as with such games a radio controller controller is highly recommended to get the most out of your time. I have played some Velocidrone and also DRL. This game feels the most natural for me so I stuck with it. I went from zero ability to keep my quad in the air for more than 2 seconds to smashing gaps and busting aerials. All in about 15 hours. It's so much fun once you get the hang.

You will not get it at first if you were like me. You'll think,"This makes no ******* sense". But I urge you to stick with it! Things will just start to click, but you're going to eat dirt a lot. Just remember, that could be a 5 dollar prop or a total loss at over $300 USD. So do all that here where it's free. Trust me.

I have this game to practice flying my irl drone, so I can do aggressive maneuvers in a sim before testing it out in the field. The custom drone options are great, you can set up your machine in the game exactly like your personal drone, and the response is pretty close to reality. Additionally, you can use your drone RTX as a controller input, which allows you to learn the muscle memory for flying pretty easily.
All in all this is a fantastic game, and the custom maps are super fun.

I have not played any other paid simulators such as velocidrone or drl, but I can say that this simulator is extremely good. When I first started playing, I was not very interested in trying the multiplayer game mode. However, once I tried it, I was amazed at how much better it made the experience. The multiplayer community is great, and its exiting to log on and find someone you recognize to fly with. Its great for beginners because you will be able to use the spectating option to view other players techniques, and for other players to spectate you and help you or give you advice on your flying. The workshop feature is another great aspect of the game. It allows you to customize and tune your drone with a variety of parts. In the flight controller tuning section, you can tune your rates and PIDs, and you can even swap between FC firmware options such as Betaflight, KISS, and a bunch of others which I forget. The workshop features many different frames. most of the options are 5 inch frames, however theres are like maybe two 6" options, and two or three 3" frames as well. You can change between batteries, most of which are 4s and 6s, as well as one 2s battery, like three 3s batteries, and one 5s battery. theres are tons of different motor options as well- Im not gonna get into that because there are so many, but chances are, your gonna find exactly the motor you are looking for. it even has the exact motors that are on the baby ape 3" from darwin fpv (if you were wondering that for some odd reason). next is props, which there are also a lot of. sizes range from 2.5" up to 6". the other drone options which you can customize include: action camera(gopro hero 4, gopro session 5, and this one weird flat camera thing thats really light but looks ugly): fpv camera(there are a lot of options, but the only thing this changes is cosmetic appearance of drone, and the weight- ie. it doesnt effect the way your flight view looks at all): antena (I spelled that wrong, but i dont care so fight me. Also this does not change the way the drone flies; only weight and drone apperance): the last thing you can change is color of all the parts, except for motors, batteries, camera and antena, and the color of the carbon. Alrighty, I think that is just about everything. nevermind I lied- there is also a track builder option which gets the job done. I personally do not like it very much, and there are not as many options as I would like. However, this is not a disadvantage in my opinion, because of the 20 or so default maps, and the great steam comunity- there are a lot of great maps that people have put together (my favorite is the map from Frvp which is (I think) called something along the lines of "fpv bando-nice". anyway, there are a few other things that I left out of this, because of time (Ive already spent like 40 minutes on this review lol). I really hope this helped you decide if you want this sim or not. If there are any questions you have about this, leave a comment and Ill try to respond. also, I may or may not post a video about this game on my YT channel: BigJ FPV. if not sorry. anyway, I really love this game, and I made this review because If I can even get one more person to make the commitment to join the liftoff FPV community, than that would make me very happy. cheers!

After about 3 hours of getting used to it, it's apparent this is one of the best drone sims. Instead of ragging on about how great it is, I'm just going to give some limitations to consider:

Drone customizability:
If you fly 3" props, you'll have a lot less options than the 5" community. I've only found one setup that feels right, and it's still twice as heavy as the real thing. For the 5" drones, the options are nice. My suggestion -or more of a plea- is for the developers to include some generic parts that can be used to build approx. any drone. Or at least the ability to fudge the numbers on the real parts a bit to get closer. If nothing else please add more (small) batteries. 
++All that said, liftoff still has some of the best diversity. 

Races: 
My camera is at 45 degrees (sometimes I up it even more) and my throttle rarely sees less than 70%. At least anecdotally. I love the races for the speed and how forgiving they are, but if I want to practice real precision flying, I have a hard time finding it here. Compared to some other sims, the technical practice from liftoff is severely lacking. To compare, skydive's largest feature is about the size of liftoff's smallest. Occasions where you need to fly tighter than your camera can see are very rare.

For hardcore skills practice, I don't think this will be my go-to, even though the drone feel is much better than the alternatives. For some fun and practice that will translate into a real drone, I can't recommend it enough.

Both my xbox 360 controller and thrustmaster t16000m felt way too sensitive, and even after trying the tutorial for 45 minutes and following the instructions it was very frustrating as every input would be way too much.

Maybe it's just not my thing or i "should've practiced more", but it was just a frustrating experience and I didn't feel like I was making any progress. I tried adjusting the deadzones, however that didn't really help either.

If you fly drones IRL and/or have a good controller for this game then this may be very enjoyable for you, but as someone with neither that just wanted to try seeing if I could get into it, it really didn't work.

Apart from this, one of the tutuorial video's was privated and the inability to make changes to the controls without quitting out of the current tutorial/level also felt like it was missing. The game feels good, but it lacks polish in basic areas of the game if you're trying to get into it.

I haven't touched the racing modes yet, but freestyle and free fly modes are pretty fun. I often just zen out, listen to youtube videos in the background, and get some practice on the sticks, making new lines across the maps for hours. The only critique I really have about the game is that it doesn't have a way for communities to make maps. They can make their own tracks on top of pre-existing maps for sure, but the same ten or so environments get old very fast, and this could easily be solved if the dev team comes up with an SDK to allow users to submit new maps on the steam workshop. If they did that, I'd be stuck playing this game for hours at a time.

I am brand new to drones and drone sims. After trying out Liftoff on my son's computer I got hooked. I purchased the Radiomaster TX12 Mk II and Liftoff sim. I have 14.9 hrs in it so far and I am really enjoying it. The first couple hours I felt like I might have wasted my money but that feeling quickly subsided shortly afterwards when things just sort of "clicked" between my brain and thumbs. LOL. I do NOT know how realistic the sim is to flying real drones, nor do I know how Liftoff compares to other drone sims. I searched on YT and took the majority of everyone else's opinion, which highly favored Liftoff. 

Observations:

The skill level on some racing maps labeled as Low, is a lie. One map, for example, is rated as Low. However, there are 3 tracks to choose to race on that map. The first is definitely a Low skill level but the others on that map are NOT low skill level. Just be aware of that.

The maps themselves are big enough to learn to fly and enjoy but bigger maps would be a plus. Also, there are height limits.

No documentation. Figure it out as you go.

Lastly, just go ahead and purchase the Ultimate Collection. You won't regret it.

It's got a great concept and probably the closest you can get to irl drone fllying but my problem is that it is purely focused on small enclosed race tracks. I get it your probably an fpv racer yourself so you created something that others alike can practice on when not in the right environment. But I felt so restricted. the map sizes are ridiculously small, there all too focused on the 1 group which are fpv racers. Where are the mountain ranges and scenic views you can practice around with rocky ledges and cliffs to drop off, islands to explore, snowy ski ranges or curvy roadways. If that was included with bigger maps and less limitations were in the game I would have been happy to pay $25 for and not soon to request a refund. $10 and would have happily kept the game for little stuff around practices as it is definitely the next up from the Official Dji simulator. Need to tweak the dji fpv drone, it doesn't hover in Normal mode and im using the Dji Fpv controller so I don't know if it was anything on my side. Good effort but not quite there yet. A little more effort into making this for a wider range of audiences and I would be happy to pick the game back up.

The game comes with a lessons feature with tasks/goals to complete so beginners know where to start. 

While the game has controller support, thankfully, the DJI Controller 2 works very well with the game (besides the fact that the buttons will have to be binded). This helps with getting a good feel for the controller when applied to the real thing.

Amazing game, love it. Now that I have played it for a while and also flew my drone IRL a bit more I can give you a review. Physics and drone control feel very real. A bit easier to hover a drone in one spot in a game, than IRL, but pretty close. Tried different props and settings to get it closer, but IRL it is just not as simple even on a low rates. 
What is not realistic at all is crashing and trees. I have crashed my drone many many times in real life, not a single thing has broken, not even a prop.. But you just touch something in the game and the drone brakes.. God mode in this game is more realistic to be honest.. 
Now trees. You just touch a freaking branch with your drone in real life and in stays hanging there.. Every freaking time! It just spins itself into those branches. And they are hard to see! In a game nothing happens, just makes you props "broken" while in real life you could probably use those props to trim the tree itself.. 
1. Throttle physics a bit off, too soft in the game.
2. Crashing in the game does not make sense. Drones don't brake that easy, not even close.
3. Tree branches brake your props in the game. In a real life those branches are like drone catching webs. But they don't do any damage to the props usually. 
Other than that, the game is wonderful, highly recommend it.

I've put in 100+ hours in this sim and I can safely recommend it, not only as a tool to hone in on your FPV skills, but also just as a fun game to play.

Let's get something out of the way, this is a sim, not real life. Don't expect it to be exactly like real flying. Many variables are in play that will not give you a 1:1 experience. Perfection, however, should not be your metric for a sim. This is not a perfect tool, but it's still a very valuable one. Stick time is stick time, it's a good thing. Practice races, try to go faster, even if you're not a racer. You will improve overall and it'll be valuable for any type of flying. I've heard many complaints that the physics feel "floaty". Honestly, at first I felt the same but frankly, the more I played the sim, the less I felt that. I think I just didn't fully understand the physics of an FPV drone.

Don't waste time looking for the absolute perfect replication of life. It is a fantastic sim that will be a great tool if used right.

Happy flying!

But I've gone back to Liftoff because my enthusiasm to control every little aspect of the thing has gone away. I just want to play for bits of time and race or freestyle. After logging about 5 hours of flight time I decided to try flying in manual, and it was AWESOME, but very basic. Excellent Drone Flight Simulator!
--------- --------- --------- -------- -----

- After a crash, I find it helps to restart the computer, to prevent additional crashes.

--------- --------- --------- -------- -----

How to use the previous version of Liftoff:
- Right click on Liftoff in your Steam library list
- Select Properties
- Go to the BETAS tab
- Select the ‚Äòliftoff_1.x.yy‚Äô branch from the drop-down and close the window
- The previous version of Liftoff should start downloading
--------- --------- --------- -------- 

- The many tracks and races make this a very enjoyable flying experience. The 3 lap races let me compete against my personal best times, which make for great replay value, and shows me when I am improving.

- To make learning easier, I initially set the rates to 0.25 and reduce the camera angle to 6 degrees. As I improve, I increase the camera angle to 12, 18 and 24 degrees.

- When beginning, I liked to fly the rugged "Vortex 150 mini" drone, and use a small 2C battery, which has the drone fly slower, because the thrust is reduced to 0.37 kg, down from 1.34 kg.
For me, it is funner and easier to use full throttle on a slow drone than partial throttle on a too powerful drone.  

- After I am comfortable with a track, I use a "Vortex 150 mini" drone with a more powerful engine or propellers, with a thrust of  0.53 kg.  

- I use an 8 channel USB simulator, model 0908A, in G3-G7 mode.  I bought it on Lazada online shopping for about $25 US.

- I use 2560x1440 at 120 hertz, on a Samsung Q70 55" TV.  120 hertz makes the screen much smoother than 60 hertz.

- I have an AMD Radeon 5700 XT graphics card and an AMD 3700 cpu.

- I turn off "Show game triggers" and "Show race guides", to be able to see tracks better.

- I turn on "Show joystick overlay in OSD".

- For Ghost Mode, I use "Full race ghost".

--------- --------- --------- -------- 

Best Beginner Tracks:

- Autumn Fields ,Track 01 - Fly in a rectangle around a field, so easier than the "Straw Bale" track.

- Liftoff Arena, Track 04 - A simple figure 8. This is a great beginner track, to practice turning left and right.

- Hanger 26, Track 04 - A lazy figure 8, with 9 gates. Great for beginners.

--------- --------- --------- -------- 

Track Notes:

Straw Bale - Low Skill Level. This is the first track, but a beginner may find it easier to start with the "Autumn Fields" track 1.

Pine Valley - Medium Skill Level.

Minus Two - High Skill Level. Flying in a parkade. I initially reduce the camera angle, to fly slower.

This game is incredibly high quality and is a thrill each time I play. I do not have many critiques so far because I've only been playing around with this sim for about 3 days now, but I have had a great experience with it. I have noticed from this sim that my IRL drone flying has improved and allowed me to practice whenever I want. The vast selection of provided drone models and the capability to customize your own to match real-life models is a necessity provided in this sim. The ability to try new tricks and maneuver and crash with no risk in this sim with its incredibly accurate controls has made me much more comfortable flying drones in general. It is an excellent buy for that reason. I HIGHLY recommend this sim for new or advanced fpv drone pilots.

I purchased Liftoff for the sole purpose of learning to fly the DJI FPV drone.  Like many, I was a complete newb and wanted to get in the air as quickly as possible.  After attempting to fly the DJI FPV in full manual straight out of the box, my battery flew further and more graceful than the drone did.  I purcahsed Liftoff and never looked back.  I spent around 60 hours in the sim before taking off and flying manual mode in real life and I can say with 1000% certainty, it was the best $20 i ever spent.  I fly every day. If I am not flying outside, I am flying in the SIM.  Bottom line, it's 20 bucks...you have at least several hundred in your FPV quad.  Spend the money, save yourself the heartache of a broken quad and your family the horror of watching you come unglued when you break your brand new quad because you said, " how hard can it be?  I go this!"  It's hard, you don't got this...buy the SIM!

Liftoff has a great UX and the tracks are great. Lots of variety, nice graphics etc. However, I just can't bring myself to recommend it. I really want to recommend the game because the tracks are better than all the other sims put together but I always end up ending a session annoyed and frustrated.

The physics are ... weird. I'm not really sure how to explain it. The throttle doesn't behave like other sims nor real quads (that I've tried). It's like they've mangled the input to better suit controllers and messed it up for real radios. I find it very hard to maintain a consistent height in Liftoff whereas I can do this without even thinking in DRL, Velocidrone and all IRL quads I've tried. TBH I haven't tried with a controller because I'm only playing the sims to practice while it's raining or dark out.

Then there is the performance consistency. No matter how far I lower the settings I get these weird frame drops or something. It's very jarring and almost always throws me off.

If you're just after a drone game then cool, definitely give liftoff a go. It can be fun.
If you're after it for practice, maybe go pick up Velocidrone.

To summarize: this is a good simulator in terms of simulating drone flying and controls, and is 100% worth getting if you are interested in FPV drones or already own some and want to get additional flight time out of your day

Main complaints: this simulator wont teach you anything about video signal quality, battery sag, or dealing with wind. The parts are limited and while there are some very fun maps to freestyle in, most aren't worth flying on unless youre practicing racing or sticking to a very small area
With that said, nothing beats getting to fly for 10+ minutes without any concern for your battery or having to go pick up your quad if you crash. It's a great way to get familiar with the controls of flying a quad (even with an xbox controller) and lets you practice tricks that youre not confident in doing IRL. The lootbox system is irrelevant as its just skins for the existing parts, but ignoring the superfluous features Liftoff very much accomplishes the goal of simulating FPV drone flying

Hi,
I bought a copy of ‚ÄòLiftoff‚Äô some time back and, I have to say, it is really very good! 
Due to time constraints, however, I am only now just beginning to explore the program more thoroughly. 
I am looking to develop my drone flying skills mostly and ‚ÄòLiftoff‚Äô is about perfect for this considering that the winter weather is often unsuitable for real-life flying in my location.
Also, the summer months can be a little uncomfortable for me here and so again this means more simulator time for me.
So, the main point for me is to become a better pilot but this program is also seriously fun to play, I really like the seemingly endless options for courses, drones and levels, just great!  In addition to this there are many options for me to try which I would never attempt in real flight. It is critical for me to be a safe pilot so there are many risky maneuvers in this simulator that are out of the question for me in real flight, flying at high speed close to parked vehicles for example, or fast low-level flight over water.
So, I would like say congratulations to the builders of ‚ÄòLiftoff‚Äô and I will see you in the air.
Thanks guys,

I'm only new to drone flying. I have flown my 5 inch quad about 10 times and today I had the confidence to do some of the crazy maneuvers for my skill level. Flips, rolls, inverted turns, split-s, going through gaps, fast low flying. I would not have been able to do this without flying in lift off for several hours first. 

I'm very surprised on how accurate the simulator is compared to real life. I'm able to do the moves as I do in liftoff which accurately translates to real life, my fingers just do the move without thinking.  I did read comments in regards to liftoff being too floaty but I though it was pretty accurate. I was surprised on how much the drone really does float in the air in real life. 

I did find my drone to be a little more drifty than the ones I used in the sim but my drone isn't in liftoff anyway and I was able to quickly adapt. I could always tune one of the liftoff drone to be closer to mine.

Without liftoff I would have definitely have broken my quad by now several times over. This investment is worth every penny!

I held off on getting liftoff for quite some time, an i had heard that the physics were not very good. However it was on sale for "Sim Fest" so i decided to give it a try for my self. I actually like it a lot more then i was expecting. I have already put 8 hours on in in the couple days i have had it. At first i was confused with how the damage system worked, i would bump a couple of times, or brush some bushes, and next thing i know my quad is all over the place and can barely fly.  I had gotten so used to being able to bounce all over the place in other sims, but this sim completely changes you mentality. It make you fly much more cautiously at firs because of how easy it is to not be able to finish a race due to quad damage from the slightest of bumps. I think the infinate race is a unique game more, letting you just race as long as you want, with no brakes in between. I do however dislike the recharge and repair gates... they are almost never worth even attempting, as you are more likely to kill yourself trying to repair yourself. better off to just force a crash and be good ans new in a few seconds, rather then pend 20 seconds trying to repair yourself if you are lucky not to die from bumping into the repair station. Freestyle mode is where i hear most people spend their time. this is unique to liftoff too as it actually detects different tricks an gives you adds up points for all the tricks you do.  All in all in mot disapointed with liftoff. Dispite what i had heard... I'm actually quite liking it.

Literal crack defined as a video game (simulator). I started off bouncing off walls, trees, buildings, etc and what felt like a horrible, clunky control scheme/physics to realizing I just sucked butt and needed to warm up. This game has several different styles to play alongside a magnificent selection of drone customization options to choose from. I'm still terribly inconsistent in my racing, but from my initial startup to where I am now is miles ahead of where I thought I would be. I play with a Xbox controller and it's a little too sensitive for my liking, but I know if I got some joystick extensions it'd be more like having an actual RC controller. 

Being able to hit B to restart the races is extremely useful, I enjoy how quickly I can get back to racing after I f/up. If you're new [u]go to the settings and toggle god mode. It'll allow you to actually go through some races bouncing off of stuff and not having restart and get frustrated. (Looking at you, underground parking lot)[/u]

My critique so far for things I wish they would improve on is as follows:
- menu UI control with a controller. It's really janky and hardly works and I just have to resort to using a mouse to select things.
- maybe a joystick axis sensitivity meter/arc (not just a dead-zone section). I would really like to just manually turn down the sticks sensitivity's towards the different axis. 
- an option to toggle brightness on the checkpoint lines (I could also be missing this somewhere as well)

One of my favorite things about the singleplayer as well is that the drone NPC's don't just swamp you outta the gate. If you get faster times, they also fly faster times. It's nice because it keeps it competitive always.

I sincerely hope more people actually buy and play this game. It's so much fun, and extremely rewarding.

Liftoff is a great way to start practicing FPV drone flying. I was used for a long time to regular drone flying and got really into FPV drones after a while. So I decided to try this simulator to see the differences. This simulator helps you learn with time and practice to fly an FPV drone and apply the same skills to real life. Also, you are able to practice tricks and maneuvers without being afraid of crashing and needing to repair a drone. So if you are new to drone flying I recommend to check this game out.


You are able to use a drone transmitter as well as the DJI FPV controller which is much smoother. It is best to practice with a realistic transmitter than console controllers since it does not have the same feel at all.

The game is realistic, you find yourself being more confident when you pick up a real drone or make your own. Oh, which reminds me! There is a game option to customize your own drone. The types of Motors. Propellers, Camera, Antenna, etc. You can also download community made drones and race with the community online. It is normal to be frustrated at first since there is so much information and it may be overwhelming on how to start out. But the best way is to start out with a simulator that has physics and dynamics close enough to real life, and Liftoff does a great job.

The game alerted me to an issue i had with my TX. At first i thought it was the game, then i realized it was sometimes happening IRL too though much less noticeable than in game, probably because of the difference in speed comparing game to Real World.
Impressed with the accuracy of the game, though their devs might need some PR filter when dealing with the public as their communications with me when i had the issue was very shrude and uncaring.

My favourite drone sim of the 4 I've played.  Noobs be warned, the initial learning curve is very steep for any racing drone.  I played this for a while before the first time I tried a real racing drone, and had no problem flying the real drone.  Tons of community maps.  The tracks aren't as pretty as some of the other sims, but they are fun, and use less resources than Velocidrone.  Has a lot of options for building tracks and drones, wider range of 'rate' algorithms than others.

Liftoff is one of my favorite drone sims.  It has been good for learning how to fly a FPV drone.  The graphics are some of the best I have seen, the physics seem good, I like the ability to select multiple real drones, and I like the large selection of levels.

Absolutely horrible physics. The tiny multirotors in this so called sim feel like giant 15 pound 600 - 800mm diameter drones where they tend to float when releasing throttle. And actually I can descend way faster with a giant floaty drone than in this sim.  Maneuvering a heavy real world multirotor is much easier than this fake sim at the same speeds(up to 130mph). Its as if the developers never even piloted a multirotor before. Its all wrong... There are small adjustments in the options menu that help improve realistic handling, but it's not enough since it's the physics being wrong. 

I will recommend this product only for newbies wanting to gain minimum sufficient hand and eye coordination before taking things to the real world. 

As far as technical craziness, there is 0 excuse for this basic graphics sim with extremely tiny maps to be over 16GB! This sim should be no bigger than 4gb with all it has to offer. Optimization is horrible. There are far more graphically intensive games that run faster on max settings compared to this sim.

Liftoff is great once you get past a learning curve. Everyone gets it at their own rate. Setups and lessons to be learned from there are a lot of them out there. For me I could not just jump to it and get it. I had to spend a lot of time learning about it all. Never stop learning, it's harder if you don't have people in the hobby with you but there are tons of information to learn from out there. I love Liftoff it has saved me a fortune in drone parts and pieces as well as made me a better pilot in the real world. Good luck out there and remember to fly responsible.
A must have it you are learning to fly FPV for the first time.

Liftoff was the first sim that I purchased when I got into flying FPV back in 2019. It did a decent enough job of allowing me to get my FPV legs under me, but my focus quickly shifted away from freestyle and more towards racing. All of my time went to Velocidrone and destroying countless numbers of drones irl, so I pretty much haven't touched liftoff until just recently... and wow! The developers have done some amazing work because this is not the same simulator that it was in 2019. 
The flying characteristics feel so much better, and some of the new maps are stunning. I'd say the feel is pretty close to real life (with a well tuned quad on a perfect day) more often than not. The only thing that feels off to me is the hangtime when I cut the throttle, but it may just be that I need to tweak some settings / try a different quad.
While I haven't played in a while, it is a great way to learn freestyle that will save you a lot of money in broken quads.  I think it is pretty well as realistic as you can get.  I love the scenes.

insanely solid simulator. If you're an experienced pilot or just trying to get your feet wet before getting your first quad, liftoff is a must have. The physics are solid, environments offer a wide variety of challenging lines and enjoyable scenes, and the work bench offers a slew of components you can use to create a build similar to what you may be flying IRL.

Only downsides for me are the absence of cinewhoop platforms and maps that provide moving subjects to practice chasing/tracking. Cinewhooping is a super popular quad platform and a lot of people get into flying as a means to supplement their videography, and a sim is where they'll likely start. I recently got into cinewhooping and wish I could get flight characteristics in Liftoff that feel a bit closer to whooping.

Using Liftoff as a learning tool, I was able to confidently fly my DJI FPV drone in manual mode in real life.  Even with over 100 in-game flight hours invested, there is so much more to learn to fly freestyle the way I'd really like.

This game provided the means to practice flying from the comfort of home... in spite of the weather outside (Canadian sub-zero temperatures and snow).

Liftoff has been such a great learning tool... and I don't see myself parking it anytime soon.  And, with the recent announcement from the devs that DJI's FPV drone is coming to the game as a DLC, I'll be playing even more.  My goal is to keep using this game to learn/hone new skills which I hope will translate seamlessly to real world flying.

Liftoff is an easy recommendation to anyone wanting to learn to fly freestyle in FPV.  Hats off to the devs and thanks for such a great game.

Controller support is iffy and asking for help evidently isn't something to expect for your $20. Bought Velocidrone, had a controller issue quickly resolved by reading their docs. Their instructions did the trick for Liftoff too, but I don't feel like Liftoff has earned my business at this point.

The developer says:

    So you negatively rate Liftoff based on an issue outside 
    of Liftoff and for not finding our documentation?

So I looked at their documentation, and it didn't resolve my issue. I opened a discussion and didn't receive any help. And this response to my review is over a month after I left the review. Given the developer's assistance I'd never have gotten it working.

If there are specific requirements to get it running on a platform, those ought to be documented. This ended up being a relatively easy fix, but I was left to find it on my own after being told by the developers that it's not their problem, and that's easily worth a negative review.

hehe game that taught me how to fly real drones goes wrrrrr. (btw go get a $19 usb dongle for your transmitter so you can fly in game with an actual transmitter.)

This is worth the extra money from the free version.  It really helped me to develop my muscle memory and different things I didn't realize I was missing, and once I was able to fly my tiny whoop again it was so much "better" than having never used this simulator.

Of all the simulators, Liftoff tends to provide -- in my humble, amateur, crash-constantly opinion -- the most realistic flight characteristics when it comes to overall weight/G-force/gravity; and PID tuning. DRL is too floaty, and other sims I've played feel just about the same. Slap a large enough battery and cameras on your frame in Liftoff, and turn on prop wash and battery simulation. You'll get proper V-drop feelings, you'll feel the weight of your quad in your sticks, and overall, you'll get good training. 

I'm a huge fan of the infinite races. I highly recommend any new FPV pilots take the time to run the basic infinite race options on the haybale/farm map. It's the best way to really get comfortable with YAW and THROTTLE CONTROL! The two biggest things that I think cause trouble (crashes) for all new pilots. 

Other small details that really make Liftoff a good simulator: Camera noise / VTX signal simulation, fisheye effects, very realistic specs on all available parts (motors, frames, cameras, etc), ability to properly and easily map things like turtle mode/arm/disarm on your radio in-game, and very realistic prop/arm damage when enabled.

Liftoff has been a hit or miss for me due to poor FPS and performance issues for so long. After early Jan 2022 update to v1.4, the performance issue are gone. The game runs smooth and flawlessly on every track with an average of 100+ FPS using a Gtx 1070 on high settings. Now that it runs good, the physics feel good and realistic too. I have other sims too and Liftoff feels equally good. It appears to me that once you pass beginners stage, all sims have far more similarities and small differences. I am using a cheap Flysky radio with USB dongle and Liftoff detects it automatically. I never expected this overhaul for such an old title. This deserves a "Labour of Love" award.

I've enjoyed this simulator a lot more than I expected to.  I bought it after a Youtuber recommended getting a controller and simulator and learning to fly before buying a real drone.

I've been flying FPV on and off for a couple of years. Flying in Horizon/Level mode is the only way I knew how to control the quad until I bought Liftoff. Since flying the Liftoff simulator I am able to fly in Acro mode now! It is very difficult to learn at the beginning but once I got the hang of it I'll never go back. Surprisingly the quad is easier to control and manipulate in acro. Once I get about 10 to 15 hours on the simulator I'll go out and fly my Elegant GEPRC and see how it goes. LIftoff is awesome and I'd recommend for anyone who wants to learn how to fly a quad copter in Horizon or Acro. Before you go by a 300 or 400 dollar quad, go buy a good Radio transmitter like Spectrum or Taranis then get Liftoff. You'll be good to go.

OLD REVIEW:

After learning how to fly a drone thanks to this game, and later spending hundreds of hours trying to get better a it, I think i'm finally ready to give a fair review of Liftoff. I started without a very good understanding about drones, so i tried all the alternatives available in the PC drone sim market and found Liftoff to be the most convincing in terms of physics, graphics, UI, ease of use, features, maps, etc. I was not dissapointed at all, and started practicing... A lot. And a lot...

Where it shines the most is the community's involvement, people can share drones, configs, custom maps through the Workshop and it works great! BUT it's still a little bit on the limited side (you can't import external map files of any format, you can only place some props, basic shapes with basic textures on top of the base maps". Don't get me wrong, the map creators are awesome and some people have managed to create wonderful maps anyway, so we can only dream about what they could do with better tools. A suggestion could be let players apply textures to the shapes (wood, metal, cement, plastic, windows, etc), create materials (stuff like simple water, lava, swamp), COLLECTABLES (there are many explorable maps). If that was possible i think the community would blow up in creativity and the game in popularity.

Personally i love the adition of "unusual" parts like the UFO one for example, that kind of customization is always welcomed and works wonders to motivate new players to play the game and old ones to keep flying (although i think the leveling system should totally reward points for free flight sessions (as they're the ones most people use to actually practice).
Love  it !!

Liftoff has been a STAPLE in the FPV Community. I'm going to call it one of the "big three" -- Drone Racing League Sim, Liftoff & Velocidrone. I personally do chores every day on each of these simulators but Liftoff is the sim I always come back to for the pilot community. The graphics work great on even slower computers but when you have a big screen & good video card the experience is pretty great. Physics are mostly realistic but really feel the best out of these three.

There are other drone simulators out there that we could compare with Liftoff, however those lack the multiplayer aspect so we won't.

There are many maps to choose from & lots of races. Community maps are creative & varied.

If you're flying FPV already & don't have Liftoff, i'm not sure why not! Get it now.

If you don't already have a pointedly supported flight controller, don't bother. Using an xbox controller is effectively impossible, and any of the inexpensive USB compatible options don't consistently work.

This wouldn't be a huge issue if the level of support and configuration in game was literally anything more helpful than a locked out, blank config screen if the game isn't autodetecting your controller and a message that comes off as "Don't even ask for help from us. Call the manufacturer."

Some level of forcible manual configuration would be nice. I know I'm working with substandard options (BetaFPV xbox-shaped controller), but let me actually see what the game is looking at so I can troubleshoot would be amazing.

If I can get my controller to work again or consistently, I'd LOVE to recommend this game. The times the controller works, I find the in-game behaviors to be great and super adjustable for beginners, allowing you to get the ropes without the penalty of crashing.

So yeah, if you've got a supported flight control setup, this is definitely the game for you. If you don't have the gear, this game will be a frustrating tease.

This game is great for warming up the sticks and is very accurate to real FPV drones physics. This game is perfect if you are unable to fly your drone if you live in a city where you are unable to or because the weather is unsuitable for flying. Overall the best part of this game is that you can freely practice and experiment with new tricks without the risk of crashing your expensive drone and being forced to buy a new one or replace parts. This game is also very good for newcomers to the sport and is personally how I started and got into FPV flying. You can easily set up an Xbox1 controller and play freely before buying the real thing. This is overall a great simulator and very fun. The only downside is that the mapping tools are less than suitable. The mapping tools only give you a preset number of basic objects that you can use to make a map, which isn't bad if you are wanting to revamp one of the many premade maps and make your courses, but are terrible if you want to make a map from complete scratch. I wanted to make a map of Dust 2 from CSGO but was met with the unfortunate realization that I would not be able to due to the mapping restraints. Other than that there is nothing bad about this game whatsoever. 10/10 I would (and I have) recommended this game to people before they decide to buy a drone, and to people who just want to fly without leaving their house.

I was hoping that I could use LIFT OFF as a simulator for learning how to fly my drone, but it does not even remotely translate to how a drone actually behaves. I tried several settings, several workshop drones but same results. There is no air friction or drag, when you turn up the throttle there is no kick, when you release the throttle the drone does not fall, it just descends. When you try turning yaw and roll at the same time the drone continues in the same direction it was travelling. The drone behaves like it is in space. It just goes infinitely in direction it was set to. There is no drag, no air resistance it is absurd. I don't want to learn how to fly in space, I want to learn how to fly with my drone when I am unable to use it outside. This does not work as a simulator at all for that purpose and it is very unfortunate that Rotor Riot supports this game. I am instead learning how to fly in real world and get much better flight results than in this game. When I am learning flying in this game, my skill actually degrades in real world because the physics is not remotely similar.
I can imagine a lot of people can have fun playing this game, but by expectations were far different.

I can really see a lot of people including myself learning to fly a fpv drone on this sim, its going to be a really useful tool for many, including myself, though I can already tell it could use a little tuning, the starting maps, at least, starting at the learning to turn maps, they could really use map progression points, by that I mean, starting the new pilot on a map with flags much further away then the current flags or gates are at, then as the new pilot feels they can handle the basic turning, have them move onto a map with closer and closer flags until they can make just about any turn, as it stands, I feel the learning to turn map is a little too progressive, the gates are too close for a beginner, also a map maker would fix this issue too,

The other thing about the beginner map, is the map itself, the ground anyways, the flat repeated lines makes it hard to focus on how close you are to the ground, with no relateable object on the ground to give a sense of scale, my eyes tend to focus on the horizon to keep leveled then seeing how close I am to the ground, some grass, leaves, sticks, a river, keep it flat but make it easier to see how close you are to the ground, the squares make it harder,

This is a early review though, so expect a update once I log 10 plus hours.

It's good for learning but 2 things really annoy me as a beginner: more advanced tutorials are needed and the flags for the races should be ghosted. I swear I'm not hitting them. Wish there was a switch to turn them off so I could fly through them.

If you're new to FPV drones, you really need to spend time building up muscle memory, and using a game like this is a fun way to do so. What seems impossible at first will become more and more attainable as you practice. One of the big challenges is that the closeness of the standard mode 2 controls to a first-person shooter game is kind of a tease: you think your FPS-with-a-controller experience will see you through, but you've got re-learn things.

The main downside I can see with heavily leaning on a simulator for practice is that activities like races in the game arguably encourage a bit more recklessness than you'd want when flying hardware in the real world. The main upside is that you are much less likely to javelin your drone into every hard surface your first 10 flights in the real world.

I have found this simulator gives you a very realistic comprehension of flying a drone not 100% but i would say about 84%. if you want to get into flying drones but want to get all of your crashes out first then this is a must.

only 4 hours but as a real experienced but not pro to FPV this is well worth getting for any one in the FPV hobby either experienced or beginner. trying new tricks as a pro to get it down before risking damaging and cost of repair to the drone saving alot of money.

the tutorials are useless being in a graphically empty area with a tiny flag to fly around does not help at all. for the newbies i would say get the game and a half decent controller and fly in one of the open area maps with some obstacles and just trail and error is best, while trying the multiple different drones available as this will give a good idea on how different weights and power respond, it will take time but just spending half hour a day flying around you will see improvements in a week.

- So many loading screens, when going into a menu or even going from a menu into another submenu. Super annoying.
- Tutorial videos are very badly integrated into the game.
- Tutorial videos are not up-to-date (they show menu entries that don't exist and only talk about two flight modes, even though there are four).
- Controls are very finicky, not sure if this is the same for real life FPV drones, but only moving the analog stick on my PS4 controller a few millimeters resulted in the drone to completely spin out of control. My thumbs hurt after a few minutes of playing because I had to tense them up so badly. I did not find a way to fine tune the controls.
+ Game runs smoothly on my system at least.

Maybe this game plays better with an actual RC controller, but if you're planning on using something like a PS4 controller, I cannot recommend this.
Definitely worth it.

Update on my previous n depth review: :-)

After 20 or so hours on this sim and finally hitting that acro switch on my brand new DJI FPV I can well and truly confirm that the practice and basic skills learned in the sim do infact translate to flying in real life.

As a total newbie i bought the DJI FPV combo after watching some youtube vids and thought wow! that looks awesome, how do I get into that.

I very quickly realised that I had stepped into a whole new world of fanatical FPV hobbyists.

Right or wrong or wether you hate or love the DJI FPV drone Im stuck with it and need to learn how to fly the XXXXXXXX thing. I love normal and sport mode but have quickly outgrown it.

Also, quickly to add. I bought the drone with the premise I could practice on their drone exclusive sim. I quickly learned that it was only available on apple. wtf? lol.

Long story short. I found Liftoff on a youtube vid. I have a steam account and have been a massive FPS gamer for 15 years plus (not no much this last few)

I bought it and loved it from the getgo. So Soooo hard to get to grips with FPV controls (for me anyway) I want to be great straight away but learned quickly it was going to take time, patience and many hours to build that muscle memory.

That's all it is btw.. Building that muscle memory. Every hour spent makes movements on the controller happen quicker and without thinking about it so much.

Graphics are great. 
controller works great
customisation is awesome
tutorials are great

If you are like me and wanting to practice before crashing your expensive bit of kit then this is it.
Translation of the controls in this sim to real life flying are not 100% but are damn sure certain to give you the skills to keep your drone in the air and make some pretty cool moves. You will know right away that the in sim practice has been worthy of your time.

For fun or for practising before real life first flight then you will not be disappointed.
