my background..engineer, aero grad, been flight simming since the mid 1980s..yes before 9600baud modems,..,dial up, broad band..flight simulator 95, longbow in dos, novalogic, janes series..you name it..and flown RC fixed wings, gas, glow, nicad, nimh, lipo, turbine, rc helis 3d helis, micro, large scale..drones..and ive tried velocidrone, DRL, liftoff and tinywhoop GO. im into tiny whoops and TWGo is better than Velocidrone and DRL but Liftoff is by far the best drone simulator available.

This a great simulator. I haven't yet flown in real life to know how accurate it is, but I'm pretty sure it'll give you a feel and the experience so when you do fly, it's not completely new to you. One reason to go with LiftOff versus the others is that there's multiplayer. This is fun if you're into racing and want to race other people. I don't race, but it's really fun to do freestyle with your friends and show off some of your tricks. LiftOff has great controller support for gamepads and transmitters, even though I only have experience with spectrum in this game. In the overall picture, LiftOff does complete the task of being a simulator, teaching you how to fly, but it does a little more and that's what makes it stand out.

Although it is a great and realistic simulator to practice FPV drones, I do not understand some details and ideas that make the game much less enjoyable. This is the best FPV simulator but it could offer much more with few tweaks.
First I would love a more progressive approach to the game. At the moment (after 11 hours!) I am really struggling in completing the easiest races of the lowest levels. I would like to have few initial levels where you practice how to use sticks (maybe using only few of them at the beginning), like moving in a direction, doing one large turn, ... in a slightly competitive way, and then gradually increasing the difficulty of the tracks. The game at the moment makes me very nervous trying to go through those small gates.
Secondly I do not understand why, when I touch the ground (at any speed and direction), I bounce high. This is not realistic at all.
I think with these features, Liftoff may be not just a drone simulator, but also a very enjoyable game, since it is very complete and it has a very good physics

The graphics aren't that great, but they're better than the competition.  I think that would go even further toward making this feel more like FPV once you leave the simulator.  With that said, it took me only a few hours to get comfortable and probably a dozen or more to get adequate.  Flying in acro mode is tough, but it's what you want to do.  I enjoy the tuning aspect, but wish it was a little bit more like Velocidrone's implementation with a reproduction of BetaFlight.  Would be even cooler if you could simulate the other interfaces too.  With that said, the simulator does its job, and does it very well.  The challenge is the hardest part, but if there's high enough engagement that helps make it tolerable and get more people over the hurdle.  Lastly, the physics feel pretty darn good - maybe slightly floaty/twitchy compared to real life, but that's a very subtle nitpick I'm noticing.  Well done Liftoff!

When I compare the Liftoff vs the DRL (another FPV drone racing sim on Steam), Liftoff's physics feel much more realistic than the DRL's in my opinion. I also like maps of the Liftoff more. Maps are closer to what you will experience in a real life, they are not so dark and obscure, and they simply just make more sense in general. There is even a Joshua Bardwell's yard in this game, a nice trifle :).

Liftoff has an OSD similar to what you get through Betaflight, I appreciate the artificial horizon. There is even a battery voltage indicator. The rewind feature is a better idea than just a distracting reset button in DRL. There is also some damage model in this game. Your props get damaged based on the type of impact and the object you collide with - hitting an inflatable gate, flag or a wall has different effects in terms of drone's reaction and props damage, same with going through the tree-tops - I really like the developers thought about this.

Multiplayer offers "Infinite race" mode where you can join whenever you want and don't have to catch the short moment before the race. I like hanging around sometimes, improving my own times in multiplayer, having some real people around and maybe learn from them a little. I don't really have to compete with others, given my current skill level there is not much chance anyway :)). 

There are still things that could be improved. The tutorial section is there, but it's really basic and quite boring. Most importantly I would like to see some kind of campaign mode that would make use of the game's content that's already there. It would be nice if the player could be led through the available races from easier to more demanding ones and feel some progress without having to decide what to do next. Or maybe even something more advanced like starting with some cheap basic drone, racing and earning points for buying better ones, tuning them etc, I believe this would bring yet another entertaining dimension to the game :). 

All in all, I think the Liftoff is a good choice if you want to practice the FPV piloting skills without damaging your drone and If I'd have to choose this or DRL, I would definitely pick the Liftoff.

P.S.: I experienced no game-crashes. For me the game runs fluently without hiccups. It also works fine with my Radiomaster TX12 radio (although it is detected as the Taranis :).

I got a flying machine!

I'm fairly new to FPV (this is my second stint). The first time around, I found Liftoff more difficult than flying in real life...but real life took my drone away from me. (A nice gust of wind, video transmission loss and a large forest swallowed it up.) I still loved flying, though, so I decided to give it another go. I wanted to be serious about it and put in a lot of sim time this go around. I have Liftoff, Velocidrone, DRL, FPV Air 2 and FPV Freerider. Of all of these, Liftoff keeps me coming back. Each sim has different things that I like more than the other, but Liftoff is where I really built my confidence. I think it may be the perfect sim if they integrated the workshop items into the game somehow, similar to using user-created quads in DRL. (I don't care much for going into the Steam Workshop and subbing to a quad/track/etc.) Other than that, I love this game. For beginners I suggest just going into free flight and flying around. Get used to the sticks, hovering, moving in a straight line. Then start to mix in long sweeping turns, getting them tighter and tighter with stick coordination. Eventually, you'll find that Liftoff isn't in fact that difficult. It's fun as hell. I'm 18 hours in (in the past two weeks) and I've just now started racing and hitting gates successfully. (I previously did nothing but freestyle, learning stuff like the split s.) If you're serious about flying, this is a great place to start. Just have patience. It will all come with time! Happy flying!

Amazing FPV simulator.

Tried it for almost two hours and then refunded.

I really like the way the drones "feel", the mechanics and physics. The rewind option (when you crash you can quickly rewind the last few seconds) is a great idea, The OSD is simple but great and there are some really nice environments.

However - the game is definitely sub-par on the tech side. Runs only okay on my desktops (RTX 2070 Super / 1080Ti), with frames jumping like crazy. Rendering distance is a joke, even on max settings (vents on roofs pop up 50 m before you, trees look horrible until you're pretty much right in front of them). My Thinkpad Extreme Gen2 laptop makes this game into a stuttering experience that looks straight out of 2005. 

I could live with all this, if I had to - but to be honest, not if I can just go and buy DRL Sim for less than half the price and, though it needs some tuning to feel as snappy as Liftoff and lacks the OSD (why?), it has more and better looking tracks and just runs beautifully on any system I've tried. It also looks and runs better on my laptop than Liftoff does on the desktop. 

If Liftoff was better optimized I'd be down, as there's a lot of potential here. But it isn't and I'm afraid it won't get there. Until then, I'll play the better, cheaper and overall more polished alternative and hope for Liftoff 2.

If you have a strong gaming rig give it a try and compare for yourself. If not I'd recommend you just save your time and buy DRL Simulator instead.

As a newbie to quad racing with interest in it, and was recommended by the youtube channel Flite Test to try it. I could not possibly be more turned off to the idea. I realized that the controls are meant to use an Actual transmitter, which i dont have because i'm using this to see if i should invest in a set. So i used an xbox controller. Good grief one slight adjustment and you're spinning out of control, glitched into the floor and having a fit. I looked at the tutorials and most of them were videos that wouldn't load because it used the Steam browser. So i went back into freeflight mode and just tried to get it off the ground. Eventually i made it actually fly and it wavered around like a drunk airborne hockey puck. I know that the throttle side also adjusts the turn, but my god this does not work for a regular controller. Also why is one of the triggers what switches songs. that should be throttle. Ugh. If this is an accurate representation of how drones work and react, then i have no idea how anyone could fly one of these. Im going back to driving brushless buggies.

If you are just starting out in FPV drone flying this is an absolute must! Not only for controlling the drone but building drones with different components, tuning the flight controller software etc. And the big bonus to using LiftOff? It will save you hundreds or thousands in damaged drones while you learn how to fly. Also if you are new to FPV it will teach you how to set up and connect your transmitter to LiftOff and then use the same transmitter for your real drone.

If you have flown (real) airplanes before as I have the drone is NOT an airplane. There is no such thing as a trimmed up hands off flying mode. Straight and level is not a thing etc. The drone is truly 3 dimensional in a hurry and LiftOff manages the inertia well and the HIGE/HOGE  events too. 

As a game only the price is good but the RC Transmitters are expensive. But there is a free flight training field, match races and I believe multiplayer races too although I am not that far.

Edit: I found out that the game is not good at handling many-core processors. If you manually set the CPU affinity in process explorer so that it only runs on the first 6 cores (for me) it runs very smoothly and usually maintains close to 120FPS even at 4K high settings. A lot of people have had this issue for years. Disappointed the developers haven't addressed this.

Have been thinking about getting a drone / FPV setup for a while but I've never had the opportunity to fly one in real life. I cannot speak to the realism of this game when compared to real life flying, but so far it seems extremely touchy. Maybe drones in real life feel like a rabid squirrel on cocaine. I'm playing with an xbox controller, and it really doesn't feel like this game has been designed to work with it. Half the time the menus don't respond to my controller and I have to use the mouse. There is no place to just view what all the buttons our bound to or what anything is. This is definitely a experience that expects you to know what the difference between all the different flight modes is because it sure as heck doesn't tell you. The tutorial is a joke, its just a bunch of youtube videos. I didn't buy a game to watch youtube, make an in game tutorial. It would also be nice to know what the difference is between all the quads in some way. Is there one that is good for beginners? Who knows, because it doesn't give you any information on the drone selection screen.

Overall, if you have zero experience with a drone and are wondering what its' like, this at least for me was a great way to know that it's 100% not a good idea to just go buy a drone and try to learn how to fly with that. This game does not hold your hand in any way, which is a shame because I think it's a really good tool for people who are thinking about getting a drone. It could have easily shown me what's going on, how do get some basic understanding of how to fly, etc but it doesn't.

All of that said, im not ready to give up on it. Once you manage to get the drone to fly around a bit and you make a few turns, it's pretty damn fun. I am going to keep at it, try to get more practice in this and eventually I'll buy a tiny whoop or something cheap and small to mess with.

I'd still recommend if you have a interest in drones. I just hope they improve the first time experience and help make the learning curve a little less steep.

Update 1:
Almost 7hrs of gameplay now and starting to get the hang of things. Have completed a few races around the very first track. Starting to get the feel for how to control my turns / speed / height. I think there needs to be some more structure put into a beginner experience, but if you just stick with it it clicks after a while. Definately a must have for people with zero flight experience. I'm looking forward to getting my first micro quad (Inductrix FPV Plus) in a few weeks. Hopefully the effort put into this will translate. Will update once I get some real-world flight time under my belt.

Update 2:
Well, I've come back to this game after having got a quad in real life and learned to fly it. Able to fly in arco mode now and even win some races. Overall, this is a decent training tool and it did convince me to get my first quad so that is great. You're able to learn how to fly, by crashing over and over, without ever damaging your real life quad. It doesn't feel like a real quad, but its close enough to just get time on the sticks in the off season. Funny enough, you still can't just use the controller to navigate the menus and need to use a mouse half the time. There is still VERY little explained in the game and overall really doesn't make it easier for new pilots to learn the ropes. Its sad to see many of my complaints from YEARS ago still not fixed / addressed even with semi regular updates. Nothing compares to real world FPV flight, but this is good enough and fun to run laps in during the winter. Gonna try some other drones sims and see what ones feel best now I think.

It's a very good simulator. I have found a bunch of minor cons, and a lot of pros. The following are from my personal experience with this simulator (updated after 24 hours of gameplay):

Pros:
- Feels quite realistic in terms of how it flies (not 100% spot on, but close enough)
- Great for developing muscle memory and practicing manovers
- Lots of tracks, and can be expanded by steam workshop (improvement: entire maps from workshop + a map editor or SDK to allow conversion of any maps (from other games for example))
- Controller setup was easy
- In-game HUD almost corresponds to what I see in my FPV headset
- The game looks great (improvement: could be more realistic (hay balls don't reflect nearly as much light, the entire environment is static etc))
- Decent training scenarios
- Can build your own tracks
- Decent looking graphics

Cons:
- Even at fantastic graphics setting, objects tend to pop in and out of view (disturbing specially on the Hannover map, where flying in the park, benches, poles etc just pop into view)
- Exclusive fullscreen option is now there, but it doesn't work on vulkan (didn't try the other, windows and outlook notifications are still quite disturbing)
- Ground still feels like you're on ice
- Camera noise feature is still very unrealistic
- Adjusting camera angle in-game is painful, I have a lot of analog inputs, it would be nice if the camera angle would adjust slower when I move the slider less
- Main menu is awkward to navigate with mouse/keyboard
Pre flying for the first time in the real world, this has been a useful learning environment and a bit of fun too

Do you want to learn to fly FPV? Do you want to learn cool stuff without spending thousands on broken drones? Welcome to Liftoff. This simulator helped me grasp the basics before I actually put a drone in the air and is still helping me practice much more difficult maneuvers without having to fix and pay for crashed drones. I did have about 400 hours flying normal drones for work and fun before getting into FPV but the flight characteristics were so different that it really didn't help. This is the way to go. You won't regret it unless you just don't like having fun.

While not the pinnacle of flight physics (improving constantly!) out of all the other drone sims, it is definitely high accuracy. Tuning and building are functional and also becoming deeper as the sim is improved. If you fly a quad in real life you will not find it difficult to build a sim version that performs within 90%. I own multiple drone sims that i fly for different reasons but this one is where i come to put on some chill music and get into the groove of flying. ANY sim is recommended for beginners but this one is what i would put on top to jump right in and learn/train stick muscle memory.

If you're thinking about flying FPV, you have to get a simulator. When you first fly a quad, you will crash, ALOT. It's best to get the first few hundred crashes done in a simulator instead of breaking components that cost a lot of money. For $20 you're probably saving hundreds of dollars that would have been spent in drone parts. I flew in liftoff for probably around 15 hours before flying a real drone (which was a small whoop drone, a mobula 7), and I was actually able to have some real fun with it out of the box without a crazy number of crashes. I still come back to the sim to practice new tricks that I‚Äôm too scared to try on a real quad, or practice racing skills.

If you‚Äôre going to play this game you NEED a radio transmitter for a decent experience. If you try to fly with a video game controller you‚Äôre in for a bad time. You can get the betaFPV controller for $40 which I hear is a good budget choice.

People argue about which simulator is best, but it's important to keep in mind that no simulator will ever feel exactly like real life, most FPV simulators to me feel "floaty", it‚Äôs hard to explain but it almost feels like the quad doesn't have as much weight and momentum as in real life. If you‚Äôre just starting out, this doesn‚Äôt matter at all, and just learning how the sticks control the quad is by far the most important part. Get whichever one has the most features, and I think liftoff has plenty and nice selection of quads and maps.

Flying (in acro, which is what you should learn to fly) is extremely hard by the way, and you should really be using Youtube to help you understand how to fly. Don‚Äôt be discouraged at the start, because you will be continually crashing and it takes a while to learn, but don‚Äôt worry you will improve quickly.

So far I have been honing my flying skills on Liftoff, DRL Simulator and Velocidrone (starting from zero), and while none of them is perfect and each one has their own strength and weaknesses, I found Liftoff to be my go-to choice almost every time (with DRL being second). There are two specific reasons for this:

First, map selection. The available maps cover a wide range of different terrains and especially the large outdoor maps like "Green" and "Hannover" are great for learning new freestyle moves. This is helped by the fact that the graphics are quite good in general and especially the rendering of trees and foliage works well for me to match what I'm seeing in the goggles when out flying in real life.

Second, although none of the sims I've tried so far provides the ability to really customize every detail of a custom quad build, Liftoff definitely offers the widest range of options that actually have a noticeable effect on flying behavior. I had a lot of fun testing out different combinations of motors and props. This is only hampered by the fact that switching between the workbench and the test flight is rather clunky user experience wise and even though loading times have improved over the last year, it still takes too long to switch between screens.

At this point it should be clear enough that I am not really a racer - although Liftoff offers a handfull of race tracks on each map and supports online races, the overall selection is propably too small for hardcore racers. Also the track editor is incredibly finnicky and tedious to use in my (admittedly limited) experience with it. Someone looking to train for serious drone racing would probably be better served with Velocidrone's plethora of MultiGP tracks or DRL's tight, technical 3D tracks.

For me though the point of a sim is to practice general muscle memory, improve throttle control and have fun learning new tricks. It doesn't have to be perfectly accurate in simulating flight dynamics (IMO none of them is) but rather reveal mistakes in my flying and keep them from becoming too costly by having to learn from them in real life - basically good enough to get me 80% there. Having said that, the physics simulation in Liftoff actually feels pretty good to me. It does a decent job of matching what I experience out in the field, and I found that if I can pull off a move in Liftoff then I will 90% also be able to do it IRL - which, for me, is exactly the point of practicing in a sim.
This is a great simulator... recommended for many of the best pilots.

Wow. I've been toying around with Liftoff since the early days, and I recognized it for what it was: a decent simulator that can help can help familiarize and practice drone piloting skills. However, it wasn't without its faults, and never felt real - a general "floatiness" in the physics made hang time and other aerial maneuvers a little odd. 

Graphics were decent enough, and had been improved upon over the years. After several years, they've updated the graphics again. I'm not sure I could list everything that has been improved, but the game went from looking "ok" to "outstanding". Environments are detailed and immersive. What else could you ask for in a sim?

Haven't picked it up in several months, and decided to give the major update a try. I am floored - this changes everything. The physics feel real, the drones now have a weight that is similar to FPV IRL. I have raced and free-styled with a pretty powerful setup, and run something similar in Liftoff. I am flying on a Taranis X9D Plus with the FrSky USB receiver in both cases. The similarity in feel between Liftoff and real physics is astonishing. Thank you to the devs for updating and polishing Liftoff over the years. The latest update finally compelled me to sit down and recommend this simulator.

UPDATE: OK.. something has changed, and quite heavily. I've left Liftoff alone for a while, and apparently 2 massive updates have been rolled out and, it seems WAY better now, I honestly think the developers did a great work here. I will leave the previous review down below, but I have to admit the following changes:
- Load time has dramatically decreased, now it is way more acceptable.
- Realism, YES, I don't know if they did some work here, but I find liftoff a lot more realistic now.. or I'm just getting worse.. who knows :D
- Maps: New maps! Also, well.. yeah I've just realised I can import new community maps.

So, all in all, I feel I can recommend this game now. Well done!

OLD REVIEW:
While this game has some potential, it offer way less then the only other FPV sim I've tried (DRL) for much more money. First and foremost, I was complaining about the loading time in DRL. Here we go, this takes the same time DRL was taking to load the menu every single time you load a map. I mean, in this game even the settings screen is taking ages to load. The simulation is way less real than the other, on liftoff I felt like a pro, I was able to do things I could never do that easily on DRL. What I've found most annoying is the complete lack of proper freestyle maps, or at least not some map not small or flat. Most maps are like that, either too small (paris is ridiculous) or flat (almost any other except Hannover and another full of building). Who cares about Bardwell's backyard (sorry Joshua, your videos are the most useful on YT but your backyard isn't exactly an "interesting map").. Maps here are clearly for racing ONLY, interesting only if you put some obstacles.. Sure, title says "FPV drone racing", but why adding freestyle into the game if almost no map is good for freestyle? No hidden locations as well, the emptiness. What else.. Controller settings are way less customizable than on DRL, AND most of the settings requires you to go back to the main menu. ohhh, and the night mod! 4 pounds to have the sky.. dark. I was thinking it would bring more stuff. Nope. Dark sky. And some light apparently. 

Now, let's list some positive point:
1) It has 3D flight mode
2) It has the arm switch, of which use is important to practice (but you cannot disarm.. most of the keys are like that, you can set the "on", not the "off", since we all have switches on our radios an "off" mode would be just logic).
3) There are many common drones available, I even found a mobula7.
I think that is all. I never asked for a refund on steam so I don't even know if that's even a thing, but I'm so close to check now. The only reason for me to keep it, is the 3D mode, which is not available on other sims.

Developers, if you're reading this, please:
- Add some more freestlye map, with buildings or any other construction allowing to practice some trick.
- Add the OFF state for at least some proper switch binding (on, neutral, off), the arm switch without a disarm is useless, I've set the turtle mode as off, but it is not the same thing.
- Add bindings to 3D mode directly. It would be useful to change style with a switch without having to cycle through all the modes.

And again..

Night mode sold at 4 bucks is ridiculous.

----

I read a lot before purchasing Liftoff as my first quad sim. Back then, Steele had just released a yt video saying he felt Velocidrone had the best flight characteristics. Still, I thought it looked rough in comparison, so I went with Liftoff. No regrets. As a very new quad pilot, it was a great tool for getting a feel for shooting gaps and taking risks.

As I became more experienced with real quads, I came to understand what people were saying about floatiness in sims. I eventually bought Velocidrone to compare and yeah, the physics feel more realistic out of the box, but it still looks rough. I prefer Liftoff's simulated video static that changes a little with range and obstacles and the prop damage effect adds a risk element that isn't too intrusive. I wanted to improve so I could keep flying uninterrupted and it worked for me. 

Liftoff has a somewhat clunky, but pretty interface. You get to 'build' quads by throwing parts at real world frames and heck, you want a little more weight? Use a 6S battery and throw an action cam on the front. They make a noticeable difference in game. 

My first ever build was an original Skyeliner. I followed JB on yt and I wasn't too knowledgeable about the fallout over RR. Liftoff pushed all the exciting buttons for me as a fresh fan of the hobby; brands I recognised and wanted, my own quad in digital format and JB's house announced as an upcoming track. 

As an aside, just this weekend past, I rebuilt my Skyeliner and managed to reach a new height with the tune using UAVTech's 2 pack method. Propwash eliminated and even in the gustiest conditions, it feels locked in. Suddenly, Liftoff's previously more unrealistic seeming flight characteristics feel a little more realistic.

Anyway, don't hesitate to grab Liftoff if you're a beginner. It's pretty to look at and you get to crash without risk to your own gear. If anything, it'll help you reach a level you mightn't otherwise get to without a lot of time (and cash) spent picking parts, building, tuning, wrecking and rebuilding.

I had some technical issues at first that caused me to request a refund. After fiddling with the settings again and again, after submitting the request, I actually managed to fix the issue. ( no sound once controller calibrated). After I got the sound fixed, I played non-stop for 4 hours, leading me to try and cancel the refund request, but steam moved damn quick and approved the refund before I could cancel. I love this fpv sim so much, that I went right back in and RE- purchased it, now that I know I fixed the sound issue. I have been watching the youtube videos for months, and 99% of FPV droners, all said the same thing: START WITH A SIM. I am so glad I did! Had I tried to just jump into it  without fully understanding how each control axis responds, I can almost guarantee that I would have broken something on the first one I purchase. (Plan on buying the DIY Rotor Riot budget CL-1 kit. which is also available in the sim, and holy crap, it is quick!!! Plenty of power for first timers like me). Just in the few hours I have been free flying around, I have improved so much already. I am going to be purchasing my Reciever this week so I can hook it up and get a feel for the ACTUAL control setup I will be using. The sim is very user friendly. Even the most novice computer user, could get themselves in the air in no time, and there are several tutorials I HIGHLY recommend as well. There is a HUGE variety of different quads with different power, weight and control settings, and you can even go in and create your own! This sim is going to keep me occupied and learning about this new hobby I have come to love so quickly, from my current status as an entry level beginner, to the level I hope to be at someday where I can fly like these freestylers I see rippin through abandoned buildings on youtube. I highly highly recommend this sim.

But the Liftoff simulator taught me to fly in ACRO mode, gentlemen, and that's another level for you. Awesome. I recommend it to all RC pilots. Liftoff will take your heart and you will immediately buy FPV equipment, just like me. Great. Great. Great.

Not even 6 hours in, and this sim has helped me immensely. I've flown cinema drones (namely DJI) for a while, but never ventured into FPV until recently. With the DJI solely using level mode, FPV seemed like it was unattainable. I thought acro (rate) mode was impossible and I couldn't fathom how racers or freestylers could get remotely that level of control. 

I played the first 4 hours of the sim with an xbox controller, waiting for my transmitter to get delivered. The sensitivity was insane, and since the joysticks center automatically, it involved a lot of fighting the throttle to stay lower. Ironically, I think this actually helped. I just did the last 2 hours using my new Taranis X Q7 and was immediately 10x better, I assume as a result of experiencing the sensitivity of the xbox controller for the first few hours. Took my quad IRL out, switched on acro mode for the first time, and had no issues at all. 

Liftoff was an AMAZING start to learning how to fly FPV drones, and I can't recommend it enough. Surprised no reviews are talking about their most recent physics update. 

Liftoff was my first simulator, that I got a few years back when first getting into quads. It was a great start back then but I ended up favoring DRL for the bigger maps and competitive online aspects. Then I began favoring velocidrone because you could put vehicles in there to track. All three still had "moon gravity" meaning it felt floatier than an actual quad. Hang time would be literal seconds longer than in real life. All that has changed with liftoff's most recent physics update. They changed their whole engine and the driftiness, floatiness, drop, thrust... it's all amazing. It feels like flying a real quad. 

This is my new recommended sim to all beginners. The most realistic sim there is. My only gripe is the map sizes and no moving objects. I want to practice mountain surfing, following cars, following birds. Liftoff has the physics down, now I only ask for added functionality.

Almost all drone racing sims have something off with the flight physics, and liftoff is no exeption often having a strange airmode floatiness to it, but with that said, what we have here is a very solid simulator for practicing racing and general freestyle flying. The graphics are beautiful and level selection is broad, with optional race tracks for each map. You can even create your own if you so desire. An amazing sound track is also included for those who like to vibe as they rip a pack. Setting up your transmitter is the most straight forward I've seen yet making the overall experience feel very seamless. I highly recommend for those who want to practice new tricks or practices on rainy days or even those who have yet to even take there first real flight as to get their feet wet so to speak.

EDIT**



Okay.... I'm incompetent...I can now recommend this sim after and only after you make some adjustments to it. Please see below.

I previously gave this game a down vote, not recommended. I'm changing that now.

My previous review of this sim was done without proper setup of the sim. Transmitter wasn't calibrated to remove jitters, the quad selected wasn't near what I fly 

and the FC was not at all adjusted from stock....if you don't do this you won't like it.

Special note: for the love of life please adjust your FC settings. 

Hit the escape key, head into FC settings and if you do nothing else increase the "I" gain on all three parameters by ten points and keep adding 10 till your quad feels too stiff, 

then, 

bring it down by 5 points each time until it feels just right for you.
 
Warning**** 

Lf you leave the FC on stock settings the quad will feel like it's drifting, especially in turns. 

It's gonna be a B!tc# to fly and yeah it's not a good time.

NOTE***** 

You really aught to take care of those issues I've mentioned otherwise your experience with this sim will be less than satisfactory.

The main few problems:
- Once you reach level 10 or above the reward chest contents are just props with shitty patterns. We need frames, cameras, antennas.
- Still when you crash into a haystack it sucks you in to its side, same with walls. While maybe in real life this can happen, rarely ever, here it's constant and it's annoying to wait or reset manually.
- It's hard to disable arming, for some reason now I have to press a button every flight, previously it started with just the countdown.
- More mainstream products available would be awesome, sponsored or not we can pay for them. I'm willing to pay a dollar for a Reverb frame, or a dollar for Runcam Phoenix 2, etc
- It would be great for Tango 2 remote to actually utilize some buttons for arming for example

Im a guy who tries to get into FPV hobby as of 07.2020. As YouTube videos have suggested, i bought controller and connected it into PC to play simulators, before sending parts for real drone.
 This aint first sim i have tried, but its one of most reasonable sims i have played yet. It has many settings to toggle to your liking. You can choose between preset drones, that fly differently, or build your own (i would suggest building your own, as closely resembling your own as possible). Although it took some time to find a good drone for beginner, since most drones are set up for pros, with high speeds, and very sharp turns. You just want to get comfortable with controls on not very fast and agile drone, then build up your skill with faster ones.
 Potentially this sim has saved me some crash times, since i learned to fly on it. For the first time i did nothing but crash, untill i got used to controls. Gotta say, controls are not very comfortable on radio transmiters, but this sim helps you get used to it, therefore most likely you will be more comfortable when taking off with a drone for the very first time.
 I have yet to receive parts for my drone, and try my sim skills in real life, to deteremine whether this sim is good or not, but while im waiting, its good to be able to build up my skills with simple turns and tricks.

BEGINNERS - Use something else!

DEVS: If you want to avoid reviews like this in the future, get someone who has never flown a drone, give them your software and an XBox controller, and tell them to fly (using the tutorials if they want - I did!). Don't say anything else to them, just watch the disaster of them trying to use your software.

While waiting for radio to ship, I tried practicing with XBox controller. The game is unplayable because the controls are so sensitive. I spent half an hour reading online posts and trying different solutions to make it work, but nothing worked. In modern times, how can they not have a preset for XBox controllers to make it playable so that a beginner can learn the basic controls before getting a real radio? Even worse, the menu you need in order to tweak the control sensitivity is REMOVED from the tutorials. So, you need to start the tutorial mission, then back out to free play to try to do the suggested exercises so that you have access to the flight control menu that lets you mess with rates. If you are a beginner, get some other software and start with your XBox controller. Once that makes sense, pick up a radio and use it with that other software that you're used to. You'll have a way better time than trying to start with this.

This is THE FPV simulator. It works with my Flysky radio, and you can change almost everything. You can customize every aspect of the quad, you can turn on or off interference, fisheye effect, motion blur, anti-aliasing, and more. there are at least 10 maps, each with at least 5 races, and you can make more tracks for the maps. Physics are good, graphics are good, and, at lowest settings, you can run it on almost anything. My PC has a Pentium n3710, 4 gigs of ddr3, no dedicated graphics, 4gb ram is shared between integrated graphics and system, and I can get over 20 fps. It does depend on the map(i fly the pit and hangar C03). My settings are everything bottom but 600x400 res. Minimum specs are often wrong. It is worth the 20 bucks.

Liftoff is the 4th FPV Simulator I have logged substantial hours on in my FPV journey.  DRL was my favourite  simulator until I purchased Liftoff. Whilst DRL is a terrific simulator, I feel Liftoff steps it up to the next level and has dramatically improved my piloting already. It has a sense of reality perhaps more so than DRL. The freedom & ability to download any number of community based drones has pushed my skills continually as these are faster & more nimble than any factory set drone. I really enjoy being able to add new tracks and fly new drones every day and there are drones & tracks for all skill levels. 

I would rate Liftoff as the Number 1 FPV Drone Simulator on the market and whether you're a skilled FPV pilot or just beginning, I recommend Liftoff and give it 10/10.  

Thanks to the people responsible for such an awesome simulator. Please continue to keep it fresh.
Doctor Drone
Australia

I bought DRL first but I wanted to try both it and Liftoff out so I bought Liftoff after 10 hours of DRL.

DRL is fun for spec racing the DRL Drone, Liftoff is more fun and has really cool custom tracks and a great online community, and Velocidrone kicks the pants off of both of them but it's got less user-friendly features with a much more advanced online community.

Honestly just get all 3. If you had to pick 1 get Velocidrone. If it has to be on steam, get Liftoff. DRL is really fun for the qualifier maps and indoor track for practice though.

This game is the only convincing simulation of drone physics outside of a dedicated simulator.

It seems that the developers did not intend Liftoff to be a simulator of all things RC.  For that you have Realflight and AccuRC2.  Instead it focuses with razer sharp clarity on drone racing, and uses some superb physics and good graphics on the area of drones only.  No helos, no internal combustion engines, just pure 'through-the-goggles' drone racing.

Its a niche within a niche, but it does it brilliantly.  It has physics that equal that of AccuRC2 (a superb all-round RC simulator), but with far better graphics and genuinely compelling gameplay.  Too many RC sims fail to offer a compelling experience, but Liftoff works on the level of a simulator and is a cracking game in its own right.  RC sim developers take note - this is how it should be done.

You will need a proper controller to get the best out of it.  I would recommend the Interlink controllers that come with Realflight as they are easy to setup and USB controlled.  I'm no expert on controllers and I'm sure there are many options, but don't use a standard game controller as their mechanisms  are not suited for this kind of sim.

I haven't raced drones, but I have flown them and I have spent a lot of time flying RC helicopters.  Its very difficult to get the feel of RC flying right.  The way RC machines slip through the air and squirm rather than settle down, even with onboard computer control, is the reason why they are so hard to master.  Liftoff nails the feeling of a squirming, agile, nimble high-speed flyer.  Best of all, its gets the 'heft' of it right.  I can't explain it - its a feeling.  

Physics for this sort of thing is very hard to do.  Liftoff gets it right.  By contrast, the awful DCL (a bigger budget drone racer) gets the feel so wrong its shocking.

You just know when a sim is right.  And this is right.

So what are you waiting for?  If you love RC flying, or want to experience what it really feels like, then buy it.  Buy it right now.  A sim this good deserves our support.  You won't regret it.

As a complete drone noob, i decided to buy a cinewhoop as some DJI goggles, without ever having played with a drone. If it hadn't been for this simulator, i would have spent 10.000$ in lost, crashed, mauled and drowned drones by now. 

If you have absolutely no drone experience, like i had, i would recommend the following approach:

1. Investigate the market for the drone you want (don't buy yet)
2. Buy the remote controller you want, which fits the drone
3. Buy LiftOff and practice with your controller
4. When comfortable with controlling the a drone in the SIM, go and buy one in the real world.
5. Praise this game for saving you a lot of trial and errors, that would have cost you a lot of money...

Absolute must-have for drone pilots or soon-to-be pilots! Thankfully, I picked this up before buying my racing drone and was able to put in about 5-7 hours before my actual drone flights. I can say with 100% certainty that I would have crashed hard had I not practiced here first. The transmitter connectivity is great as I was able to practice on my actual transmitter and get accustomed to the layout and feel of it before the real thing. Since flying my actual drone, I can say that the mechanics, movement and feel of the simulator are fairly accurate to real-world flying (without the massive fear of crashing of course). I was able to sample PID tuning in-game and determine various Rate Profiles that seemed to fit and add similar configurations to my drone to more quickly, and safely, optimize my flying habits. Now, if it is a rainy day or late at night, I come back to this to push my limits, train more and really just have fun racing and exploring.

I've been flying Velocidrone for over a year and really enjoyed it, but thought I'd try LIFTOFF for a change of pace.  I heard a lot of positive comments about LIFTOFF so I decided to purchase it.  Boy am I glad I did!  Fantastic!!!  Well worth the money spent.   I love that there are so many options depending on how you want to fly.  I love freestyle and that's pretty much all I've flown in Velocidrone.  I felt most Velocidrone racing courses were to advanced for me.  But LIFTOFF has so many great racing courses at so many different levels.  For the first time I'm really enjoying racing, and all the racing courses LIFTOFF has to offer.  I now prefer to race rather than fly freestyle.  Thanks to LIFTOFF my flying skills are improving and I would definitely recommend  this to anyone starting out, especially if you want to learn how to race!  Don't get me wrong,  their freestyle options are great as well!!  THANKS LIFTOFF FOR A GREAT SIMULATOR!!!

So chances are I'm like many people who have considered this game....I'm getting it only because I'm new to the drone hobby. I already have a drone, but my ultimate goal is to get a real nice one, an FPV drone. I bought this after some online research deciding $20 was a great deal to give me HOURS upon hours of flight time and practice with a FPV drone. This way when i've logged 30 hours or more of straight flight time, i'll be comfortable and ready to fly a drone without literally breaking it the first day I try flying it. I already have about 2 hours in and i'm able to fly (though very janky) around the map. My brain still isn't used to the inverted controls for flight games or RC toys in general, but so far i'm loving this. If you are interested in this kind of video game cool go for it. Personally i'm using it as a way to get very proficent before I do the real thing. As a heads up, you CAN USE console controllers with this. You don't need a "Transmitter", and lord have mercy on your soul if you attempt to fly with a keyboard. You CAN ALSO PLAY IT with a computer with specs LESS THAN the minimum recommended. It may not be buttery smooth but it seems pretty dang good honestly. it gets laggy and janky when you are loading, but once you are actually FLYING your drone it seems fine.

I'll start by saying this in its current state is a $10 game tops. Maybe even $5 for the fact comparable sims are out there for $5 and run 10x better than this game in its current state.

This game is in bad need of better optimization, the fact I have a $1,500 Ryzen PC and a $1,200 Intel powered laptop and they can barely handle 60FPS on low settings is a joke for 2020. Ive played free BR and other games that run better than this and they have massive maps and textures to load not to mention all the other players and AI on the servers.

Only a handful of courses and maps, honestly for the $15 or $25 price tag they should have a minimum of 10 courses to fly. I think there is like 6.... Two of which are terrible to fly, especially for new flyers who 90% of this game is made for... 

The sounds as in all quad training games is terrible. But the physics are pretty good at least. I do also like the support of the steam community quad builds. Not sure why changing motor and camera colors are blocked by a "Premium" mode. Also why some cameras and frames are grayed out and not accessible at all. 

Conclusion: Would I recommend this game? No, not for $25... $10 sure but still boarderline not worth it even for that price. Once they optimize the game to run better, add more curses and make this an overall game its worth the $10 or $15... Till then no not even close. I actually prefer Velocidrone as far as optimization, but this game has better controls, physics and quad avability. But the fact Velocidrone is only $5 and runs 100x better its much better to learn on.

[b]TL;DR[/b]: this is a great introduction to FPV flying with decent graphics and easy-to-use menus, and a decent amount of levels and options.

First off, you'll need a [b]controller[/b]. I started with an XBox One controller and that's [i]just fine[/i].
Within less than a week, though, I connected a real transmitter/controller (by connecting my TinyHawk 2 drone, enabling HID mode for it and then using the real transmitter/controller as input for the game).

It's somewhat easier/different to play with a real controller than an XBox one, but as a beginner: that doesn't really matter. With the XBox One controller, you'll learn how to use both thumb sticks effectively. Once you know that, you'll probably map these skills to real life flying with little effort.

There are quite a few [b]levels[/b] in the game, which have various flying mode including free flight, various race tracks to practice, or running the same tracks in an actual race both single and multiplayer (I haven't played multiplayer so far). The only downside is that levels are mostly static: almost nothing in it moves.

The [b]workbench[/b] (drone editor) is very easy to use: you can chose some of the basic components that affect your flight. Components that wouldn't fit your build (e.g. propeller too big for the frame/motor)  are automatically disabled for you. The only thing I'm missing is more options for micro-sized drones (more frames, more props, more engines).

If I could [b]request features[/b], it would be:
- Even more levels; or making some of the existing ones bigger, like the city block.
- More dynamic levels (e.g. moving trees/grass)
- More options for creating custom micro-sized drones (or have some popular real-life micro-sized drones in the game!)

[b]Disclaimer:[/b] this is my first FPV experience.

[h1]200 character summary[/h1]
Liftoff is the best Drone Simulator around. Customize your build, and fly away, With Online multiplayer, Freestyle, Racing and Free Roam. It supports transmitters and feels just like the real thing.

[h1]Drone Simulator[/h1]
If you are into drones or want to buy one I would recommend buying this game first, It is a very realistic drone simulator. Flying a drone is damn hard and this will save you a ton on repairs. It can also help you understand advanced tricks without bringing you, your environment or your drone in danger. You can fine tune your build and your Flight controller to make it fly exactly as your own drone, It will help you build up confidence and some precious flight hours, day and night, weather or no weather and without changing the battery every 10 minutes.

The Customization is very good The game uses a mixture of real and fake brands, Aside from your ESCs, Flight Controller and Video TX you can exchange all parts. Not all parts have real brands on them, But all parts are based on real brand stuff, You can see the resemblance but the names are changed. The frames are mostly real frames, You can change the frames,, The motors, the battery, the antenna, the props, the fpv camera, you can even add a gopro if you like that, You can also add additional ghost weight to make it fall more.

[h1]Gamemodes [b]9/10[/b][/h1]
The game offers a bunch of gamemodes You can do Races on tracks in the maps, You can free flight and just fly around, You can do freestyle for doing tricks. Online Multiplayer is also pretty cool, You can race, free roam, or race against ghosts of the best pilots in the world. The game also has a built in level editor, You can place props in any map, add checkpoints and you have built yourself a track, You can then go on to race on it against your friends. The game offers leaderboards and a lot of options to tweak.

[h1]Gameplay [b]10/10[/b][/h1]
I have played a lot of drone simulators, But Liftoff is by far the best one, It is mostly flying around or customizing your drone. The game tracks your movement and displays tricks if you perform them, The recognition system for this is not perfect. The controls are spot on, It truly feels just like my real drone. In free flight you have to make your own objectives think I am going to do that and then try to perform it, It does not challenge you, you can always just reset your drone. Racing on the other hand is very tense, Some tracks have pretty insane corners, small gaps and high speeds. And all this while it is even hard to keep the drone in the air. It is a great experience if you are looking for a game to start or a game to get better.

[h1]Aesthetics [b]9/10[/b][/h1]
The game looks amazing, Especially the drones, You can get real close up and see many details like the screws, carbon fiber texture. The scenery is a bit less realistic but nothing to complain about. The character models are not great, But you rarely see them when roaming the levels. The Soundtrack is very Dubsteppy, But it is nice, Overall the game looks nice, and it has a great variety of levels and decors.

[h1]Performance [b]8/10[/b][/h1]
Liftoff works flawless with my transmitter, It is a Taranis X9D+ No drivers or any tweaking needed, it just works. The game runs very smooth, It could always run better, but I had no crashes. I had no stutters or anything that would impact my flight, But some levels might feel smoother when you lower the graphics a bit

[h1]Replayability [b]10/10[/b][/h1]
There is no Story, No Unlockables, This game stays fun as long as you like flying drones. The Multiplayer surely adds to the replay value, but even without, Flying a drone will always remain a challenge, It is more of a simulator than a game It is a tool to help you get better. The amount of hours you can get out of this game is virtually endless and you can always keep on getting better.

[h1]Improvements[/h1]
Cloud Save Support for your custom builds, I would love to see more brands making it to Liftoff, It is good for the game, It is a good representation of the sport. And it will only help companies with brand recognition. I would also love more maps, Maybe a Tinywhoop level, A small outdoor map with a house that has all doors and windows open, stuff like that.

Add more different parts Like Flightcontrollers, ESCs, PDBs, Then Choose what kind of Firmware you want to run, Imagine having to flash and configure BetaFlight, It would be a great learning experience and it will increase safety within the sports. Choosing the right ESCs with all those new technologies, And ofcourse the VTX, having Clearflight and stuff like that for better vision. It would make things more realistic and a lot more educational.

[h1]Workshop[/h1]
The game also has workshop support, Where you can upload your custom builds, But also custom tracks, consisting of props that you can place on existing tracks, Most of the tracks have big open areas where you can build anything really. There are over 10K workshop submissions which mostly are tracks, There is no developer curation but the community does a pretty good at rating the tracks.

[h1]Conclusion [b]9/10[/b][/h1]
Liftoff is a must have for any drone enthausiast, If are not into drones but you like stunting, racing, or insane challenges it might be right up your alley, It is incredibly hard. If you want to eventually get a drone I would advise getting a transmitter first, A controller feels very different and you might learn some wrong habits.

I recommend this simulator to anyone wanting to pick up FPV and perform their first steps. It's really okay for this. HOWEVER. I don't own a racing/freestyle quad or FPV goggles but i intend to one day as i'm getting back into the hobby of RC flight after more than a decade. Sims like this would have saved me lots of money and heartache back then. I'm only 4 hours in, mostly free flying around Joshua Bardwell's house and i'm already stoked. (I've been watching his videos and learned a lot!). And I haven't even gotten to the quad customization tuning options.

I can't speak for the realism since I've never flown a kwad, but i do fly RC helis and planes and this sim is comparable to the other RC sims i've tried like Realflight and Phoenix RC in terms of realism. But what sets Liftoff apart from those sims is that it's both a sim and a game making it fun, not just a training tooI. It's also very polished, quick to setup and fly with a good IU. I also like that it's on Steam with its regional pricing, features like the workshop and community.

Graphics are great. I really like the camera noise feature, which when set at low res (1080 or lower) with highest quality settings but AA turned off, makes it look like real analog footage. I'm getting 50fps on my i7, gtx1050ti which is acceptable considering analog FPV systems display at 30 or 25hz. 

It works with my XK X6 transmitter using a $4 Flysky SM100 PPM to USB "simulator cable".

So, coming from a freestyle/race pilot of 3 years, this is my honest review.

Honestly, the game is not terrible. I used it on rainy days and during the winter for a while to keep the rust off the fingers. The issues I have with the game are mostly just absolutely TERRIBLE optimization. I have a Ryzen 7 3700x/GTX 1080ti and the game will drop from 144 to 60 in the matter of a split second (regardless of graphics settings). This results in non-fluid gameplay, and honestly it made me feel nauseous at times. Now, don't get me started on the custom maps, those are even worse at 40-50fps. Mind you, while trying to figure out this issue, I had Afterburner, HWMonitor, etc. Running to monitor usage of CPU/GPU and see where my bottleneck may be sitting. To my surprise, the game could hardly utilise 30-40% of my GPU, while still under-delivering frames. Same with CPU, but it was near 10% when the game was running, which likely means the game doesn't use much more than 5% with my background processes running.

As for map selection, it's decent. Nothing crazy, although I did spend 3/4 of my play time in the Hannover map. It's gorgeous, and a blast to fly through. Frames seemed to hover around 80-120fps (which is still terrible compared to what an optimized game can run at). There are a few others that were good, but nothing quite compared to Hannover. 

Quad selection/parts I feel could be much better. Me and my buddies run similar setups and we were unable to find any parts to match in the game (2207.5 2750KV, closest thing in game was 2206 2600kv or 2306 2650kv, which feel drastically different from a 2207.5 high KV stator). We had to try to get around this by using lower kv/higher pitched prop or a 6s with higher pitched props and smaller battery, lowering/raising weight, playing with tune, rates, etc. Nothing seemed to really work as we wanted it to, kind of leaving us desiring more from the quad/flight characteristics. 

The physics are somewhat janky. Quad is very floaty/drifty, and doesn't seem to resemble any of my real life quads whatsoever-no matter what I change. Tried to get a heavier feel so I raised the weight, but lost all my thrust. Tried different motors, props, etc, but nothing worked as I wanted them to, or they were changing the entire flight characteristics/throttle curve too much, making me drop the weight back down and basically flying a paper quad. From racing, to freestyle- it just didn't feel right. Mentioning this to others seemed to show that most people agree with this, and that it's been an issue for years with Liftoff.

In conclusion, I ended up trying out Velocidrone and everything seemed to have fallen in place for me. Everything feels good, part selection is good, quad customization (flight characteristics, thrust, downforce, etc) all felt very natural and gave me the results that I expected. AND 200FPS CONSTANT!! I can see it drop to 195 ish every so often, but never noticed any frame drops or stutters in-game. I guess you can't go wrong with any game, as long as you're getting stick time in.. All in all, "quad feel" can be quite subjective. But if you're looking for the "end game" quad sim, I suggest you give them all a try for an hour or so before deciding which is right for you.

i like the fact that it prepares you for what fight is like in real life. it givesa new pilot a chance to get the stick movement/orientation and the ability to coordinate them all together as well as figure out rates and explore flight characteristics without the worry of crashing my real drone as well as a seasoned  pilot stick time during the winter months(or when waiting for shipping of new parts lol). i believe this is the fastest and most inexpensive  way to get into the hobby. as a newbie its very expensive to get started and this hobby has a very steep learning curve. I would recommend to any new pilot buy a transmitter and  build their first drone to have a better understanding of how to repair it when it crashes and breaks while using this sim at the same time to learn to fly. this is much faster than buying a ready to fly route as this will teach you the basics of flying as well. I bought this game not having any FPV experience at all. I was motivated to buy it because I was interested in FPV from YouTubers who fly drones, and I was eager to try it out, but I didn't want to risk an expensive drone that I didn't know how to fly, so I bought this game. After I played it for a little, I bought a simple drone, and I started out flying IRL with some experience from this game. It helped me learn the basics of flying and how it works and feels. I highly recommend this game to anyone that either already flies, or wants to because this game is very realistic to what real life drone flying has to offer.

So I decided to have a go at FPV multi-rotor flying and after trawling through the forums and watching YouTube videos, the choices for simulation training for me came down to Velocidrone or Liftoff and as I have a gaming laptop that can easily handle it, I chose Liftoff for the simple reason it's available on Steam. Connection to my Taranis radio was very simple and works great. I cannot comment on how it actually compares to real flying as I am complete noob and haven't got to that stage yet. By far the best map I found for learning is the golf course as it has paths you can use to follow at the same time as avoiding trees and branches and there are passage ways through the bottom of the clubhouse to fly through.

The one bad thing I found with this game is what you'd expect to be simple training levels seemed very difficult due to the flight characteristics of the Quad. I thought it was down to my lack of experience so I had a friend have a go who has experience of flying but he had difficulty also. I've just ignored them as the quads in the game are much easier to fly.

This game is so much fun.  I have to have my drone in 3rd person view for now (I used to fly RC helicopters and drones but not in FPV).  I love the thrill and fun of navigating the really interesting courses or just free-flying in a pine forest or other really amazing sites.

I'm still learning the technical side of acro flying but with practice I seem to start getting really good at fitting the FPV racer in the 3D space with finesse.  Until I leave it for awhile then I'm pretty clumsy but thankfully the software lets me play in horizon or level modes which helps me rebuilt my muscle memory.

I get a mild satisfaction even getting kudos/points for coming back and playing every day.  Even if I only race a few times around the track it feels like I can make progress in my points total as well.

Truly an awesome game; loads of fun to race around and fly.  I use a Spektrum DX9 bound to the WS1000.

And there's a bonus--there are tracks available on Steam from the user community.  Some of these are really clever and make use of the environment in really ingenious ways.

Well done, developers!  What a joy :)  Thanks a bunch!

--Scott

Short version: Liftoff is just great and highly recommended!

Long version:
Liftoff offers both for beginners and for experienced pilots a lot of stuff to have a ton of fun, to relax, to practice and to learn / improve flying skills!
Transfer into the real world of fpv flying is very good!
I was able to run liftoff on an old 32 bit, windows 7 system from 2007 (3 gb ram, gtx 650) on lowest settings. System requirements are not too high. Of course newer systems let you enjoy the eye candy, and performance is better.

Pros:
-varied simulator with a lot of different environments, (a vast number of custom) tracks and races, copter setups
- helps to learn how to fly (also in real world)
- gives the opportunity to practice in a professional way and to expand given limits when racing or just to relax when crusing around or to practice new tricks in freestyle mode
- inexpensive 
- works with a lot of differnt hardware (pc systems, different controllers)
- very active developer team that listens to its clients and with good humor
- great features like the liftoff pro league with prices and badges
- very active and great community
- ...

Cons:
- imho there are no really cons. I always found a way to enjoy liftoff

There is still room for improvements though like more different multiplayer modes or different racing modes (probably developer team is already working on that)

Conclusion: Every second spent in Liftoff was worth - Highly recommended!

I want to like this sim, but has 2 [b]*MAJOR*[/b] issues.

1. [b]Horrible performance[/b] for what it does.
With  all graphics settings set to minimum and resolution 1440 x 900,
I can't f only play in the first level (yellow field).
It gets ~50FPS with occasional hiccups.

All other levels are simply unplayable <30 FPS, huge input lag. 

I tried it on 2 laptops:
- OS X 10.14.4
- MacBookPro11,3 (late 2013), Intel Core i7 2.4GHz
- NVIDIA GeForce GT 750M
- it's not a new laptop, but played waaaaay more complex looking games like League of Legends, Metro and GTA5 with medium settings without a hiccup.

- OS X 10.14.4
- MacBookPro12,1 (late 2016), Intel Core i7 3.1GHz
- Intel Iris Graphics 6100

2. Menu loading time is a joke. Several seconds (!) for transitions between menu screens.
[b]OMFG. Hello, developers![/b] This is just one screen with a bunch of buttons and a simple 3D scene. The response time in entire menu should be <100ms. For such a game there only 2 moments that can have excuse for loading time:
- initial start of the game
- loading a new level
Note: coming back from flying to menu system should be instant.

Another thing is that you can not change or even see(!) key/transmitter key bindings when flying - this menu is simply not available when flying. It feels like it was written by a bunch of low-paid interns.

TL;DR Liftoff is a lot of fun, with pretty good physics, top of the line graphics, a good number of courses and up-to-date quads that can be played with my real transmitter.

I had been learning to fly quads using RealFlight 8, which has a great simulation system and the ability to build your own from scratch. However, the environments there feel pretty sparse and spread out so it feels boring pretty quickly. I decided to jump on Liftoff since it looked to have more of an arcade feel.

Entertainment - This is what keeps me coming back. I pretty much learned to fly FPV exclusively from doing races, and by doing races I mean spending a few hours trying to get through my first lap. There are different styles of gates, from arches to inflatable tubular gates, and flags, scaffolds and plenty of bits worked in from the environment. It makes each race feel more unique instead of just the same arches with different scenery. The ghosts let you race without feeling lonely, but there's also multiplayer you can hop in and see just how bad you are. The Freestyle mode is ok, detecting tricks with multipliers and such, but I prefer the Free Fly with trick detection turned on so that mode isn't as fun as race is.

Simulation - The physics simulation is pretty good. The quad handles correctly and feels like it has the right weight, but it handles too well. It is like it is an idealized quad that flies super locked in. It seems impossible to generate any propwash and even though you can adjust the PIDs, it doesn't really seem to ever handle badly until you jack the numbers up so high that I think the simulation just breaks and the quad flips out. Being able to change rates in a Betaflight-like UI is great and very effective though.

Equipment - There's a small variety of quads available to which you can swap out parts to change the feel. Things are modern so you'll see parts you recognize people using today, which lets you pick parts that match your system or try out new things. The parts selection isn't very big, although there's not huge amount of variety in the real world either (how many 2207 2400KV motors do you need?). There's a bunch of ~5" quads and some variety on either side of that, but no whoops.

Graphics - The graphics really shine and there's even modes for simulating video interference. The environments are very different and allow different styles instead of being all compact technical courses.

Controls - I play with my Taranis and it really helps to match the feel of flying. However, the UI is tough to navigate with the sticks even once it is all configured, but once you're in a race/freefly/freestyle, you can use the controller to restart so I guess it is ok. There is ~100ms of lag between moving the sticks and seeing them move on the screen though (tested with camera), no matter what my settings.

-Pro-
*A fantastic way to learn how to fly Quadcopters
*Works with FlySky FS-i6
*Good selection of parts to try
*No broken props to replace
*Kids can try to fly a Big Boy QWAD
*Even works when raining
*Pays for itself with every crash

-Con-
*Menu to select parts could be cleaner, better detailed to understand what a part will do
*No Replay Mode
*No Micro Quadcopters (aka sub-250g)
*No Free Mode LZ Pad

I really like this simulator. The maps are big and you have a lot of them to choose from. You also get a lage variety of different drones. The race couses are pretty difficult sometimes but there are easier tracks as well. You can build your own tracks as well via the track editor (havent tried it yet). Ive never flown a real race drone so I cant judge how realistically these drones fly.
You also have the possibility to "build" your own drones. I tested it and I figured out that I suck at it. It is really hard to do this properly because you need to PID-tune the quads (dont worry when you dont know what PID-tuning is). The features are nice. You can paint your drones and have skins for them but they dont affect your drone in any way.
I havent tried the multiplayer mode yet.
The different modes like race, free flight and freestyle are nice. I like free flight and race the most because the mechanic of the game doesnt alwasy detect your stunts in freestyle mode.
But after all these features I have a rather big complain: Liftoff crashes a LOT. Im running a farily well computer on Windows 10 x64 bit but Liftoff crashes almost always after approximately one hour of flying (I run the lowest graphics possible on 1440p). I even had crashes afer just half an hour. I dont know how it will be on other computers but for me this is an issue. (LuGus please fix that)
I also think that the price of 20 bucks is a bit high but looking back at it after about 30 hours of playing I thik I would buy it again because the game is just so nice.
All in all I think buying Liftoff is worth it for you if you want to learn to fly a race quad (you need a transmitter or a game contoller of some kind that works similar to a transmitter or so to really enjoy/learn it). But you need to think about the crashes being an issue for you (can be already fixed when you read this) and wether you want to spend 20 bucks on it.
For me the purchase was worth it. I learned to fly reasonably in this thing. I hope I coverd all the basic and important aspects (I probably havent).

This game seemed great at first but multiple issue soon became apparent. First off, in several map groups the game is unplayable as there is a significant amount of blur, so much so that I cannot tell apart a tree from a gate. Secondly (and worst of all), high speed 6s setups (at least for me) are unobtainable; 90% of the motors do not work with a 6s setup (at least for me) without shooting to 100% power at 10% stick. I am only able to somewhat simulate my actual quad with one hypetrain motor (I dont think its a coincidence), therefore negating the benefit and purpose of this simulator. Please fix this in a patch. Lastly, it is impossible to turn off airmode- dont get me wrong, airmode is beneficial but not when the idle value makes the quad skyrocket when hitting the ground or adding to the already floaty feel of the quad.

This sim has very arcadey physics.  You can build and fly ridiculous quads and download and race through insane user built tracks.  You can also try out 3D and other flight modes.  The multiplayer is very well fleshed out, with a pro-league that runs every now and then.  Liftoff has good customization with tons of parts and loot boxes to unlock cosmetic changes.  The track builder is very good, you can build simple MultiGP tracks or crazy flying castles.  And Steam workshop makes it very easy to find and download new quads or tracks.  The devs are also consistently updating Liftoff every few months.  Needs a rather beefy computer to run well, most non-gaming laptops won‚Äôt be able to run it.
Best sim out there.

Liftoff is a fantastic sim/game if you want to learn to fly racing/freestyle drones IRL. If you already fly it's a great way to practice racing or doing new freestyle tricks without destroying your real drone. The physics are not totally realistic but it's close enough. There are many drones to pick from in the game or you can build them how you like. There's a good variety of tracks,a track editor and Steam Workshop support. There's also a mutiplayer mode. Highly recommend!

DCS World
Velocidrone
FPV Freerider

Great job team, best sim overall!

Lower End PC's: Turn your resolution down: any FPV goggles wont have a high resulution either, so it doesnt take away much except eye candy that would not be there with a real drone.
Higher end PC's,  I would advice the same .. get it as real as possible so you wont be thrown off by bad video when you go for real.

All soms (ALL!!!) will have to be tweaked to get the feeling of your specific drone. A LOT of the 'this simulator is floaty' stuff comes from PC's that are not up to the task of calculating the physics and providing the visuals, and thus take longer .. the game time slows down, and while everything is still simulated accurate, it feels off. Lower your settings if this happens for you.
As in: set it to ultra low, see how that flies, now you have a reference.

With the addition of Bando City, this is now my favourite freestyle playground. FPV Air 2 still wins for racing, mainly due to the good tracks and the 'no hassle fly now' approach. You did sortof take away the only reason to fire up velocidrone, well done I guess!
This sim is perfect to get a taste for fpv before dropping money on all the equipment, and after you do it still works great to hone skills and fly when you can't get out.

So far I love this sim. I have not actually flown fpv before but this will get me on the right track to flying the real thing. 

The graphics requirements are higher that what I have but I am able to play it with no problem. I have intel HD4000+ graphics with 16GB ram and i7 3720QM cpu. I set all the stuff to the lowest and select fastest in the drop down. Set the frame rate to 60 and resolution to 1820x1080. It runs smooth as butter.
Not recommended. very poorly optimised. Makes it unplayable and not fit for purpose unless you have a high end rig.  Buy Velocidrone instead, runs much better.

Awesome sim if you want to learn to fly FPV drones.  I've flown well over 100 packs irl and over 100 hours of sim time, and I have to say flying on Liftoff helped me up my skills way faster then if I'd just destroyed my quad time and time again.

Cool game. I've never flown a real drone, so I can't say for certain how realistic this is, but it certainly feels realistic. Well, other than when your drone gets tangled up with an obstacle, which seems to confuse the game a bit. But you're not supposed to run into obstacles, anyway, right? So far, I still am a very long way from being a capable pilot. I never knew flying a drone was so amazingly difficult! I'm having fun learning, but I still can't stay on track with even the most simple levels. If I can make it though a couple gates in a row, I feel like I'm doing great. It's extremely hard. But, hey, if that's how it is in real life, well then that's how it should be in the game. Many reviews said this was a pretty accurate way to gauge your abilities with a real craft and practice real-world skills, so I'm glad I got this game before spending hundreds of dollars on a real kit. I would have broken thousands of dollars of parts so far. I'll keep trying... :-)

Update: Ok, I've actually made it around the track! Enough to finish a couple races against the AI, and win! (They slow way down for you after the first race, always trying to do only slightly better than your first race's time. So all you have to do is slightly better than your own previous race's time to win the following races.) The drone I found easiest to control so far is the Gremlin. I tried several others and still can't control them. But I can see how this would be a lot of fun if you practiced enough for the controls to be second nature so you could just focus on racing instead of battling for basic control. I'm still having fun learning!

Great sim! I assume. As a complete noob looking to learn, I have no idea how close to RL this is. But it sure feels pretty good to me.

Started with an xbox elite controller but found it hard to get a decent setup, so bought an entry level USB controller (Turnigy Evolution, ¬£40) and I've had so much fun since it arrived :) 

25 hours and counting - through that super tough acro mode initial learning curve - now starting to set some pretty decent times on the tracks.

Just scratching the surface... thoroughly expecting to clock hundreds of hours in this....

The issue was my Xbox one controller could not be calibrated well enough to match the sensitivity levels that are required for this game. No matter how many times I calibrated, there was always a drift I couldn‚Äôt compensate for.  This doesn‚Äôt happen with my other games so I don‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs a hardware issue, more like the controller can‚Äôt get to the level it‚Äôs asking for.

I wasn‚Äôt about to go out and buy a better controller for this game but i can see this being a perfect sim for those who have the appropriate controllers or hobbyists.

I guess only use it to goof off and not really practice. It's ridiculous because I have flown in real life and adjusted PID's and would have no problem on these courses but some are impossible (Especially the arena tracks) to keep tight enough to do a lap. If anyone has a solution please let me know, I keep trying to like this....game... but it's been nothing but trying to play with settings to get it to feel real and actually practice.

Early review. I've got a Vortex 180 and I'm amazed at how well that translates into this sim. There is something odd in the floating mechanics--like I feel I fall faster iRL vs in-sim but beyond that the exact same problems I am experiencing iRL I am facing in the sim so it's giving me a great look into my own issues. It'd be great if there was an instructor mode that could tell you something like 'you've got a drift, to cancel do x, y, z' but that might be too fancy.

Anyhow, for only a few hours in I'm really enjoying this just as a way to get more flight time in without destroying more props in the real world. :)
