With over 20 years in the rc hobby I have flown many different aircraft fixed wing, heli, multi-rotor, even some that dont fit into a class. For FPV quad flying this is amazing, and 10% the cost of other sims I have owned. I love that I can just drop parts in and use my actual pid's. My muscle memory training for flips and rolls is getting so much better with this. Plus to just toss a quad around and shoot through holes like Charpu, MrSteele, Ummgawd, and so many more is amazing. I get to work my skills without cost and then apply that to my real flights. My only complaints thus far is that the sounds need work, ok a lot of work, and I want an option to auto skip the animation of putting the goggles on. I hate having to hit the space bar to skip it every time I change a site or quad. As I said for the price it is great.
Great game, helps to get some stick time in when the weather is bad

so, ive been looking for a FPV racing simulator for a little while now. ive tried DRL sim, and it was honestly kinda meh, and then i tired velocidrone and bought it since it was good enough to just put around in and race some friends in. then i heard about this, tried it during makers faire cinci, and loved it. ive never done an real life race before with my personal Armattan Mongoose (with race precision rates) and let me tell you, the freestyle is on point with real life, and the handling and feel is also very much there. the one thing that i did notice wasnt there is when you hit leaves, you also hit branches and sticks, and that damages your props a lot more than what it does in game (i know from experience.) 

the one thing that this game has over the two other sims that ive tried is realistic physics, and realistic handling. another thing that i feel that this game has that others doesn't, is a very live community, and a community that helps tweak things, and provides way more tracks for the game than what comes stock! 

if anyone has read this far, dont think twice to purchase this game, just go ahead and do it! its great, and easy to master if you know what you are in for when doing a solo race. the bots/ghosts get better and better as you progress! if you feel like your flying slow, use the arrow keys on your keyboard to angle your camera based on how you feel with flying! i have mine set at 55/58 degrees because i felt like i was going too quick and looking up way to far to see the gates.

This is a solid FPV Drone sim.  I have used it to get used to flying before I bought and maidened my Diatone GT-530.  It made the initial experience so much less threatening, and I can continue to hone my skills in the game.

I have noticed a few limitations though.  You cannot actually use the drone editor to build your quad.  You can get close, but they need to provide you with many more options and variables in order to get yours to visually look correct, as well as settings to get it to fly more like your actual quad.  

Also, the flight areas are too small.  The golf course is a pretty good size, however, its still pretty easy to end up out of bounds.  I would prefer to have much larger areas to fly in.  I would also want more variety with bandos and buildings and such.

Overall though, I like this sim, and will continue to keep using it to hone my skills and enjoy flying when I cant fly my real quad.

I used Liftoff to practice FPV flying over the winter in preparation for flying my Vortex 230 Mojo FPV quad this spring. I used it with a Realflight Interlink R/C controller. I had my first real FPV flight yesterday and after a couple flights with a buddy spotting for me I was feeling very comfortable in both horizon and acro modes. Liftoff was definitely a good tool to help me learn how to fly FPV and is highly recommend as a training aid or for simulating FPV just for fun.

I've never flown a real grown up drone before, but from what little experience I have, this does seem to be quite realistic.  I have recently gained a large interest in making an FPV drone as well as a big HD camera platform quadcopter, and have ordered a few FCs, ESCs, motors, etc, while I run frames off on my 3D printer and having this software, and using SmartPropoPlus with a DIY cable, has let me get used to the feel of my Flysky i6x and how a drone will react to it.

Very impressed, and I haven't even gotten into anything past the trackless free play as of yet.   The $22CAD price tag is fair, but being as cheap as I am, if I hadn't had this Steam credit from Christmas burning a hole in my wallet, I probably would have waited for a sale, but I'm glad I didn't have to.

I've played over 1000 hours of sim between Liftoff, Velocidrone, DRL, DCL, Hotprops, Freerider, etc... 
Liftoff is by far my favourite FPV simulator to date. LuGus has done a perfect job combining realistic simulation with a user friendly interface, active competitive multiplayer community, and fun to play progression/unlock system. 
I absolutely recommend this game for anybody in the FPV community, beginners and experts alike.

One of the best drone simulators ive seen so far.

The only thing i miss is a model of my own drone.

This is great for rainy days when I can't fly my drone outside. Feels very close to real flying. Well worth the money.
It makes for a good simulator, but when it comes to the racing sided of things, they can become a little unrealistic in what a quads capabilities really are. Otherwise it is a great sim.

just don't fucking get it unless you have the reflexes of a f***ing ninja! it's ridiculous! tap a little to the left yawing and you do a whole a** 1080 spin, and racing is awful, because one mistake and you're f***ed, so just don't try unless you're an actual drone racer, please, don't suffer as i have

I love this simulator, compared to what I fly (Blade Scimitar 110), its a perfect match, I also like how you can create your own drone setups for you taste and style. There are some minor problems, such as speed at which the drone falls in a dive and battery managment, but overall, a very good sim.
been try to get it to work for 5 hour so far get to track then wont load not happy

By far the best simulator on the market....if you have the pc for it. I have used almost every simulator out there DRL, Velocidrone, RotorRush, FPV air and freerider, Realflight, and AccuRC. 

As long as you have the hardware and can achieve 60+ frames a second better if you can get that number above 100fps then Liftoff will the best thing you can use currently.The reason people that say this feels floaty is because they are not achieving a Frame Rate that is reasonable for the simulation of FPV racing. 

In the end no simulation is going to be perfect, it cannot simulate wind for one along with a few other things but in terms of performance and feel Liftoff fits the bill. You grind a couple hours a day and I will guarantee you that you will become a better pilot.

This is my 2nd simulator after downloading Liftoff and exhausting all the possibilities in that sim in like 5 minutes.

You get what you pay for with this sim, as you basically get a fully fledged PC game out of the experience. I haven't gone too in depth on what you can do to customize your own drone, but you get a bunch of pre-built selections based on real-life builds from the best pilots out there.

The realism of the sim is great. I'd never expect pristine accuracy from any sim, and this one is no exception with the gravity feeling a bit floaty at times, but nonetheless this sim does a phenomenal job of altering characteristics of the flight accurately based on what frame / setup you choose. Being in the market for a Chameleon, I now am extra confident it will be an ideal build for my preferred solo-freestyle flying. I now have a good idea of why some frames are chosen for their purposes as well, which i definitely never got from the cheaper sim. They really leave no stone unturned when it comes to simulating an actual fpv flight. the game even gives you an optional little animation of "you" putting on goggles, and some artificial noise to distract you just like with IRL FPV. I turned that off myself since it messed with my framerate, but that's just cuz i have an old PC.

One minor gripe is with the freestyle trick judging, it tends to ignore certain tricks if done too soon after a different one. I almost feel like it gets confused when i very obviously do a powerloop straight into an inverted spit-S without letting it clock the powerloop first, since it seems drifting seamlessly right into one trick from another sometimes results in getting no points.
Very instructive and useful for any skill level...

The game game runs awfully on Linux:
First I had to mod the startup script because the devs didn't add a solution that was posted like a year ago. Without that all textures were corrupted.
The performance on Linux is beyond bad. With a GTX 970 and an i7 4790k I have to set every single setting to minumum to get >50 FPS which is required for the sim because without that the controls are sluggish.

Now to the game itself:
The loading times are awful for what kind of graphics quality you get, even on maxed settings.
Especially 10 second+ load times within the menu where it just has to load a few quadcopter models is a little sad.
Model diversity is good and I really like the steam workshop integration.
The game doesn't have many maps and most only have a single race scenario.
Physics are okay but I wasn't able to get it to feel 100% right. Still good.
Ghosts that are supposed to be some kind of opponent seem to follow random paths and are pretty much useless.

I specifically chose Liftoff because of it's advertised Linux compability and I got an okay simulator that basically only works on Windows. If you want to use this on Linux stay away, for everybody else it is okay.

I like this one for many reasons;

>there's a free online multi-player mode (where you can race or just fly around with others online)
>there's a map builder (and a race builder for each pre-built map)
>the maps are varied in nature, giving a good mix of different skills and levels
>the physics are on point!

I've paid for a few others, and tried all the free ones (as of this writing: 1/21/19), but this is the one that I always come back to.
It is as close to flying a real racing drone as I have seen. I use it to help improve my skills without paying the price of crashing. It is constantly being updated.

If you want to learn how to fly racing quads while having fun, get this. Works with gamepad too(dont need radio to start), expect beign frustrated for first few couple of hours, but once you ll get it, you will not regret time invested in to this.

FOR DEVELOPER: game works great overall, but please add option to tune TPA (throttle PID attenuation). Settings I find to be perfect for maneuvering simply go crazy at full throttle, TPA would fix this issue flawlessly and make this game almost identical to flying the real thing
definitely worth buying if you're trying to get into FPV Quads. make sure to get a Radio as well, really helps!
"Yeah, I can fly" - Tony

Best race drone simulator? [i] Yes	[/i]

Why?

[list]
    [*]Realism: this game is among the very best, if not the most accurate simulator available.
    [*]Steam game: It allows you to download it on any computer hassle free, 
        ability to return if you dont like it, workshop, cloud saves... etc.

If you want to improve your drone flying skills or get a feel for what FPV race-drones are like? Get a transmitter and LiftOff.

I have enjoyed every minute of flying, and I hope you will too!

Have you ever wanted to fly a drone? Do you have one, and wish you could fly it better? Do you want to become a world class pilot? Here's your chance. This is the premier drone flight simulator. Get it!

As any pilot will tell you, ACRO mode is the only way to fly. And the learning curve to switch from a history of SELF-LEVELLING flight like most toy-grade drones to ACRO is steep. When I first started learning, I could barely take off and start moving forward without flipping upside down. But, through perserverance, I've learned to fly decent in about twenty hours, and can get around many courses with no errors.

This game works with your RC transmitter (so far with a Spektrum DX5) so that you can learn to fly with the same tool you would in the real world. IF you don't have a tx yet, you can also use a PS3/4 or xbox controller with two joysticks. There's a great variety of drones and courses, both of which you can customize or create from scratch! People have used this as a track design tool for real world courses.
Amazing game, Great feel. Highly recommend

I've played all of the other popular drone dims  and this is the one I always recommend.

Plenty of customisation options to get your sim drone to feel pretty close to how your real drone feels.

The best quad drone sim out there? Probably the only real one to be honest.

It's cool that you can use real controllers or a gamepad.

I've used this with a USB gaming RC controller that is close enough to the real thing (without the high quality sticks and knobs) to be able to take advantage of it as a proper sim.

It's probably the best option to learn and practice how to fly properly without destroying a pricey race drone (and you will crash, over and over).

Getting the hang of basic physics/dynamics in Liftoff really helps in dealing with the surprise of real world wind/airflow dynamics that are constantly changing with a real world drone.

There is one race drone in particular amongst the preset models that matches the real one I've tried flying, and it has done more to improve my abilities than when I was just going out to a sports field and trying to fly cold.

You can get more 'non-quality,' mindless practice time in with this since there are no battery limitations like in the real world (just reset when you're ingame battery runs out). And you're flying no-assist style drones that require a heavy level of skill.

The fact that you can build your own drones and maps is also a very nice touch. If this were a flight sim, all of the components within the drone and map building sections would be pricey, individual DLCs. All of this is built into the game... so kudos just on that for the respect the developers are giving to the serious gamer community.

If you are genuinely keen to start developing quad/copter drone flight skills, you will need to invest in, at least, a proper RC styled USB controller (not a console style gamepad), and don't hesitate about waiting for a seasonal promo discount. This game is worth the full price, and it receives steady, quality patches and tweaks from the developer.
Awesome game. Awesome simulator. Nice way to save yourself money.

Purchased this "game" earlier this year to supplement my flight time with UAVs, while currently this program doesn't support (i.e. have models or flight charactoristics) some of the more popular mainstream quadcopters from manufacturers like DJI or Yuneec, the concept of flying FPV on the smaller race-focused quads is very usefull.  Flight controls are crisp and responsive, although the Steam Controller has a habit of lagging inputs or becoming too sensitive to flight stick control manipulations randomly.  Im not sure where the issue lies, I've tried it with two seperate Steam controllers and the lag occurs with both.  This is not an issue with linking a RC controller to your PC.

For a low cost and low risk entry into fpv drone racing, this simulation feels accurate and responsive.  Lack of real world maps for freefly (not based around race maps) is a negative for me, but it would appear that there is some sort of customizability on the horizon.  One nice little addition is the ability to import your own music playlists into a watched folder, although be aware that the last information I had, MP3 format was not supported, only .wav and .ogg.
great trainer! fun with friend or alone

Great sim, my only problem with it is all the load screens between menus and how long some of them take. My pc isn't the best but it can run the game smoothly (60fps) at mid to low settings.

Zero to Hero in 16 hours sim time. 
I went from blundering about to mostly locked in solid in one week. Flight at first was almost aerobic, more body english and intense seat squirming than action on the screen. There's a lot of room  left to grow yet, and much more left to learn, but I'm ready now to put one in the air in real life. I'm wondering now how well a Tiny Whoop can imitate the stiff, hotly tuned 5" 6S in the sim.

The secret, or at least my pivotal learning moment, came from taking out all the mush in the control center. Reduce expo to deeply negative in all three of roll, pitch, and yaw. I'm running -.42 on all 3 axes. Reduce RC and increase Super Rates to get 1000 deg/s. The quad now is an extension of my mind. I can focus now on just learning to fly. Brisk forward flight is easy and solid. Fine placement at speed and hovering remain challenges.

Good luck. Enjoy!

Very fun...and I'm sure it has saved me a ton of money!  About 50 hours in and I'm winning races and my fingers finally have the muscle memory needed for real life racing.  The goal is to finish 100 hours of training before I buy my first racing drone.

I have gotten to the point where I crave to come home from work so I can play and try to finish the difficult races.  I'm sure real life will be a little different, but I figure this is a great jump start to getting into drone racing.

TLDR:
This game is a bit of a "niche" thing, and I only can truly recommend this game to you -
the reader - if you genuinely are into drone racing and want to get better, or have a substitute if you can't go out flying RC in real life. it also isn't as much a game as it is a simulator. I want this review serve as a buyers beware on why you should or shouldn't buy it, 
rather than recommending you to buy this with a positive review.

Full:

The good:
For it's intended purpose, this game serves as probably THE BEST FPV drone simulator
you can find on steam, or even the internet for that matter. I fly FPV in real life, and Liftoff made me fly FPV exponentially better after only 10 effective hours. it made me transition from stabilized (Horizon) to full manual (Acro) flight. 
If you have an RC transmitter lying around capable of linking to your PC, and want to get better at FPV Flying, because it certainly will make you better over time.
this game is an absolute must! I met the Devs in person and they are absolutely great, very nice, passionate indie team whom are very open to suggestion and interact very frequently to community feedback. the game gets updated regularly,
and almost every two or three months, you get new FREE stuff and maps to fly on. For a simulator, this game is an absolute steal!

The buyers beware:
This game will for most part be full manual flying by YOU, preferably flown by a dedicated RC transmitter like the Frsky Taranis. I highly recommend you to NOT pick up this game if you're not planning to get into the hobby of drone flying/racing or if you're just not into FPV drone flight as a whole. 
Don't expect to jump into this without prior experience of RC flight, and think that you'll have the hang od it after an hour, because game will be annoying the first few hours if you haven't flown RC before. This game is a great gateway to get into FPV drone flying, but to get the closest true-to-life experience, you're gonna need an RC transmitter. prices can widely vary from a simple 20$ offbrand plug n play transmitter to a professional 400$ Frsky Horus RC transmitter. if you DO NOT have and/or wish to buy an RC transmitter, this game is probably not for you. You can also play this with a gamepad but I do not recommend this as the experience is vastly different. However if you are into niche things, by all means go for it.

Excelent quadcopter sim/game. Hopefully, and according to makers, will even get better as time goes on with new updates and additions.
Might be running a bit twitchy on older systems even at lowest graphical settings (on some maps).
Has map editor and quad builder to fit different flight styles for different people, whether you like to race or freestyle. Some custom maps in Workshop are outright awesome, so do check those out!
Supports all kinds of radio transmitters and RC sim joysticks.
Would definately-100% make you a better pilot in real-life.
This is a great game for learning to fly, I highly reccomend it.

so firtst off when i purchased this game i didnt have the right radio to control it ,then when i go the radio i needed to play , game wont even start up , i see three sponser screens then imediatley goes to desktop, when i contacted steam about this issue , they said it was to long of a period to refund my money when i just wanted to kmow about the problem ,and possible redownload , pretty sad over 20 bucks
The best simulator for drones, this is the way i leard how to drive my drone, congratulations

One More Edit:

I was impressed back in the Day and I still say this might be a good way for a rookie to learn the basics of flying, but after checking back once in a while I have grown more and more disappointed with the flight model in this sim. Being an experienced pilot with top notch tech on my hands I have to say this sim feels dull and unresponsive and worst of all is still waaaay too floaty.
Having reached a certain level in my flying I can no longer recommend this sim for seasoned pilots as you will most likely ruin your reallife skills using this sim.
Additionally the devs completely misunderstood the concept of throttle expo doing it completely wrong.
While it's kinda nice to have a betaflight-ish interface for your rates it is outdated and doesn't reflect the current state of betaflight at all.

Sorry guys, but adding content without fixing the underlying issues disqualifies this sim for me.


Older EDIT way back:

OK time to edit...

First off I wanna say it's just amazing that LuGus managed to fix almost all of the problems that stopped me from loving this Game in just one day!!! Great job you've done there guys!!!

At first I wasn't able to map controls to my DX6i, what turned out to be my own fault in the end. But I was really impressed how well you could actually fly this thing with such a piece of crap of a controller like my totally worn out 5 years old 360 gamepad. This was already so much fun that I flew quite a while without worrying about setting up my DX6i properly.

When I finally tried with a real rc transmitter I was blown away how great this sim handles and how much fun it is. Compared to yesterday it's a completely different experience!

I was happy to see that it's possible now to turn off the OSD but couldn't find an option for changing the camera angle. But I#m confident this will be implemented soon.

The flight model feels good and kind of natural, but still is too easy compared to the real thing. I was able to pull off some maneuvers that would have had me crashed in real life. The quad also is not as "snappy" as I like it and PID tuning feels still a bit weird but again... I'm confident this will be fixed in the future.

So all in all this is a must have for anyone interested or already involved in FPV Racing!!!




Old Review from yesterday:


At this point I cannot recommend this game for people who fly real fpv racequads...

Looks like a good start to me, but a few things annoy the hell out of me and will make me stick with hotprops for now:

- the hover point is way below stick center and cannot be adjusted. (Tested this on my old DX4e, my DX6i and my 360 Gamepad - Hover point is at around 25% throttle) I prefer a hover point at the stick center and afaik that's how most people fly

- feels like zero throttle in fact isn't zero throttle... quad falls way too slow compared to real life experience

- camera angle cannot be adjusted

- no way to turn off the OSD ... I prefer flying without OSD


These are all things I'm sure will be fixed soon and besides those the flight model feels promising but needs more fine tuning and more real life feeling (for example jittering when decending into own propwash). There are quite a few sims out there that come near the feeling of piloting a fpv racequad and I really hope this one will come close or even spot on.

Time will tell

(this review will be updated once liftoff gets better)

If you are getting into quads, this is essential. This is my favorite sim of the few I tried. I was able to customize a drone matching my own build which has been very helpful learning what it can and can't do. Easily have saved hundreds in crashes, haha. The multiplayer racing is great to realize how terrible I am at flying.

LiftOff has been my number one racing and freestyle drone simulator. It really has helped me improve my real-life piloting skills. It has increased my confidence and skill. The more I use it, the best I get. My friends and I love to train almost on a daily basis. Its physics and level of realism is almost perfect! It's worth every single penny!!! It will not dissapoint you!

Great for beginners!
I played it 18 hours and like it a lot. It is good to fly in a simulator first before you try fpv in reallife. It saved me a lot of crashes.

I've been playing this game for almost 100 hours now. I started using it to train myself for FPV drone flying a little over a month ago. In the beginning I almost thought the game was broken with just how hard things like hovering and turning were. Within a week of hardcore practice I could make my way through most of the tracks. Now I fly through them with relative ease.

I was worried that the skills I learned here wouldn't transfer to the real drone I was building, but the feel is almost EXACTLY the same. It's amazing how similar this game is to my real quad with the same rates.

Now it's just a grind to get to where I want to be as a pilot. The devs made it easy with a great multiplayer system. The other players really help pass the hours as I practice.

The only things I want are more tracks (because at 100 hours, I've explored all of them very well) and possibly some changes to the level system. Right now only built in tracks count for XP, not player made tracks.

Anyway 10/10 would recommend.

Complete multi-rotor novice here and having a blast with Liftoff!
See TL;DR for the brief.

MY BACKGROUND:
I started looking into the drone freestyle and racing scene a few months ago watching pilot videos, tips, and builds to learn about the hobby and what is involved.
Recently I decided I needed to figure out if I want to get into the hobby and stop sitting on the fence.

Enter drone simulators(there is a few).. My first is Liftoff, and it has been a great tool without having to invest in a drone, plus, it saves on the costs to run, maintain, and repair said 'first' drone which can quickly add up in cost depending on how crap of a pilot you are!!!

For Liftoff,
I have been using a wireless XBox360 controller and have had a lot of fun but found it very touchy, but have adapted.
My first flight in FPV was the simulation of a poorly executed pancake flip, I quickly switched to Line of Sight(LOS) to begin training there.
Having progressed from flopping around like a pancake in LOS with ACRO(Manual/No auto leveling) mode to hovering and flying around reasonably successfully I stepped back into FPV and this progression very natural but I did find it a lot easier to control so have been trying to focus more on learning to fly in LOS but do jump into FPV also.. because it is more fun ;)

Anyway,
Having had a lot of fun thus far I wanted to take things to the next level so got a Taranis as Liftoff supports the use of controllers, this will help with the transition from simulator to the real world when that happens, plus I can use this same controller for my first real drone which will be a basic indoor fpv drone and then later I will do a full build.

TL;DR:
- Fly Line of Sight or FPV
- Good graphics
- Decent variety of drones/parts with basic customisation (would be great if they just opened up to the workshop here)
- Good variety of activities (Race, Freestyle, Free-Fly)
- Workshop 'courses' (no custom maps yet sadly, again the community could do so much for the developers here)
- Fun gameplay but touchy controls although I am sure you can adjust this, but I wanted to adapt not the other way.
- Good challenge, my first time flying ACRO.. RIP 50,000 virtual drones... ;)
- Great starting point for drone newbies like myself! XD

All in all, a great tool for someone like myself that was on the fence, grab a PS or XBox controller and have a crack!
If you like fast paced racing games, drone racing might be right up your alley, or if you are more like me and are into the freestyle stuff Liftoff has you covered here as well!

Very good simulator, one remark is that the levels are quite small and extremely sparse in detail. While more detail might be hard to add, I see no reason why the levels cant be larger, at least a few kilometers, to allow for some exploration. A few hundred meters is not enough. Also adding a "long range" mode that lets you practice long range with VTX signal disappearing if you go outside of LOS etc would be excellent, for example a mountain range or something with epic drops. For some of us who cant FPV as often as we would like, this game is a rescue!

I have a park across the street and I was diving trees, doing flips, rolls, playing in the trees all from the musle memory I had gained the day before. My Torrent 110 on a 3 cell was also fun.

First decent simulator i have come across for drones to be honest. Managed to hook up my FRsky transmitter with a few youtube videos and can now practice with the equipment i use in the field. The game itself has got quite a few bits of customisation but i dont feel like it makes a big difference to how the quads fly. Not sure how tuned in i am to feel the difference but digitally they all fly very similar (more powerful motors increase speed a bit but nothing majorly).

I have been flying a quad IRL for 6 months and this passes the time when weather or other commitments dont allow a proper flight outside. Its ideal for beginners to get the feel of how a quad handles without the weight of "if i smash this its going to need replaced". However the quads seem to float just a little longer than they would in real life so be warned ;)

The enviroments are great - graphics dont exactly rival crysis or what not but they are pleasing enough and you can see everything beofre you hit it!

THe tracks are pretty accurate to real life scenarios however i feel a beginners track where the gates are larger could benefit the game for those who have just started.

It is a great simulator to pass the time and practice without fear of crashing a real drone and so i will give it the thumbs up as is definately a good tool to practice with.

Liftoff is a Terrific Tool and Game! I became a Liftoff Fan in January 2017 when I puchased my first RealACC x-210 drone kit from Banggood. Liftoff taught me to fly, tune, and adjust my Taranis settings and develope throttle and axis curves. I did so through Liftoff. I was able to obtain a complete and functional understanding of RC Rates, Super Rates, Throttle and Axis Expo as well as PID tuning  and I did so before I ever flew my first Quad, ( have since built five additional race quads) I was able to master the necessary control of my quad by using Liftoff. When I flew my first quad in March 2017.....which is, somewhat different from Liftoff (Liftoff was more foregiving) I was able to  fly with only minor crashes that occurred until I mastered a real Quad landing. 
     Following approximately ten pacs, I was flyng under and around trees and successfully maneuvering rolls, loops and very fast flying. During most of my Liftoff training / practice, I flew with Fat Shark HD3's. This presented a term to become familiar with an actual 130" field of view and became accustom to goggle flight which was helpful and important. I allowed camera noise in Liftoff but reality privides a great deal more.
     I regularly utilize Liftoff for learning the feel of new rate settings (muscle memory). I presently race Quads regularly and have become extremely respectable and competitive. I just began flying 6s power on llower KV motors.....the straight line speed of most of  my builds exceed 120 mph and provides  longer flight times with apparent aforethought. I still use Liftoff every day!......It's a tool and its relaxing.....no broken parts to replace and this creates much bolder flying.... provides experience.... and defrays from  many broken parts that happen upon real Quad flight learning curves that  always exist.
     If you are interested in Quad flying or just obtaining a good working understanding of what makes a good tune and proper control rates and adjustments.......then Liftoff IS A MUST HAVE.........You can probable learn to fly without it......over a longer period of time.....but why do it the hard way? Liftoff is at your finger tips and will act as a terrific aid to determined if this hobby is for you. 

Sincerely,
JOANZS ......  a Liftoff fan.

PS.......I built a race course on the Liftoff program that emulates a local track that I regularly partake.....this allows me to experiment with new settings and pratice laps in all weather!

I would recommend Liftoff, but with reservations. It is fun and the flight characteristics are accurate enough (as of May 2018) to be considered a simulator and not an arcade flyer. Is it the overall best FPV mini quad racer simulator on the market today? No, not in my opinion, but if you are looking to get into the rather expensive hobby of FPV racing, I would not be stingy on the comparatively cheap price of a sim (at $20 we're talking the price of a motor or a battery here). My advice is to buy a few, since they do offer different advantages.

For positive aspects, the graphics are excellent and it has integration into the steam workshop for new track setups. Even in early access, Liftoff is more accurate and higher quality than earlier options like FPV Freerider. And, in my book, offering a Linux version is a huge plus! Thank you :) Binding a transmitter was also a piece of cake.

My main criticisms are a) it is unfinished and lacks content and features b) it does not run well on a machine above their minimum specs on large levels and c) for being a simulator it is extremely limited in its configuration options. Overall I think Velocidrone is a superior product, because it is highly playable *right now* with loads of maps, tracks, and quads, it runs large levels well (>60fps) on a card with 1 GB VRAM, and many aspects of the physics and quad are easily configurable. In terms of content for Liftoff, there are only a few large, interesting maps (like Hannover) whereas there are many for Velocidrone. For the the quad workbench, what is the point in fiddling with the appearance of the quad, since when do you see it if you're flying first-person-view? Further, the tutorial is barebones, and the track designer is painful to use and lacks instructions on how to use it. The menu system is also frustrating, it has long and unnecessary load-times between sub-menus, and you cannot change maps or tracks without going through the main menu system. Liftoff is an early access product (and has been since like 2016) and it's unfinished state shows. Although, this is important, it is not buggy, and I had no issues even on the less-well-tested Linux platform.

Thus, if you would like to get into the FPV hobby, I think you should add Liftoff to your library. It's fun and it works, but in my view it is not the best product on the market today.

After about 25 hours on the simulator, I flew my fpv drone for the first time this weekend, did aileron rolls, front and back flips, and even a loop to the amazement of the guys at my flying field. Complete newbie here, patiently waiting for an Eachine to arrive from China. FS-I6X was sold out on Banggood, so got it on Amazon prime, granting some practice time.

Regardless of whether the simulation is perfect, it's no doubt a valuable tool for training reflexes. One week ago, I had no idea what "sluggish rates" meant in FPVFreerider as I thought it was already insanely fast. Going back after having played Liftoff for 3 or 4 days, I suddenly perceive what they meant, plain as day.

Bottom line: Looks great, best replay value of those I've tried, and great exposure to beta flight and lingo for newbies.

EDIT: After having played Liftoff for a long time and recently purchasing Velocidrone as well, I can report that the physics is not really that different between the two.  Biggest difference is the visual feel, not the way the drone flies.

Only done a bare minimum of flying my actual drone, but what i really wanted this sim for was to help me overide 25 years of gamer muscle memory that says the right stick is for looking up, down, [b] left and right[/b] and the left stick is for moving foward/backward, [b]strafe left, strafe right[/b].

If you're into flying drones - no matter if total beginner or pro - you should definitely check out Liftoff. You'll find everything you need, from interactive tutorials teaching basic controls, to a lot of built-in tracks and races of varying difficulty, a workbench to build your own drone from real parts, a pro league with regularly tournaments and a flourishing and growing community with friendly people.

The best part for me is the built-in track/race editor which made me build dozens of crazy skill training tracks that I could share with others in the workshop. It never gets boring, since there's so many pilots always creating new tracks to download and fly.

The physics are good, if anything a bit floaty.
Graphics, sound and interface are very good, too.
The game is constantly evolving and the devs do regular updates with new and cool features.
They often even come into the multiplayer rooms and have a chat with the users and/or fly some laps themselves.

I love the atmosphere of the community, where pros fight head to head about the best laptime while beginners learn and get help and hints from more experienced pilots. I improved my skills a lot with Liftoff and was able to learn new maneuvers without the risk of crashing my real drone and having to do expensive repairs.

If you're into flying drones - try Liftoff!

Hands down if your wanting to learn how to fly fpv, improve those skills, or just burn down a track with your friends, and make new ones this sim is the best out there, awesome physics, and finally a sim where the Devs not only listen to you but come fly with you. 

time to Liftoff see you out there!!!!

I, like a lot of people lately, have wandered into the world of FPV mini quads.  I've flown RC planes for years, but flying these is different to say the least, especially wearing goggles.  I started off with a MJX Bug6  and a cheap pair of goggles. That was cool but got boring quick, I wanted to try acro and it didn't have it.  I bought a Tiny 7 and a Eachine Bat QX105. They're ok, but they lack power  which degrades their acro ability.  So, I finally sprung for an Eachine Wizard X220 and a HGLRC XJB - 145.  Before flying them, I got Liftoff and started practicing.  This simulator is an absolute must have, especially if you're new to this hobby.  The graphics are very good, nice flying sites, easy menu, and many features to custom tailor the game to your flying style and experience level.  I flew freestyle in the sim for several hours and this weekend I took the Wizard X220 out for the first time and flew 10 battery packs through it, five 3s and five 4s.  I didn't crash once and I was able to do moderate "stunts" in acro mode (all over an open field, I'm not crazy...yet).  The experience was very similar to what it's like flying in the sim.  Kudos to the dev team, your talent and hard work shines through and is greatly appreciated!!
Flying a mini quad in acro mode through narrow gaps is not easy!  Liftoff is an addictively fun way to improve your flying skills.  Nice graphics as well.

If you fly (or wanna fly) FPV, this is the best $20 you can spend, and spend you will. This "Game" keeps getting better and better, but then so do I. One of the only things missing is a running total of all the $$$ you've wasted crashing. There are really only 3 contenders for the best FPV racing/freestyle simulator and this is one of them. So if you are thinking about getting into FPV, grab yourself an Frsky transmitter (you'll need it later anyhow and this is coming from a guy who was strictly Spektrum) plug it in and fly!

Using this with Spektrum radio and a USB dongle to practice flying FPV... much more willing to take risks when it isn't real carbon, props, or motors that'd be damaged.   Makes me a more confident flyer in real life as well.

Awesome game/SIM. As a beginer FPV pilot I cant recomend this enough to anyone wanting to get into the sport. As quads are expensive to buy....they are even more expensive to fix or maintain. If I crash in the SIM.....no problem....reset and save myself a couple hundred bucks and avoid a yardsale. Love the fact that I can perfect a trick here before attempting it with my real quad and I can fly here anytime....dont have to wait for a sunny day, or snow to melt.... anything....hook my radio up and rip. Thanks for an awesome product.....now I just gotta kick my 12 year old son off to play.

It's a great racing simulator if you can get it working.  They should stop selling the mac version.  My mac laptop crashes in any quality setting and resolution.  It normally can't even get past the "goggles" intro animation.  My big 12 core mac pro with dual ATIs can't run it smoothly at even 720p at the lowest quality setting.  Running this game on WIndows 10 in bootcamp works fairly well at 1080p in the 'good' quality setting or lower.  It still isn't perfectly smooth, but at least it's playable.  SO if you are windows based with a really good gaming computer then this might be the ticket for you.  If you are mac based save your money.  They need to do a ton of optimization before I'd call it truly playable in either OS.

As for game play-- it's pretty good!  The physics feel fairly realistic, although as is often the case for me, the simulators are easier to fly. I think some of this is psychological (no fear of crashes), but I think it's also the case where the game just feels 'slower' than the real thing.  It's more floaty.  Sometimes the quad seems to soar more like a plane than a real miniquad.  

The crash/damage system is nice in that brushing an object won't end your session.  But I'd say its pretty unrealistic.  In the game, you can dive right through the middle of a tree and continue flying.  Whereas in real life I'd probably be replacing every single prop.  

I really want to recommend the game, but the computer requirements seem too extreme at the moment to do so.  Maybe they should market it more to the hardcore gamer crowd.  I'm not a huge gamer, just wanted a fun simulator for my quad obsession.

Doesnt Support PPM Radios such as the Fly Sky FSi6 with teh corect USB dongle and everything. plenty of other simulators work fine with it. if the developers could help me out that would be great as this simulator was just a waste of my money...

Plus it offers a multiplayer mode  so you can fly with your buddies. If you are just starting out in the hobby, you should definitely try this out and learn the stick movements. It helps a ton!!!

As a lot of comment have already stated, this is by far the best and most realistic FPV simulator around.

It uses the betaflight settings to let you tweak how your virtual quad react, which let you test different PIDs, then usable with your real quad. The physics feels pretty good (a lot better than FPV free rider or even velocidrone for me).

The simulator is regularly updated with high quality content and the workshop also supplies endless tracks should you get bored. You can fly well-known quads or make one yourself. More component choices would be great, although I understand that it's hard because of copyrights.

I love everything about this simulator, and with that price tag (19.99‚Ç¨ at the moment), there's really nothing to dislike about it.

Obviously not perfect but defintely scatches that FPV itch when its cold outside. Every update seems to bring the physics closer to reality. I imagine the final version of this game will be a MUST for any drone pilot and even in its early version status, still one of the best buys on Steam. 420 Stars out of 5.

This is an invaluable tool for learning how to fly quadcopters. If you want to get into the real thing, do yourself a favor and learn to fly in this sim. You will save a lot of money.

First off, this ISN¬¥T A GAME, Liftoff is a Simulator.
It¬¥s great for beginners who want to get into FPV flying and great for pro pilots to try and learn new tricks without trashing a 500$ Racing Quad.
I¬¥m an FPV Pilot, started with a Hexacopter, I shall not mention that the beginning was pretty expensive, always pushed the limits and crashed a lot. 
The Simulators back then didn¬¥t even have Multirotor support, wasn¬¥t that popular that time. I¬¥ve tried a couple of Simulators that would give me the feel of the real thing so I can practice without braking too many Propellers.
Liftoff is from ImmersionRC, the guys who started it all, the FPV scene. Without thransmitting the Video Data to the Pilot it would have stayed regular RC Piloting a Multirotor, Helicopter, Plane, Car, whatever...
The Community puts a lot of love, energy and time in to the Development of FPV Gear, also Simulators.
Up to this Day, Liftoff is still the best the Market has to offer!
LuGus and ImmersionRC also don¬¥t release an Early Access, they perfectionalize the Product and than it¬¥s released, from roughly 200 Games that I have on Steam (also some early access games), Liftoff has the most upgrades/updates that makes the Simulator each time better and better! 
Respect!

I really don't like this game. Physics is not even close to reality. Gravity force is I guess half of real (you could roll up side down and go for a coffee, do a loundry and it is still in the air, not on the ground). Motor have no punch. My shitty x220 with emax rs2205 and kingkong 5040 prop is 2 times faster than that.

PID tuning: most quad have giant oscillation with P gain which is low even for mentioned above quad.

Menu: From starting the game to play you need 2 minutes clicking by menu with loading screen between each one.

If you like to install it to replace flying in winter I suggest to watch some youtube quad realted channel or fix your quad.

Fish eye: In times when everybody runs cameras with gopro lense without almost no fish eye there is soooo much fish eye which is almost unflyable.

For all the people who want to learn how to fly a racing drone or any other sort of drone without helping mechanisms, this is the go-to simulator.

Really worth playing and worth the money

My favorite drone racing game / sim.  It has improved so much and continues to improve on a nearly weekly basis.  If you are getting into drone racing this game can save you hundreds of dollars that you would spend on parts if you tryed to fly as often and as aggressivly as you can in this game.  I can't really think of a better way to spend $20 toward drone racing.

Woah!  I'm amazed by Liftoff, especially considering it's early access.  It's a killer training tool for someone looking to get into quads and develop some skill and technique before burying their real gear into the dirt at 80mph.  It works perfectly with the Taranis QX7 - minimal transmitter programming and minimal calibration in Liftoff.  A regular USB cable is all I used, no proprietary dongles or the ilk.  You can also set up a standard controller to work, but be aware that controller joysticks are sprung to center, whereas normally an RC transmitter throttle axis will not be sprung, so you may want to set the throttle range to only use the positive Y axis, rather than having to hold the stick down, away from the center to achieve 0% throttle (it feels strange but it approximates a real transmitter if you don't have one or don't want to set one up.)  There're lots of in-game versions of real world quad setups and approximations for anything it doesn't have verbatim, 150 size, 250, etc., etc.  There's a good selection of courses, with what looks like more on the way from the developers and the community.  It also provides Betaflight style PID tuning.

I'm coming from a year-or-so of doing well learning to fly cheap foamboard fixed-wing planes, but yearning for that pick-up-and-fly-anywhere FPV experience that quads seem to deliver on, so I went through all the sims I could find - Liftoff is the one that does what I need.  It feels like learning to ride a bike, I've been logging a minimum of 30mins of progression every day, and I'm getting really confident surprisingly quick.  At first I was meandering high above an open field aimless and clumsy (incapable of recovery from the slightest missteps,) now I'm zooming right above the ground whipping around obstacles, making plenty of mistakes still, but able to correct for a lot of them and finish laps regardless.  I was really surprised by the tutorial, I expected something rote and boring, but the flight model feels so real and challenging that even though I was only navigating a flat grid-world with flags and gates, I was really able to focus and simply GET BETTER.  The reset after a crash is quick and doesn't feel like utter defeat, and the tutorial videos have decent advice.  Moving back to the other areas after going through the tutorial was a stark contrast - I've never had a tutorial in a game give me that much of a sense of improvement before.  It's a good feeling - I'd credit it to the work they've put into the flight model, structure, look, and feel of the game.  I'm excited to spend more time on a real quad, but for now Liftoff is a good way to train up from nothing while I spend the dark winter nights building a 270 rig in the basement.  I never thought I'd go from zero experience with quads to this confident and comfortable, this quickly!

First off let me say that i have had a rough history with early access games, but there are always a few developers who shine apart from the rest.  Lugus has put soul into this game. its not just a drone simulator. it has a lot to offer. and the developers are commited to adding more.  it has a growing community of friendly helpful hobbyists who just want to see the hobby get more popular. and the developers listen closely to bug reports, complaints and suggestions.  any major bugs i had from updates, are fixed within a week. 

if you are looking for a racing game to play on your PS4 or Xbox controller, your immediate experience will be unenjoyable. 

if you are looking for an entry point into RC quadcopters buying a RC transmitter and Liftoff should be your first step. 

"why liftoff instead of other simulators?"

-well aside from the community, Liftoff has an extensive track creator. Which allows you and the community to create endless opportunity for races.  the blue print map allows for people to go creatively wild. and make environments from the ground up. and FPV racing clubs even recreate their own tracks within the simulator for practice. 

-it has a diverse player base of many skill levels. A LOT of people play liftoff, its not hard to find a race or freestyle lobby. the game does not balance player skill, so you will find your self racing with people much faster than you. and even when you get to the point where you feel faster than most other people, someone is going to be twice as fast as that. its easy to caught up in lap times,  racing is competitve so we have to compare our selves to others, just keep in mind some people might have as much as 5 or more years of flight time than you.  its good to follow and watch the better pilots to see how they might approach a problem differently. commit it memory in practice and try to improve your times.

-freestyle stunt mode, as far as i know, its the only sim that has this kind of feature. i fly freestyle mostly so i think its pretty awesome. 

-custom quads.  liftoff does a good job at nailing the simulator part, but its  little things in the game make it stand out, Pieceing together a new build on the workbench. changing the betaflight settings. these things are enjoyable in their own ways... liftoff can teach you things about the hobby that would regularly require a newb to do a lot of googling and asking on forums. dont get me wrong, if you plan to get into drone racing, interet research is GOING to happen, but with liftoff, you might just have a lighter  homework load. 



in conclusion, i think you should buy this if your are interested in the hobby, you wont regret it. 


Cons :  i will add a list of cons once the game is finished, i think its unfair to point something out that might be removed in time.

Great for practice or just for fun. Feels very real and has lots of tuning options. This game has greatly enhanced my flying ability, and is also just fun to play when you're looking for a unique racing game.

overall, great stuff, love it, highly recommended

[h1]Liftoff![/h1]
FPV Drone Racing Game that (in my opinion) almost perfectly translates flying a drone in first-person view.

When I wanted to start flying drones I bought a pre-built drone (Eachine Falcon 250 Pro). Drone cheap enough for me to crash a bazillion times and be able to repair it. Ofcourse I first had to learn the basics of Line of sight flying but later when I wanted to transition to FPV flying things got quite different. I bought Liftoff to help me with the transition where I then got the feeling for FPV flying and some tricks too!

Anyways, to sum it up, I had a great experience with Liftoff as it had taught me how to fly FPV and I met great people in multiplayer lobbies who were willing to help in any way possible.

Liftoff has quite some features and not just freeflight on a prebuilt maps:
[list]
   [*]You can build your own drone in Liftoff and tune it to your preference!

   [*]The ability to build a track or a race on your own is also a great feature that Liftoff has. You can then publish those maps, tracks or races to Steam Workshop for other people to try them.

   [*]It has a leaderboard on every track and racing with other people is as great as in real life.

   [*]They even added freestyle mode!
[/list]

[quote=Amelia Earhart] You haven't seen a tree until you've seen its shadow from the sky. [/quote]

- some default Setups a already flattering while flying
- there are still of grafic glithes with my resolution ( 2560x1440 )

I think the weight of the drones compared to the gravity is a lot to low.
Also the feeling speed flying forward, feels like 50km/h and get shown as 120 mph.

And another bad point on the list, the last update 0.10.1 kills the framerate total.
I got a 1060 with 6GB of ram and this game should run at something like 1000 fps here.

So yeah it is on its way to be some kind of simulator in the future, but it has to be more realistic to get there.

First thing I want to say is that aside from the need for a controller (which in all fairness is really a necessity for a drone sim) most drone sims aren't quite as pick up and play as this one. Controls feel nice, and physics are in my opinion comparable enough to piloting a real drone if you're just looking for hours of inexpensive stick time. I've noticed attention to detail in the physics that are absent in other sims; ground effect for instance is a nice touch. Not to mention switchable flight modes, line of sight mode, and completely configurable drones with the intention of adding content in the future. I am really digging the versatility of this simulator as an educational tool as well. Between the flight modes, configurable flight controller, track builder, drone workbench, steam workshop items, concise tutorials, and ease of connection with standard transmitters this is really a robust sim especially for entry level pilots. Furthermore, the multiplayer is super addictive. Great early access work, looking forward to what's ahead!

Or for anyone looking for something new in racing sims/games Not to mention how amazing LuGus Studios and the hard work they put into this game everday. A friend suggested I save some props and get this sim to practice on, and I have to admit - this is the best quadcopter simulator available BAR NONE. Even in its infancy, I can see the potential of this sim. The flight characteristics, handling, even bad tuning... What a great investment! 

I am really enjoying the track editor, and hope to see some cool community offerings in that respect. I can't wait to have more objects to build with, more parts to trick out my ship, and more maps to fly in. This simulator is the shizz. hunned p'cent.

 -UPDATE:

After nearly two years of piloting multis and getting into the business in a drone shop repairing and building, and teaching people to fly... Liftoff is still my 'go to' simulator for getting noobs up to speed in the most affordable manner, and for keeping my chops tight during those stretches when I just don't get out to the park enough. 

I have watched totally green noobs go from zero to sky ruling hero in like 3-4 months! There are a lot of simulators out there now, and some of them are pretty good. I have tried most of them thoroughly, and I have found Liftoff to be the over all best rounded, simply the most fun and best physics. It must be - my sctudents are flying like ANIMALS in no time!

Thanks LuGus Studios, for making my job easier and a hwck of a lot more enjoyable!

Great FPV sim. Quad selection is good, you can mod/upgrade frames, motors, etc. Map/Track editor is easy to use.  Save your self some time and money., purchase Liftoff and practice, practice, practice.

Re-writing this review, since the developers did overhaul the input setup system. Great!

Previously I had experienced a lot of trouble with setting up the inputs, but the developers did address that lack. After that change I gave the game another shot, and was pleased to discover I could actually play it now.

The game offers a ton of customization options for the various race quads, which is neat. The flight experience feels quite accurate, and once you get into the swing of things can be quite fun.

I do hope eventually more environments are added, as it's a bit bare bones. But considering the pace of development, that's just a matter of time.

It would also be neat to offer players a wider range of quad flight styles. Right now they have the twitchy race quad nailed down pretty solid, but a slower more easy to get into experience might be good for players who don't have experience flying race quads for real. Something akin to a Tiny Whoop style, or lower tuned beginner quad setup.

Old review below for posterity.

-----

It seems like the developers have gone for a minimalistic stylish gee-whiz interface when it comes to the controls. I ended up with 2 control axes inverted, and instead of a simple check-box like every other game ever to invert that axis you just have to auto-detect that axis and move it opposite of what the game prompts you.

Do you end up with multiple control axes with the center point way off? Well, tough cookies because the game doesn't let you adjust that. Spent a bunch of time farting around with windows controller options (Which shows my inputs as properly centered, contrary to what the game thinks), only to have nothing work at all.

The games auto-calibration is junk, at least for me. It ends up centering your sticks WAY off, then as I said you can't do anything to fix it.

Seriously, for a control-heavy game like flying a twitchy race quad, I would think giving the player a multitude of control options would be common sense.

Really want to like this, but until the control issues are fixed (Just giving options would do the trick!), refunded.
This game really helped my irl flying!

This game made me able to fly a racing drone.
I bought it while waiting on the parts that I ordered, not being very good at flying at the time.

I built a drone with parts similar to what I ordered with the drone editor in game.

Now I fly with my real drone as well as I can play this game.

I mean : 10/10, it's fun AND useful!

Using 2017 13' MacBook Pro Intel Iris 650 gpu. 3.1GHz i5.

The best quad-sim out there! And I have tried them all. For both racing and freestyling.
EXCELLENT!!!
best fpv drone sim. the graphics are pretty good. and the physics are the best out there.
pretty much the best multicopter game up right now!!!!
This sim is great so far. I'm new to quads( about 3 months in now) and in the few hours I've been using it I'm getting a better feel for piloting than I ever got from the free sims I've tried.

One of the most realistic quad race sims. (in comparison to Freerider and Velocidrone) It even simulates signal distortion of the VTX. But most important the handling of the quads are very realistic!

Gorgeous levels: Urban and nature landscapes. Nice trees, like to S-turn and powerloop the trees in Hannover. Very nice forrest track Pinevalley, intense track to fly on. Quite some different quads you can fly with: 130mm to 6 inch quads. (missing the (dutch) epiquad though)
There's also purist race mode (which i prefer the most) where the battery voltage and propdamage play quite a role on the race experience. User interface looks nice but not alway logic and music is fine but after a while a little boring. 

Didn't got to the trackbuilder yet but there's enough content in the workshop to practise flying with.

Tip for the developers: More attention on the leaderboards! Perhaps it is possible to set record times in multiplayer mode when you are flying alone in a race.

Number one simulator. hands down.
Big Up to the Lugus Team

Try stepping into the real world without any experience and you're going to have a bad time. This game helped me take the leap from flying in a sim to real life.
After spending many hours learning to fly with the Vortex 250 in-game, I got the ready to fly build and the transition was almost effortless. All the basic maneuvers felt pretty much identical from game to reality and I was able to save myself probably thousands of broken quad parts.

Fanatstic simulator! Has a very real to life phusics engine.

Liftoff is a brilliant Sim for fpv flight. Active dev team and everyone i've encountered seems super friendly and out to make the best possible sim they can.

In terms of play, you can use a controller, tweak the inputs and deadzones to give you better control. you can use your actual Transmitter you use in the real world if it can send pc data. i use a taranis x9d plus and it works great.

customise your own drone with a bunch of official parts. i've toyed with the fastest i can find, to scaling it back so its a little slower, much like my real world drone!

Lovely environments and then lots of community made content. upgraded environments are on their way too!

If you are looking for a drone sim to see if you like fpv flight, this is the one i would recommend.
If you fly for real, get this anyway, its much cheaper to practice in here and not break any real world parts! ;)

great fun, great community and great development team

Now im not saying that this is a fault because it is not this game is great and i use it reguraly when the bateries are not charged or if i just have some free time. just please give us the ability to have more options.

I have a lot of real world experience with RC aircraft, and have used a lot of the popular commercial RC computer sims, too. I've done a bit of FPV, though not any FPV quads (yet!!) 

With that background context stated, I'll say that I'm very impressed by Liftoff; the maps are cool (though a bit small), the courses are challenging, the quadcopters fly well, and the simulation of FPV (including the interference you get) is pretty good. Being able to build custom quads using real-world parts and software is awesome.

It's not free, unlike some of the competitors, but it's far less expensive than almost all of the mainstream RC flight sims. I felt like it was money well spent... except now I want to get a real FPV quadcopter. LOL!

This is my first review at all. I am doing this fantastic hobby since 2 years now and I think I have every available FPV simulator. A great possibility to improve your skills or to get some skills :-) Challenging and fun. The problem with Liftoff was it's abysmal rubberband physics. Graphics, interface, tracks... everything good but this physics. No comparision to Veocidrone or Rotorrush. The latest update was a huge step forward and now this sim is awesome in my opinion.  The physics feel really good, Betaflight settings are very responsive and accurate. Best (greatest) flying environments so far (Hannover :-). Graphics are good, perhaps to good. At Pine Valley I can not get rid of these micro jerks with my PC (I5 6600k, GTX 1060 6GB) Shadow drone functionallity is just aweseome. All rounds are displayed as a shadow drone... so if you have your last round the slowest you fly behind all your other ghost drones. Adrenaline kicking as hell. I am not longer sure what is my favorite but at the moment I am just flying Liftoff. Thank you developers for these piece of sofware. Woth every cent of the 20 Eur. Sorry for my english, I am from Austria.
Great sim

This is a great simulator if you are trying to learn acro for the first time. After building and ruining my first FPV drone I realized I needed time in a sim. After a few sessions of Liftoff I was able to get my bearings and understand how the drone moved and what it was capable of performing. Great compatibility with a Taranis. The BetaFlight additions make this sim even better.
Excelent way to learn to fly minquads, gets even better with a Taranis controller.

I bought this game like a year ago, and it was super bare bones at the time. I felt like I had wasted my 20 bucks. Well I wanted to warm up before heading out to the park the other day so I fired it up again. Lo and behold they've added a TON of stuff. Lots of parts, frames, tracks, a race mode. Music. I was able to create a quad reasonably similar to mine, and I was amazed to see that it flys almost the same. I haven't tried any other simulators, but back to back with the real thing this ones super accurate. I've been warming up in liftoff before going out to race, and this has upped my game considerably! It's also pretty fun to fly the quads that pros use and see how the compare to my old beater. One thing you should know is that this is very clearly a practice tool, not so much a "game". It's accurate, (it even simulates bad video reception) but it's not pretty, it's really ugly acutally, and there's no game modes and no unlocks or anything like that. As a simulator I can't say enough good things about it though, it's AWESOME!

A total waste of $20.  This is not worth giving away for free.  I run my controller through all the tests - its all fine.  Then I try the simple freestyle level - all the controls are off.  It just tumbles around in circles.  Impossible to use.  Don't waste your money on this junk.

A wonderfully priced flight sim that is, itself, a wonderful flight sim. If you're just starting to get into drones and/or FPV, definately get this sim. Plenty of time to practice flying with out having to stop every 5 minutes to recharge your batteries.

This game is fantastic. For people looking for a realistic quad FPV simulator, I've tested many of them including this one, and it is the only one that I chose to continue using. It has nice graphics, gameplay is smooth and realistic, it's a very good way to learn, practice and progress , and also have fun.

This game is terrable if your player with a controler im using a PS4 one the preset is unplayable in ACRO mode which is the only mode your want to fly in as this is whats used for racing. The camera dosn`t keep up with 3rd person and lags behind so your drone is not level on the screen and make you feel sick and often the game just losing the drone completely and bugged out.

I love this game! I have got quite a few flight hours on it now and cant stop playing it. The graphics are great and doesnt require a super computer to run.
I have tried a few simulators but this is by far the best one. Feels more like a quality product compared to its competitors and far more detailed.

At 100 hours played and with some great recent updates, I thought it would be fitting to write an in depth review. 

Check it out here: http://www.controllercraft.com/articles/liftoff-fpv-racing-simulator-review/

This simulator is fantastic! The best I've ever used. I tried the more popular $5 simulator thats out there, as well as the DRL sim and was disappointed in how little they helped my piloting skills. Liftoff is worth every penny and took me from a newbie pilot barely able to fly in Horizon mode to a full acro pilot. The fact that you have the ability to build a virtual drone with all the flight characteristics of your actual drone is a huge advantage in learning as how you fly in the simulator can almost directly transfer to real world flight. It feels really good and is astonishingly close to real world flight. And to top all of this off, you can actually tune your PID's. There is no finer simulator out there, nothing else even comes close!

Updated Review: After trying many similar sims this is the one that stands out.  The best use I get from Liftoff is the track builder, where I can refine my racing skills.  A great addition would be the roll_yaw_mix/FPV cam angle from BF, helps control at camera angles exceeding 45 degrees, imo. Great training tool and recommend it to anyone looking to start flying FPV racers.

Highly recommend - simulation really good, takes a ot of getting used to flying if you haven't flown FPV quads before but very satisfying when you do. 
Maps are really good and the map editor is great, and when combined with the maps I can see a lot of potential for making your own really cool tracks. 
Being able to make your own drones is also an appreciated feature - I was able to make a simple, low-power drone that's not too twitchy to practice on before moving onto more powerful drones.
Graphics aren't amazing but that honestly doesn't bother me and I don't think it detracts from the game at all. 

Not so great is the UI which could do with some work, and music I find kinda meh and repetative (you get pretty sick of hearing the same tracks over and over very quickly).

If you're getting into FPV quads or just want to use this as a stand-alone game in its own right, this is awesome, and it's still early access! I'd say it's good enough for full release as it is right now, but it looks like they'll be adding more maps in future at least.
One of the best FPV Drone Racing sims available!

I had tried Liftoff back when it was first released.  I had nothing but trouble trying to get it to work with my Spektrum DX6 Radio, the one I use with my real racing drones.  After trying just about everything, I gave up and decided to try again when the product matured some.
Well, over the 4th of July weekend, I decided to give it another go and I'm so glad I did.  The developers have done wonders not only with the hardware compatability issues, it has brought the product into a competative state with the other successful FPV Racing sims currently available.  The physics, graphics and general gameplay have come so very far in such a short period of time.  Liftoff is still an infant ... not every interface and feature is perfect, yet. But, when you consider just how fast thngs are maturing, this product will be the standard in no time flat.

(My review has changed since I now have plenty of hours on this simulator).

It's an excellent simulator, especially for those who are wanting to get into FPV racing and freestyling.

The only thing that I greatly dislike about it is the sad fact that the game CONSTANTLY forgets what my transmitter is when I shut it down and I have sit around for around 10 to 30 minutes fighting with the game to get it to properly detect my transmitter when I boot the simulator back up. It's AGGRAVATING! Come on, do I really have to fight with getting my transmitter controller to work with the game EVERY single time I boot it up? Really? Why can't it just save my transmitter and its settings? Seriously... this is just pathetic.

The devs really need to fix this issue, otherwise pilots are bound to run into the same issue and get just as frustrated, leaving this otherwise awesome sim for one that actually works with their transmitters.

Note: I'm using a FlySky FS-i5s transmitter.

----
Pros: 
* Realistic flight physics
* Good graphics
* Simulated FPV static
* Track editor for making custom tracks
* Has a few official race tracks already in the game
* Customizable drones and flight settings.
* Awesome downloadable content provided from the Steam Workshop community

Cons:
* BAD TRANSMITTER DETECTION. Having to re-do your transmitter settings every time you boot up the game is just asinine.
* VERY HIGH difficulty and learning curve (this game is not for everyone)
* Physics can sometimes go bonkers (the game is still in development, so I can't blame the creators)
* Not a lot of tracks/areas (yet)
* Has a small selection of drones (this most likely will grow larger as the game develops)
* An actual flight transmitter/controller is definitely required (video game pads don't quite cut it)
* Flight transmitters are pretty expensive (as well as the hobby itself). Good flight transmitters usually range between $60USD and $80USD, sometimes well up to $100USD and over. Just a fair warning.

This is a good game. Graphics are solid and experience is similar to a real racing drone.  I have about 60 hours played and it's helped me become a better pilot.  

One word of advice - for the first 50 hours I played - i used an Xbox 360 controller.  This taught me some bad habits - as the accelerator  knob always comes back to the centerline.  

Recently I purchased a trainer cord for my Spektrum transmitter and the feel is MUCH more realistic and it's much easier to control.  Now I don't have to always lower the throttle like I had to on my Xbox controller.  I feel like I am getting a much more "real" experience and the drone actually acts like the real thing!! 

My real racing drones are: Vivfly M2 220, Spedix Blackknight, and a Blade Torrent 110

Pros:

-decent variety of areas to fly
-workbench is a cute idea

Cons: 
-UI is terrible
-Tracks dont feel much like real drone tracks
-Options for drones are strange. Not many options that actually look like current gen race drones

Overall: 
its not any better than other sims you can get cheaper or free.
This game is pretty good but so badly optimized. I run a 1080 TI and I have performance issues in 1080p. FIX YOUR FUCKING SHIT

I love this Drone Simulator. It works great with my Flysky radio and my Taranis. The Sim has improved my Flying and my confidence. I am trying more advanced things than I would have in my real flight time, Because of this softwear.
If you are a noob or have been flying for a year or so, get this sim it WILL MAKE YOU A BETTER PILOT !!!!!!!!

Great drone sim!  A lot less expensive than buying a drone and crashing it a hundred times.  I honestly cannot believe that the reviews of Liftoff are not overwhelmingly positive; it's solid fun!  I'm using a game console controller to control the drones.  I bet it would be even better using a real transmitter such as the FrSky Taranis Q X7!

I like this Simulator. Besides the Vortex you have a nice range of frames, motors ad props to choose from, everything is customizable. You can also tweak your FC to your personal liking. Getting it to work with my RadioLink AT9 took a little bit of time but once i figured it out (thanks to the forums) i had no further problems. I bought this Sim late 2016 to get some stick time over the winter month and since then, the amount of maps, drone parts and options have almost doubled. Over all a fun Simulator with frequent updates for little money.
It flies so good now. Great update. Feels literally like my real quad. Great work!

This is a pretty niche game, and is only really best played with proper equipment. While you can still run vjoy and a bunch of analogue audio hackery to make the old hardware work, in 2017 you should really upgrade to the current gen RX that supports usb.
The game itself is great, still quite a bit to go. The part selection is rather dull, but it barely matters. It provides good track and dexterity practice. Definitely up there with the best sims for FPV quads.
Pretty fiddly to work out how to add workshop tracks to your game though, the process should be a lot more streamlined.
So Crash, Much Majestic, Such Wow. But really, GET DIS SIM.
Still has a long way to go before full release. Controller compatibility is spotty at best. Graphics are good and if you can manage to make it work with your equipment it can be a fun fly.
