I have tried changing my PC performance setting in control panel, but no luck. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

I liek it ah loht!

This is the best sim I've tried. Keep up the awesome LuGus!

Not everyday is a good day to fly. It's raining outside, you're sick, you've been drinking, or you need to rebuild your favorite quad? No worries, fire up Liftoff, have a seat, and get ready to rip. Most pilots will tell you that you need to keep flying to keep your skills up, or you'll go rusty, and have to relearn everything all over again. It's about muscle memmory, timing, and familiarity. Liftoff helps out when you don't have any packs left to rip, or the weather isn't cooperating. Customize your quad as close as you can to the one yu fly with the workbench, tune it up in the ingame BetaFlight simulator, and set your FPV angle. Yhe FPV will also simulate the video noise you get from your headset from flying near large metal structures, behind trees, and distance (to a degree, you'll never lose Video like in real life).  Want to race it up with the community? Get out there and try the prebuilt tracks, or get on the Steam workshop and try out maps that others out there made. Loads of fun without the cost of crashed quads, busted props, and puffed packs.  Grab it and you'll be pleased. I have FrSky Taranis and Turnigy Evolution, and I have to say, the Evolution just worked as soon as I plugged her in, whereas the Taranis required me to make a model. Either way, easy set up and get to ripping.  Only downfall is the music tracks get really repetative, so fire up your own music. God mode in races isn't infalible but it really gives an edge to the guys that play with it always on, and will make you wonder how they slam the shipping container and still keep flying. This is solved by disabling god mode in any race you create, but don't expect the races you join to have it disabled. Well worth my hard earned money, since it makes me a better pilot without the cost of repair.

Liftoff installs and runs but thats about as far as it will go considering that it doesn't have native support for PS3 controllers. (or keyboard flight for that matter) Instead the community has a guide directing new players to download and install 3rd party software to enable some semblance of  functionality. The 3rd party in question is "MotioninJoy" and its webpages immediately trigger a malicious website warning. No telling whats being installed from this site once the player opt's to use this software.

Note: From what I'm reading from various sources, Win-10's driver signature verification must also be disabled for this to work. (Sounds fishy)

Overall, "Liftoff" was beyond disapointing... It's total waste of my money, time and a potentially huge security issue should Motionjoy's malware is still lurking on my system. (Yes, i uninstalled and am scanning as I write this)

Pointblank... the Dev's should be ashamed that their release has made such a bad 1st impression and should take steps to remedy it ASAP!

This is hands down the best FPV sim that I've tried. I've used both RealFlight and the DRL sim but they aren't even on the same level as Liftoff.  The physics in Liftoff "feel" much more like real flying than the other sims. The Liftoff UI and in-game graphics are also far superior to competitors. It's clear that the team paid close attention to even the most minute detail.

I'm currently using Liftoff with a FlySky FS-i6 Tx and I'm loving it. Get Liftoff, you'll never look back!

Before trying Liftoff, I used to play DRL, however it doesn't have the same real-feel and realistic flight model as Liftoff has, unfortunately I've been unable to play due to lack of a compatible controller, the FS-i6 does in fact work, but generates a lot of noise which is interfering with the controls. I have been playing with a full compatible USB controller and it works amazingly well, and gives a near realistic feel of flight. The game however is very weighted towards racing pilots and not freestyle pilots, and here I'm referring to lack of objects on the maps and the limited size of maps as well for freestyling. I would love the see the option to create own maps so we can design freestyle maps ourselves, but seeing as it's in early access there's a lot more to come and hopefully more suitable options for freestyle pilots. :-)

For those who are wanting to learn how to fly fpv but don't know where to start, or are unsure and nervous about wrecking a racing quad, this is the place to go. Not only for the flight experience to gain, but the developers that stand behind their work. Two updates ago, I had problems where I couldn't even fly on here. I contacted Lupus Studios and in less than 24 hours they had me back in the digital skies! And to put the cherry on top, pilot Jack FPV of FPV Academy on YouTube releases tracks and courses on liftoff based on his instruction and drills he's created so other pilots can practice freely without risking wrecking their quad, or offers pilots an opportunity to fly drills inside their house while the weather is uncooperative. Love this one so much, my first quad is an Immersion RC Vortex 285 just like the one on here! Looking to get into the scene? Here's where you start!

Update 0.10.1:
Throttle control is better now, flying feels much much better now cause I dont have to worry about weird throttle curve. Still I feel like I have to use 40% of throttle to hover, will do some more testing with stick overlay. But its much more intuitive than before and considerably closer to my real life quad (I use @35% to hover).
At first (freelight) I thought quad was pretty slow (first map, desert) but when I tried race, it showed that the grass something is just really big and the quad is actually pretty damn fast.
Overall, it feels great, I think on par or even bit better than Velocidrone now (can be cause by my computer tho). Only thing that bugs me, can we have some settings for races where on crash/restart we go to last gate instead of starting whole race again? It's little bit frustrating, god-mode solve this partly, due the fact that quad sticks to everything like glue.

0.10.0:
After months trying to find simulator that is close to real life, I am still with no luck. DRL is floaty, Hotprops is laggy and has funky crash animations. Velocidrone is pretty close, but also feel bit floaty. Liftoff, well, feels ok. But something I can't get over is hover at 50% no matter what I try (500g weight with 5kg+ thrust shouldnt act like that). That feels horrible to what I am used to with real life quad which hovers at 25-30%. It's a shame. Hopefully devs will fix this. Till then its not worth the money.

Liftoff is an awesome drone racing simulator!  I would recommend it to anyone interested in drone racing out of curiosity and/ or those looking for a professional drone racing simulator.  The developers have obviously been doing their homework.  They also are keeping it well maintianed and there are a large number of competitive racers to contend with in Multiplayer.  There is also a way to groom yourself into actually becoming a competitive drone racing pilot!  And by their photo on Facebook...they look like some guys you'd want to hang out or race with.  And there are scores of extras downloadable tracks to keep things interesting!  And this is just the early access version!
Thanks!  Keep it up guys!

Sweet FPV Trainer. Showed me just how rough I am and finally taught me what my mates have tried telling me for ages, that i don't want to jump straight into 4s Li-Po's. Turnigy Evolution linked up perfectly on windows 10. Like perfectly! I mean I plugged it in, ran the game, no dramas. No crazy order of operations like  plug it in, calibrate, go to options, ring your grandmother, pat the dog 3 times against the grain, turn on, hit yaw, pitch, yaw, arm, roll, etc. None of that business. Just plug and play. If you get it and say to yourself "But Julia Gillard said this was great, yet I am bad player, i keep crash, I do not crash my DJI Mavic or my Parrot from JB Hi-Fi" then that is your problem. FPV drones are much harder to fly than mass produced shop front tractor drones. They are harder to use but faster, better, stronger, Daft Punk'er. Enjoy crashing and realising how much this game saved you in broken parts on your first quad.

It's by far one of the best FPV sims I've used in a while, but it does have some problems.  I have logged 72 days on RealFlight G6.5, so I believe I'm able to say with certainty what I'm experiencing here.  This simulator has decent graphics and the models are pretty smooth when they work.  My only gripe with the simulator is that it intermittently stops communicating with my Taranis.  Hotprops never had this issue, but in this simulator you will be flying perfectly fine when it suddenly starts holding the last stick positions like a failsafe.  It starts about 3:30 into the game in my experience and can ony be fixed by restarting the game.  If you continue playing, the failsafes get even more frequent despite no apparent cause.  It gets really annoying when you have to restart the sim every 4 minutes because it starts glitching.  

This sim has great potential and will become my new favorite when the bugs are worked out.


Edit:
4/22/2017
After some recent updates, the issue with the controller stopping has decreased in frequency significantly, so I have no idea what changed.  I have tested it with 3 different cables now and the issues are still present, but they only happen once every two hours or so worth of use which I consider acceptable.  After experimenting with the voltages of the Taranis battery, I have found very little correlation between the batery and failure rate.  This could very well be an isolated incident that only happens on my setup so I don't think it's a big issue.  

This simulator has now become one of my most used training systems and I recommend it to anyone wanting to get into the hobby.

I will be polite in this review.  If you have any problems at all installing liftoff or getting it to work on your computer (not crashing), than quickly ask for a refund or you will lose your $20.  Of the 5 hours that support claimed i was playing the game, i actually had about 30 minutes of playtime where the flying was unacceptable and I was trying to correct it.  The other 4 plus hours was trying to get the game up and running with both ps4 on a mac or my spektrum dx6 on my windows.   They count everything as playtime... from the second you launch the game.   I am now out $20 and have a game that can't be played.   Maybe future releases might work. ... hmmmm

This is the most realistic fpv sim that I have flown to date. FPV graphics are spot on. Multiple drones to choose from, and beautiful scenery. You can also build custom drones from a selection of parts. Controller setup is easy. I love this sim!!!

Liftoff is a fantastic game and I highly recommend it to others getting into the hobby of drone racing or just want a really good simulator. Pros and Cons to this game are as listed:

Pros
[list]
[*]Great Flight Sim for Drone Racing
[*]Great Community for Addons
[*]Allows for Custom Playlist
[*]Great Graphics and ability to Turn on or off Noise (Noise being grainy quality of camera) on Camera

Cons
[list]
[*]Has Certain Flight Height Limits (I know this is supposed to go along with FAA guidelines or limitations of Unreal)
[*]Free Flight is Limited (Certain Heights and Fly Distance)
[*]Customization is Also Limited

Other than these Cons this is a beyond fantastic game and it is just getting better! I would totally recommend this game to people looking to get into this hobby or just looking for an alternative to other simulators.

Currently one of the best fpv simulators.
Flight physics are getting better and are already pretty close to reality depending on your setup.
In the experimental branch it feels better at the moment so i am sure there will be huge improvements in the future.
Multiplayer works great and i like the idea of having competitions in the future.

Liftoff is also great for beginners to learn flying acro and getting a feel for drone racing but make sure to have the right controller.

The best controller is probably still the taranis and it feels pretty natural even if the resolution is currently still reduced by the unity engine but sadly that is something the engine developers have to fix.
Another option are simple, old usb simulator controllers that are sadly pretty hard to find now. 
Or just grab any radio with ppm trainer port and use a simulator adapter or your soundcard with something like smartpropoplus. 
The turnigy evolution has a terribly slow update rate at this point and until that is fixed in a different firmware i probably won't recommend using that.
I hope there will be more and better usb controllers available in the future without the need of ppm adapters.

One night I was bored and decided to get into FPV drone racing. Without any experience I went online and bought Wizzard X200 and FlySky FS-i6 transmitter. Days later, drone sits in the corner waiting on a battery and I  have my FS-i6 connected via USB cable and fly this game like crazy. 

I will add my part of the review after I will fly the actual drone, but so far, this is the best simulator I had a chance to play. I tried FPV Freerider and DRL and both felt way to arcadish. This one is really fun and hard. Autolevel mode is easy and fun when you want to get use to flying. Acro is hard as ****. I have a huge respect for people who can pilot drones in fast speeds! 

One thing that I do not like is the lack of control layout. I often find myself quiting the game just to go into options or even googling how to do basic stuff like:

"A" for acro mode
"V" FPV or behind drone
"B" line of sigh
arrow up and down BEFORE arming the drone to adjust the camera

or I miss that I CANNOT pick my own drone for tutorials. I understand I cannot use workbench, but at least to pick an easy and slow drone would be good.

Otherwise a very good game, but a bit confusing interface and part where I actually pick my transmitter/controller.

Keep up the good work guys!

First, I do have some credentials to mention, perhaps to add some validity to the review.  I served 6 years in the Air Force and while stationed in Italy in 1976, I joined a group of Italian hang glider pilots I found while driving in nearby mountains.  I bought a hang glider, flew 5 times from a 2500 foot peak, and then crashed and broke my arm. The military took care of me, and I'm okay.  Years later, I discovered flight simulators on an Apple II computer (SubLogic FS2). I've used simulators ever since then to an exhaustive degree.  In 2004 I had the means to start flight lessons, and obtained a Private Pilot license in 2006.  I put about 80 hours in command of rental planes (Cessna 150, 152, 170, 172M, 172P) and then got training in a Weight-Shift Control sport aircraft.(commonly called a trike) and then I bought one, N502PW.  I flew 100 hours in the trike over the next 5 years, then sold the aircraft in 2014. I have a Phantom 3 Standard quadcopter, a Spedix 275 FPV racing drone, a Vortex 250 FPV racing drone, a Blade NanoQX FPV mini, a Blade InductrixFPV, and an FPV Tiny Whoop I made from an Inductrix.  My FPV videos are on YouTube at patjoyce7323.

Liftoff is one of the most remarkable simulator products I have ever used.  It has the closest feel to the actual experience of controlling an FPV drone.  There are no "anomolies" or odd glitches when you use the controls aggressively.  The most remarkable thing about LIFTOFF is the support from Steam and the Steam Community.  I bought the software for only $20 (compare to MS flight simulator $60+ ) and was able to use my really old "Real Flight" USB controller from 20 years ago!  That controller is not always compatible with other simulators, but works great in Liftoff.  

But again, the greatest thing, is how LIFTOFF has been IMPROVED since I installed and started using it.  LIFTOFF has amazing graphics.  Other simulators cut back a bit on the realism and the details, so that they can build a more expansive landscape filled with all of the actual structures that are there in the real world.  Liftoff is so designed to get the best balance of landscape detail (3d objects) and computer performance.  You can customize the complexity of the graphics displayed so that you can increase the frame rate of the simulation.  The physics are completely accurate.  You can build a new quad completely from scratch and save it.  You can select parts such as frames, motors, props, batteries, antennas, etc.  You can adjust the FPV camera angle, add a Mobius or GoPro on top, then go fly your customized quadcopter.

Back to the landscapes.  There are many environments provided for you to fly.  Each one is very different from the others.  The first "Straw Bale Field" is wide open space with no trees (except for a few outside the fence).  The bales of hay provide a clear ground reference.  The next environment has tall pine trees so you can learn obstacle avoidance and more advanced maneuvers.  The next is flying inside one level of a parking garage to teach you to manage your altitude carefully.  There were several more beautiful environments (a pro football stadium, for example) but here is the beauty of all this... they keep giving you more environments as they are developed.  And the latest one, called Hannover, is like the bando heaven we all seek.  No people, just awesome open places to fly and hone your skills.  The windows have reflections, and the level of detail is as good as it gets. There are lots of areas filled with trees, different sizes, types and colors, with gaps both big and small, and not always predictable, to challenge your flying skills.

I have not ever used the Multiplayer feature, or competed in races, all of which I am sure are worlds in and of themselves, with a huge number of tracks available for download.  LIFTOFF has a builder feature which allows you to build your own track in any of the environments.  Tracks can be saved and shared.  I've build a few tracks, and honestly, it takes a while to learn how to move and place the flags, gates, and markers, but in the end, you have a really nice race track that is exactly what you need.  Then you go fly your own track, and since you can edit tracks, you can always come back later to make improvements and adjustments. 

In short, this simulator will make you a better pilot.  And it accurately portrays the experience of performing FPV quadcopter flying.  If you like the DRL product, you will enjoy LIFTOFF even more.  Worth it at twice the price.

Being fairly new to RC Drones I decided to get a few different simulators like this one, both FPV Freerider sims, Velocidrone, FPV Event and the free DRL Simulator. From the testing I've done there seems to be a large void between how each one feels and how close to the real thing they get, for example Liftoff seems to be more like an arcade game with the feeling I get from the controls, where it seems to have way to much punch the second you move the throttle stick. So just getting used to it isn't easy even when you fly in level/stability mode, it does get better in acro but the same issue with the punch power is still there. Like I've said I have several of these sims and the two I have found closest to real life are FPV Event and Velocidrone and it's because they both seem to be setup with real world physics. I fly a Robocat 270 racing drone and it has plenty of power and is capable of around 60/70 mph, and it feels nothing like the drones in Liftoff because they just shoot upwards like their on steroids.  And when it comes to the workbench screen I find the lack of contrast ridiculas because its hard to see whats on the screen unless im sat inches away from it, so I think the developers could take a look at changing the Font size and background colour to make it easier for people to be able to read the information either in the workbench parts description or the flight controller settings screen. Apaert from that I do think Liftoff has loads of scope to be improved and it will only take some tiny tweaks to get it close to a full on drone simulator, and at it's price point I do think it could be a whole lot better.  But if like me you are finding it hard to get your head around I would recommend trying some of the free ones like DRL simulator or the free trial of FPV Event, as like me you will notice just what I have, Liftoff is a great simulator but it's not quite real enough.

So I have been owing this review for a while now :) I started on Liftoff before I had received my first quad parts irl and I can safely say that it has been the single most important asset since I started quading! I have tried other simulators such as DRL, Velocidrone and FPV Freerider recharged without much luck; either the physics engine felt wrong or was simply missing important aspects, the physics settings were awkward or the drones couldn't be tuned right. Liftoff excels in all of these areas. With a bit of knowledge in tuning and a little time spent selecting components you can get a quad in Liftoff to fly about as close to real life as any sim will provide at the moment. And I say this from experience with my real setup. I would thoroughly recommend that ANYONE who flies quads and has free time available in their day should get liftoff and spend some time getting it right and reap the benefits of this awesome sim. Props go to an awesome community of fliers and an amazing dev team that are dedicated to getting updates out regularly. See you on the race track :)

Not particularly an accurate sim. It randomly resets the game with absolutely no cause at all, yet you can literally fly through the branches and leaves of a tree several times before it detects damage and resets. I've tried both a wired TGY 9x using SmartPropoPlus and a Spektrum DX6e via OrangeTX DSMX USB dongle and the results are the same, a barely controllable craft. Throttle is insanely twitchy even with a ton of expo. If you want/need to fly close to the ground absolutely good luck as it's virtually impossible to keep even the most basic quad more than 10-20' off the deck.

IT decides when you have flown too high or too far and warns you to turn back, yet even if you do so immediately it's fade to black, reset the game.

Good idea, but extremely poor execution. At least sink/fall rates feel way more realistic than DRL. But DRL feels better designed and more realistic. I'm feeling that I should have kept my refund instead of buying it again.

Before I ever got a real quad, I bought a Taranis to practice in simulators. This was easily the best decision I made. I initially started with this simulator, but it was too laggy to be any good, so I spent a solid 30 hours on Hotprops. Now that I have 6 months of real life FPV under my belt, I've found myself coming back to this sim. 

First of all, the physics are great. Being able to tweak so much in the flight controller settings has allowed me to set up my virtual quad pretty darn close to my Xhover Element. The only big problem I've noticed is that the sim can feel a bit too floaty, like any bit of throttle you give will keep you in the air much better than in the real world. Adjusting the throttle curve fixes this. 

The graphics aren't terrible, and I feel like the sim has gotten much smoother over time. I'm running it on my iMac and find that 720p graphics work the best. I also like the ability to play with FPV noise. It's not exactly like experiencing real breakup in your video feed, but it does the job pretty well. My biggest grip with the graphics is the way the trees appear. If you're flying fast at all, you'll find that they sort of just materialize right in front of you, making it hard to avoid wrecking on branches or shredding your props on leaves. 

With the more recent updates, you now have a whole bunch of frames to choose from. I'm really excited about this, although I can't say I feel a huge difference in the way the frames fly. As long as your motors, battery, and props are the same, the frames fly pretty much exactly alike, with the obvious exception of the much smaller frames that can only run 4" or smaller props. 


So, what would I change? First of all, the crash physics are pretty bad. This isn't a huge deal, but there's something amusing about crashes with real life quads. One minute you're flying along fine, the next you're tumbling and bouncing across the ground. In the sim, you sort of hit the ground and slide, which isn't realistic at all. 

Next up, I would love to see some 5x4x3 props. The "Propfan" 5030x3 do a decent job of simulating the HQ 5x4x3's that I fly in real life, but they're definitely not the same. A proper 5" tri blade with a little more bite in the air would be awesome. 

Next up, some larger areas to fly in would be fun. I'm not much of a racer, instead I do primarily freestyle flying. Levels like the Hangar are so much fun because of the vertical structures, so I would like to see more stuff like that. Maybe even a more urban environment like an abandoned factory or office park? 

The biggest thing I would change is the FPV camera lens option. First, I would move it to the workbench screen instead of in the settings screen. Next, I would add a 2.5mm option. I, like a lot of people, fly in real life with a GoPro lens on my HS1177 camera, which provides a superior field of view without the annoying fisheye effect that a 2.1mm lens has. 

All that being said, I highly recommend this simulator. It's a great way to knock the rust off if you haven't flown in a while, or to teach somebody new to fly. Despite its flaws, Liftoff is my favorite simulator and I find myself coming back to it time and time again.

you really should be able to change the camera angle on the fly. and also to be able to choose another quad for the training levels. I bought this game to learn how to fly racequads but I just can't learn to fly if I have to start with a camera angle locked at 30 degrees

This is coming from a hardcore gamer, looking to get into FPV drones because they look like fun,

I am enjoying the sim, it seems like a great way to learn how to fly before destroying an actual drone, and I could see it being a fantastic skill improving tool even when flying actual drones regularly. 

I just have a few things that need mentioning if this game is to be the "gateway drug" for gamers becoming FPV pilots, and surely that thought has crossed the devs minds.

Firstly, that tutorial is brutal. Maybe coming from a RC background it would be easier, but having never flown a quad-copter before, being put in a box with one window to exit from is the equivalent of learning to pick locks by handcuffing yourself underwater. A typical gamer will need at least half hour in a large open space, preferably with a guide and controller indications explaining how the drone works by performing simple maneuvers ie "Take off, hover  at same altitude for 10 seconds" "Now fly forwards and backwards maintaining altitude" etc until the basics are natural.

Next up, there really needs to be some sort of pre-made drones that handle differently for different levels of skill. Begin with a slow and sluggish drone that is forgiving and easy to fly, then work your way up as your skills improve. I know there is a workshop where I can edit my drone, and options to set motor speeds etc. but these should really be options I fiddle with after I have learned what is what, not while I am struggling to stay horizontal as I smash into another hay bale.

Speaking of hay bales. The maps. Seriously, I could be flying anywhere in the world, but here I am in some unbelievably dull locations. I am sure more maps are on the way, but even for RC enthusiasts this can't make much sense. Here are a few map ideas I would be excited to see in the final release:
Boat (sinking titanic?)
Music festival (maybe Woodstock?)
Theme Park
Hot Air balloon Show. (Take off from one balloon, and there are 30 others just floating about)
Construction tower.
Literally ANYWHERE! I understand that this is trying to be realistic, but a game like this also gives you the ability to do things you wouldn't usually be able to do, like fly in public areas full of people, or dangerous locations, and the lines required the fly for racing could be a lot more interesting than markers on the ground, like ducking behind a waterfall to emerge near a roller coaster track, which you must follow for while before shooting into a ghost train tunnel. Gimmicky? Yes, but if just a couple of unrealistic tracks were included, it would be a lot of fun.

TL;DR I am enjoying the game, and hope to see it become more approachable, without losing it's realistic simulation edge. I recommend for anyone interested in FPV drone racing.

If you're curious how deep I dove into the world of FPV check out this clip https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ipJS-AMC0OQ&t=36s
I'm no Matty Stuntz, but I improved quickly thanks to the help of this sim.

Ok so I did a very long review a while ago that never made it to here so I‚Äôm doing another, shorter one.
Oh and about the first one, while being long and detailed was wrong for the most parts soooo : 

Tl;dr : It is very good stuff. But. It's for racing / Freestyle drone, it's hard. In real life it can hurt, or cost money and time to crash so that's why we love a true simulator ;)

Liftoff is very good at what it tries to do, mimic the real world mechanics of immersion RC drones (it is sponsored guys, only immersion RC stuff here. They may add other options / Chassis in the future but right now there is only that)

Why you may want something else? You may ask. Well, I've build many quads since I started this hobby 18 months ago and they're all very, very, light now (250g at most without battery) and I don't know how much Immersion RC Drones weight when well equipped but they feel very heavy here (maybe 400g is my guess) But that's no real issue, it just flies a bit differently, it's less nimble, more inertia to fight against. (It might come from the game engine thought)

Something else : no 2.5mm lens it's a nice sweet spot between the Fishy mc fish eye 2.1 and the not that fishy 2.8mm lenses... just sayin'

The collision engine is a bit weird. I Hate it. But you millage may vary.

Noises are a tad off too but who cares?

It's pretty GPU intensive... Not that great looking (although still the best of its kind -.-') but don't try to play it at 4k above 60fps with a gtx 1080... I tried. Didn't work. Step down to 1440p

Not enough locations! I want Miami Beach, 'Bando Hotel, Roman Empire ruins, sick mountains, Chernobyl and what not... 

Oh and find a way to make your 4ch radio to work with the game. While it's playable -ish with an xbox 360 controller it can get very frustrating... not enough accuracy with these tiny sticks. :p

At the end: I Love it, I just want more. Keep it up guys!

I bought this program to train myself at flying my DJI Mavic or DJI Phantom Quads.  Little did i realize that this is a FPV drone sim only.  It does not offer the ability to fly a drone from 3rd person or from the view of the pilot.. You are locked into a FPV camera.  But that's not why i don't recommend it.. I do not recommend this sim because of the controls..

The quads auto throttle in this game.  I dont want it to auto throttle.. I want to control the throttle.   Once arming the drone for flight, your drone will automaticlly go up in the air and will continue to acend until you press down on your controller.  This is not how it should be.  The drone should not go up, unless i hit throttle up.. and when my sticks go to their center position, it should hover.  

I tried several presets, and both ATTI, and Level modes.  There is a built in preset for the Xbox One Controller for windows, but it auth throttles.

I made my own preset, and specifically set throttle up/down, and it still auto throttled.  

Refunded this POS. They need to fix the throttle controls, and at least put a pilot view without FPV in there.  They also need to tell people that this is FPV only.

I`m new to FPV, just built my first drone, bought a cheap Flysky FS-I6 transmitter as I was not sure I will enjoy flying at all, and I soon realized I`m probably the worst pilot in the whole world!!! I am as new as it gets to flying quads. I am going do my best to try and get into some racing - the FPV stuff. But as we all know the fast toys aren't neccessrily the cheapest. 
So I figured I had better get my feet wet with some sim time before even attempting the real thing. Smart choice for me! lol
Didn't care to get some sim that was gonna try and cover ever form of flying - you know planes and all. Just some dedicated  sim for the quads kind. One where all efforts were single focused. Not one half-a__ed in all fields - but a killer in one.
I like Steam and after some surfing around and see all the other sims and the half-hearted reviews. One kept poking it's head out by some few as to how great liftoff is.
Went to Steam and bought. Been giggling ever since! Did some 360 controller hook-up and got my feet wet. I could see the tremendous effort hiding behind an inappropriate controller. A simulator just dying to be set free! The 360 controller is great for a lot of games. But one thing that become obvious really guick was the fact that it isn't configured right for real world flight. When you go thru the calibrating stage to run a controller that isn't a preloaded configuration, I found a major flaw with these controllers.
The little joy sticks don't travel in a "square box" perimeter pattern when you have to rotate them thru there full throw calibration. What I mean is that in a real flying situation and you have full left yaw and you want to keep that input and then throw full throttle at the same time (mode two throttle with yaw on the same left stick) when you push the little stick up for the full throttle it will end up moving to the right ( back to the middle) on the yaw axis to get to full throttle! That sucks! Not a "real world" condition. So the controller takes away a whole lot of these people's hard work when they created this really great simulator and the new pilot learns how to fly with some really crumby technique!
Now I want to get something like a Taranis grade transmitter. But i couldn't see spending a couple hundred on a transmitter that might get outdated by a new model by the time I learned to fly! Shopped around and took a gamble on a "USB RC Flight Simulator RC Tech 6chn" controller. UPS just delivered it today. So I plugged in and went caibrating with liftoff. Sure 'nuf the "square" pattern of sticks on the controller is what brought Liftoff to life! Let me tell you - talk about making you feel like what the real quad must feel like! If not it has to be so close that what ever difference there must be will be but an extremely small little hickup to learn in the actual flying.
Now I am pretty sure I don't have reverse throttle - but that can be fingered out at a latter date with maybe the help  of some serious tech guy. But this little cheap controller and this great Liftoff Simulator you can be come, I'm sure, a very competant pilot. Be able to strap on a real one and fly the first time out without digging a million postholes or chopping concrete up with an expensive quad. And probably at real close to racing speeds and manuveralbility.
So people go get the real controller and this Liftoff! Highly, highly recommended quad simulator - this thing rocks!!!!

Very disappointing. The maps themselves are reasonably sized, but in a misguided design decision to prevent players bumping up against artificial walls, the actual useable size of the map is enormously small. Drifting outside of it produces a "reset timer" that ends your flight and does not allow sufficient time to get back inside the flight zone. Attempts to have this made a user-configurable option on the community forums were essentially stonewalled - first under the excuse that "it would kill the immersion" and then contradicted by the second excuse "we need to provide a uniform experience for all people, and your actual immersion is not a factor". A reasonable compromise, being a user discretion on what kind of experience they would like, was not able to be advocated for as the thread was promptly locked. Actual reason: developer arrogance.

It's a pretty decent drone racing sim.  A warning for anyone who isn't an experienced drone pilot though - this is not going to be an easy game to just pick up and play.  It's a pretty realistic sim, and they've made the "race" modes realistic as well, meaning the gates are all tiny, and low to the ground.  For an inexperienced pilot, expect to practice for several hours or more before you successfully complete any of the races.  

I really think they should add some beginner race tracks, with big, forgiving gates.

Also, there's some bugginess with the prop damage, and the auto-reset doesn't always work (sitting there with no props left, and have to manually restart).  Not sure why they wanted to do prop damage the way they did.  You can accidentally just bounce a little on the ground when you go to lift off, and it'll damage your props.  Not very realistic at all.

So yeah, there's a lot they could do to improve it, but if you're looking for a decent FPV sim for training purposes, this is it.  If you're looking for a fun arcadey game you can pick up and quickly learn, this isn't for you.

Maybe it was the rain outside that prompted me to Early Access this game, but I'm sure glad I did! Since I usually build my own 250 Racers it was nice for a change to see how a Vortex Pro handles in comparison, its was also pretty cool to see Ummagawd and Metal Danny's setups! 

Even though its in Early Access, it seems pretty polished. Graphics are well done, physics are pretty real and handling seems pretty near the real thing. The only thing is that I hope they add more frame types. 

All in all perfect 5/7 and I can't wait to see the full release! I think this game could be a big hit amoungst us enthusiasts and its a perfect start for anyone getting into the hobby. 20 bucks is far better than countless sets of shattered props, dented motors, and cracked carbon fiber frame builds that can get quite expensive.

So, where to start?

I'm currently sitting on 290 hours on Liftoff and continue to play it every day I can. There are a couple of ways you can approach Liftoff.. as a game, or a tool to use for practicing for real life flight. 

If you know you are serious about getting into this hobby, I strongly suggest taking the approach of treating it like a training tool. For example, like just about any other skill you can learn, its recommended that you get 1 hour of practice every day to improve your skills as much as possible. That's pretty much how I decided to approach Liftoff, which can even sometimes mean forcing myself to spend a bit flying around even if I don't want to... I know that sounds kind of silly when its simply a video game, but it's definitely payed off. 

I started playing Liftoff back at the start of the year, and flew in real life for the first time in July and was able to fly acro on my second flight. I'm not saying that to show off, but to show how amazing Liftoff has been for making it so someone can just go out IRL and be comfortable flying a drone at nearly 100km/h (60MPH) without even needing to leave the house.

If you are in the category of being interested in FPV but you're not too sure, I'd suggest just buying a cheap transmitter, or even use an xbox controller with a rubber band on the left stick holding it downwards like I first did and see how you are feeling at about the 20 hour mark. That may sound like a lot for just testing a game but you really need to give it a chance until you are able to get your finger coordination down and can start feeling a bit more smooth with your flight.

If at any point something "clicks" and you realize how much you love it, I'd say start saving as much as you can for a taranis transmitter, or just go out and buy one if you can afford it. This will probably be the best investment you'll make getting into this hobby as you'll be able to use it down the track when you start flying IRL.

I don't want to make this too long, so in summary, Liftoff is most likely one of the best investments I have ever made in my life just because of how much money it's saved me. If I had gone out and gotten to the level of flying I'm at now by just flying IRL, then I have no doubt I'd be about 5-10,000 dollars short by now. If I were to add up the costs of the crashes I've had in Liftoff, it would literally be hundreds of thousands of dollars worth.. so if you have seen some FPV videos on youtube, and you are interested I really doubt you'll regret making this purchase.

and finally, thanks LugasStudios for this great piece of software. <3

The game had pretty good reviews so i thought i'll give it a try. I own Aerofly 7 and this works great with my Spektrum DX8, Logitech F710, Keyboard & Mouse... however  Lift-off fails on this simple and yet essential feature..

Brilliant simulator. Developers are great and responsive, I love it!

I cut my teeth on a very popular RC flight sim and it taught me so much about flying airplanes and helis. Liftoff has already surpassed the other sim for quadcopter physics. Even though it is in early access and is very short of it's eventual goal it is a strong tool for honing quad skills. I have 50 + hours in this sim and being winter where I am I feel my learning is progressing very rapidly. I feel like my second summer flying quads will be very fulfilling having a better sense of control thanks to this sim. The developers are very interested in user input and come through with regular updates. I am very excited for the future of this sim. Highly recommend for anyone interested in multirotor flight!

Update!
I just crossed the 300 hour mark with Liftoff. I started flying quads mid summer 2015 and only flew in level mode. Even though I used that mode I still had crashes. I spent some of the winter flying Liftoff in acro mode and improved to a great degree in that time. I have had quite a few flights this summer and only fly acro (Take off, flight, and Landing), and I now fly as if I have been flying for much longer than 1 and a half seasons. I have made many Liftoff videos to demonstrate it's power as a learning tool.
I can attest, after spending so much time in the sim, that anyone having a problem with this simulator is falling victim to either their own ignorance or outdated hardware. To speak to the later I feel that hardware non-upgraders are the bain of all gamers. If you are on an old laptop or a weak one for that matter you should naturally expect to have issues with games not working correctly. Upgrade or die! Seriously if you are one of these people realize you are holding us all beack. Please stop crying about games not working on your decrepit outdated machines. To the former; Why review a game poorly before you exhaust all efforts to learn the customizations? Sims always throw arcaders off. Just because you can't fly easily right off the bat doesn't mean it's broken. It means you currently lack the skill required to keep it in the air. This is remedied one of two ways. 1. Spend time learning to tune the aircraft by a. watching videos from people that have put in the work to help people such as yourself. b. experimenting a while reserving judgment until you figure things out. 2. Un-install the sim and go find something arcadish and easier made for people just like you. 
 Also why is it that some people forget the simple fact that this is an EARLY RELEASE title? Common sense dictates that it won't be perfect and that it is still under development. Updates for this and all other early access titles can sometimes have negitive affects. Be prepared for that. New resources for liftoff are added at a more than acceptable rate IMO. Further more the developers respond to questions in quick fasion. This sim/game is living up to it's potential in all areas, improving all the time.
 To any prospective buyer please note that you will need some sort of a game controller to fly Liftoff. A keyboard will not work. Seems obvious but... 
To get the best experience a interlink radio that comes with realflight or a game commander that comes with aerofly can be used and the buttons and switches can be used to switch modes or reset the aircraft. The gimbals aren't the best but this will provide the most in-game support of functions. The Sim supports field radios (remote controllers for real world aircraft) The easiest and best of these is the Taranis X9D/plus. This radio has a mini usb port on the back that makes it a perfect option for this and other sims like it. Liftoff has a preset for this controller as well. Even though it is perfect for the sim you will need to program the radio to work correctly. There is a guide for this and many other radios. That said not all radios play nice and there is nothing the developer can really do about that.
 I own all the other quad racing sims out there and this hands down is the best and the other sims are complete products not under development. If you are thinking about buying Liftoff and especially if you want to use it to improve your real world flying I say buy it. You will not be disappointed as long as you are not under any misconceptions and are willing to spend time with it.
This is a great game. It will let you perfect your flying without breaking anything. Well worth $20!

What I like about "Liftoff" . The name and graphics look cool . Too bad everything elas sucks ! Game doesn't boot up . Game doesn't see controler .  I love how the game says " I've played for 3 hours ". I haven't played for 3 minutes ! I see some people have gotten it to work and I see a far greater number of people who haven't gotten it to work .It was a $20.00 bet and I lost .

I've been playing liftoff with my 6 channel transmitter to prep as parts come in for my quad. It's been a lot of fun i just wish there was a workshop to share tracks.

UPDATE: The workshop is available now!

I have flown in a few different multi-rotor sims and this one is, by far, my favorite. It's not 100% like the real thing, but it's certainly close enough to bring my skills up and make me way more confident on the controls. Learning with a sim is like learning to ride a bike with training wheels. Until you get out there and fly on the real sticks you can't hope to compete. However, this is a great tool to get your confidence up and make you more comfortable for when you do get your hands on the sticks. 

I've been using this sim for a while now and I'm certainly learning more and more. Each time I fly my quad I'm more and more confident and that's come way faster than just flying once a week for a few packs thanks to this sim. 

There's never a substitute for the real thing, but this is certainly something to help get your there and even help sharpen your skills when you get there.

last review deleted so, so here we go again...

okay *game* but simulation it isn‚Äôt.

no aerodynamic model, hence no ground effect, very floaty gravity, some motors behave oddly in response to throttle.

damage system just hopeless, sometimes clip a leaf and seconds later a prop falls off, other times you can make leaf salad without damage‚Ä¶ why bother with damage that effects flight dynamics if you damaged an actual quad that much you‚Äôd just stop flying even in a race.

vtx must be 1 kilowatt to punch video through that many trees over such distance, some really unrealistic levels.

Sliding on the ground (which has the same friction as ice) will slightly damage a prop instead of the prop digging in and flipping you chaotically.

The game might help you improve real life flying but equally could leave you with bad habits.
 
Needs more work... and a proper aerodynamic model

the game is really realistic and looks good but the multiplayer is missing dan it would be a really hot simulator ambesten that you can fly on his self-built tracks with friends.

There are better FPV Quad sims out there for half the price.  The maps on liftoff are small, unimaginitive and if you go too high or off the map you are quickly returned to the start.   The graphics are not great.   Got banned on the message board for naming the other better sim.  So I asked for my money back and I'm taking my Taranis and Fatsharks elsewhere.

Not to bad but still needs some tweaking, Would be nice to see a few different flight modes so it feels more realistic. The graphics are not brilliant but for the overall money it is a fairly fun game. Maybe I am looking at it more as a Simulator instead of a game that is trying to premote FPV Racing.

If you have never had the chace to fly a FPV Racing Quad and like fast paced games I would recommend getting it.
Even with an x360 controller, it's lots of fun.

As a non-FPVer I bought this game out of curiosity, for fun. And fun is what I got. A lot of it. At first I had no clue on how to control the drone and the tutorial is a mess, however, I've managed to fly forward and backwards. Soon after, I learned how to strafe, to rotate and to land. With this basic knowledge I gained in 15 minutes, I was able to dramatically increase my knowledge in a few hours.

Now I informed myself about FPV and thinking about getting into it in real life. I'm wondering if playing this game is helping me later on, but so far it didn't hurt I guess. And I bought this for the fun at first, and this minimum I got from the very first hour.

Liftoff, the best simulator for action quadcopter racing. 5 Arenas you can choose to fly around in. There are race tracks set up that you can blast through in Self level or Acro mode (toggled by pressing the A key).  There isnt much choice in the way of Quads to choose from, but in FPV mode it makes almost no difference what frame you use.  The motor, prop, battery selection in the workbench is very good. Lobster motors, quiet clever. 

I love God mode, changing props, batteries etc is for Actual reality, dispencing that chore triples your play time.

The physics are right on the money for my experience.  I have always used self level mode (comming from a Photography/Phantom background)  and I would almost never used full throttle but spending 10 hours on this in Acro mode and full throttle upto 60% of the time..... and I dont think I will go back to self level on mini quads, except maybe in the carpark level, thats pretty enclosed for me at the moment.

I have my graphics set to HD and on Good (on a laptop). It is smooth enough to weave around on the forest level at speed, the depth of field is sufficent to pick a good line through the trees.

Lift off is handly learning tool or something to help you get a flying fix on a rainy weekend.

I found it was alittle trick to set up my controller but there is a tonne of videos on how to get it going, so a bit of paitence goes along way.

You can use you own music where you kind of load it into Steam. It wasnt as easy as it could be but I did get a couple of tracks working so I could get in my "Zone".

Is it worth the money, well yes.  They have made a couple of updates which included an extra track, which is something you would have to pay extra for on a small mobile device. I have read they are activley working on multi player which would be pretty fun.  And it means you can fly with a bunch of friends with out all of you having to by expensive Base stations and those low wattage VTx's.

What I would like to see is Eagle mode.  Where you have to pitch your flying skills against Natures finest...  
But then maybe the Dutch police would ban that.
Great simulator. It's all I fly...

Awesome graphics with the latest update but unfortunately the quad physics still feel floaty and sluggish. I really want to love this game but at the moment untill we are given the options to tune gravity effects and tune the flying experience feel more realistic, liftoff will remain the second choice to fpvfreerider. 

I really believe this game could be amazing with some physics tweaks, I just hope it gets there!

This feels pretty close to the real deal. It is great for scratching that itch when you are waiting for parts. It is also great for teaching a newbie how quads fly. 

I can endorse this as a great FPV sim.

This is an excellent flight simulation for quadcopters. Definitely the best out there at the moment and constantly improving! It gives you a very realistic feel on how to fly and has helped me improve my skills a lot!
cant use dx6i with out jumping through hoops. Hope the creaters expand to more transmitters. but the simmulator is worth the money.

Perfect for entry-level pilots or exsisting veterans of Quadrotor flying.

The Quads fly how you'd expect them to. Despite a few floatyness issues it's still virtually perfect,

The Sceneries are pretty.

The Tracks flow nicely.

I love it, and I'm very much looking forward to the next updates with hopefully more tracks and awesome extra content. Amazing job, I'm veeeeery happy with it. 

FWIW, I'm flying with a RadioLink AT9, using the PengFei USB dongle set on AeroFly, I used manual preset creation to configure it, not a single issue. Power up and connect your transmitter to the PC before opening Liftoff for best results.
THIS GAME IS AMAZING AND IS CONSTANTLY GETTING BETTER. IT IS A GREAT PROGRAM.

First of all, this is really really hard. Darksouls is a cakewalk by comparison. This is impossibly hard for quite a long time and the tutorial doesn‚Äôt help. This game is clearly made by drone pilots, for drone pilots.

The games starts with the controls screen and you have to input what you want to use for what straight away. Not the most intuitive menus either. It then throws you into the main menu. Not as bad as the controls menu, makes sense. I thought the game might be hard so I started with the tutorial.

Sweet lord christ. Stupid tutorial. One of the worst I‚Äôve ever played. Doesn‚Äôt tell you how to do anything, just what it wants you to achieve. Completely pointless.

After that, I tried to fight for what felt like most of my life before I could get the drone to kinda go in the direction I wanted it to go. I thought this would probably be good enough for the first race as it would probably be really easy. I was very wrong. The first race is astonishingly hard. And you have to do 3 laps without crashing. When I finally finished the course three times in a row (After enabling god mode in the gameplay options.) I was met with my three times and a total time. That‚Äôs all. I have no idea how well I did in that race. Probably really badly but that‚Äôs not the point. I then attempted an underground parking lot level that was ridiculous, quite honestly.

Regardless of all this, I‚Äôm going to recommend it because me sucking at the game does not mean it‚Äôs a bad game. However, this could be 100000000x better if the respawn times were WAY faster. Super-meat-boy fast. Really really fast.

So, overall, the music got on my tits, the controls got on my tits, the insane difficulty got on my tits but it‚Äôs still a good game already. That‚Äôs really saying something in today‚Äôs early access market where you pay the price of a full game to watch a peep show through a layer of piss just to see what the game might be like if the developers didn‚Äôt suck. These developers don‚Äôt suck, just so you know.

Did you guys at Steam smoke some crazy pot recently while coding the next release of Liftoff? THis latest release of Liftoff 0.3.5 is wrought with bugs, even more that the previous one!! What the hell! I can't even get the game to work properly anymore. THe main menu doesn't even accept simple mouse clicks. NOthing works!

After several unsuccessful tries, I ignored the fact that even though "Calibrate Controller" gives every indication that it's not working when using the game with a vJoy device, if you press on, you can set up a custom controller profile.

It is now working well for me.  Sorry for pulling the trigger on the bad review too quickly.  I was frustrated that it cost 4x more than, say, FPV Freerider and the support page seemed to be hidden.  Turns out that's just a steam problem.  You just have to go to their website, www.liftoff-game.com and scroll all the way to the bottom.  They are very responsive and helpful.

I fly and build real racing quads and have for a long time and got this one for curiositys sake and i also fly all the other FPV sims that are available. This is the best looking one and most polished - but it's a game and not a sim.

My real copters have more vertical performance and are faster than even the most souped up custom builds in the game and the real one turns better too. You have to play around with the settings to get it to fly remotly as a real copter and even if you do it's still too floaty - it takes ages for gravity to take hold of your machine, on a real one it pretty much drops like a rock when you lower the throttle and it does not slide in turns as much as in the "sim".

It's fun as its very easy to make complicated moves but if you attempt that with a real one it's much harder as you just dont have that amount of time, reality is faster and meaner - and totaly unforgiving and we need that as a setting.

You will learn correct reactions and stick movements without thinking about it and that's the most important! FreeRider for comparision - feels like driving a bus - slow and heavy. There are already examples of people learning to fly in LiftOff and taking skills outside and flying real racing quadcopters succcesfuly!

Review Pre-Alpha Version
Nice application, but the current Version has some flaws

First the positive things:
- Works perfect with my Real Flight Elite Controler
- Flightfeeling is very realistic. The copter reacts like real copter. The simulation is very realistic.
- You can use it for learning and training 
- You can change the setup of the copters in many ways, PID, Props etc. and you can do an expo setup for you controler to make a setup which works like your real world setup.

Some things which a really bad (in the pre-alpha!)

 If you set you screen to a low resolution the fonts and the dialogs doesn't scale. So everything is unreadable. This is very bad, cause you can't make any changes. For realistic training, I use a small 8" HDMI monitor with a resolution of 720p or lower. This gives a realistic flight situation. But then, it is impossible to do any changes. I always must switch back to my office monitor change the resolution to the changes and then change everything back. This need some fixing.

There is a beginners training mode, but the colors are so terrible. Light blue walls and white bottom. This is so crazy. There is no contrast in the colors. I never used this, cause it is nothing for beginners :-)

I think this a alpha problems which can be fixed.

Facit: If it goes to the final stage this app will be the the best training app you can get for race training. Please make a final version soon as possible (before the next winter :-)

Greetings 

BTW: I read some reviews of people who have no understanding who the acro mode works. This is a simulation game with real pyhsiks. Yes, it is hard to learn at the beginning, also in the real world. Most people with racers started at the beginning with permanent crash session. Thats a part of race copter flying :-)
Using it for bulding up confidence with controls of my multirotor :-) Good so far.

Crashes frequently, controls difficult to set up, calibration method is a horrible joke. Flight characteristics appalling.   it may be an early release but frankly it isn't even up to pre-alpha staus.

Still very much an Early Access experience, but it's shaping up nicely. It's already a ton of fun to play and good practice for the real thing. The graphics are locations are especially impressive, and the workbench aspect adds a lot to the experience.

Edited 12/16/2015:
 We've had pretty great communication with the DEVS and community members using the Discussions forums as well as the in-game error reporting features. Several users have expressed issues with Transmitters not calibrating correctly or at all with the software.  If you have an RC Transmitter, there are a few guides already posted and several discussions with topics discussing how we've worked through some of those matters - but there are ultimately a LOT of cables and variances in how they're produces, and even more Transmitters that users have. If you're  having errors connected, post it and let's get you flying!  I personally have a Spektrum DX6, DX6i, Taranis Plus, and Turnigy 9x and all work well using a USB cable. The Spektrum devices took several calibration attempts, and then additional Sub-Trim manipulation, but work well after.

* * * * * * * *
All around - I am really excited to see how they progress with this game. The 3 current levels are already beautiful and the multiplayer is going to be very exciting. Two thumbs up! (Then back to the joysticks!)

Note: While this game does work decently with 360 or similar gaming controller, I do not recommend spending time to get used to it. Gaming joysticks are meant to center themselves when you release pressure. This is ideal for most game situations, but not with throttle. While I did use the 360 controller for the tutorial and first test level, and it was decent enough, once got my Spektrum transmitter connected to the game and calibrated - it was a night and day difference. Much easier flight, it was much more fun and it was much smoother feedback from the camera also as you won't be bobbing up and down.

This will be a must have for pilots that want the FPV experience without ruining their setups or going through tons of props in the early learning stages. Would also be great for teaching purposes.

Written/Updated as of 11/26/15 Update

WARNING: To play this game, you MUST have a game controller with the analog stick that supports range detection (Like a PS2/XBox controller) or a quad copter transmitter that can be connected to your computer.

Liftoff early-access is a simulator for flying a drone, or quad copter in one of the most fun ways, FPV (first person view).  Imagine being a little bird able to fly and swoop in and out of trees, buildings, underneath bridges, etc.  That is what this simulator and what FPV flying is all about.

Liftoff is early-access and is already worlds above every other simulator out there, and it's just barely getting started.  I get the feeling that this game will build a huge passionate community around it, taking all of our passion for the sport, and allowing us a digital medium to share the art of flying and to practice our skills when we can't fly (when our copters are broken or it's night time).  When it is finally release, if this dream is fully imagined, it will allow us to challenge one another to unique challenges unable to be done in reality such as fly in areas that are generally off-limits for FPVers (like in a big city, or an airport, or around an ancient mosque).

If you're interested in getting into flying a drone in first-person-view (FPV), definitely get this.  When you can comfortably fly through the gates in the easy level, then go buy a copter and you won't be (immediately) breaking it so badly as most people do when first trying to get into the sport.  If you're ALREADY a FPV'er, and need to practice up on your skills, definitely get this.  Just flying it a couple hours already has significantly improved my IRL abilities, since IRL it's difficult to get that much consecutive time to fly (because of changing batteries/fixing parts/etc).

This Game is Amazing!
(JUST SAYING THIS GAME REQUIRES A CONTROLER) It actually feels like you‚Äôre flying the drone! They‚Äôve done such a good job on this game. The tutorial sucked though, it‚Äôs a really bad way to start someone off who‚Äôs never handled a drone before. It‚Äôs difficult for someone who hasn‚Äôt had any experience. The tutorial level is really confusing and hard to tell where stuff is because the whole of the map is the same colour with no definition or shadows. I was playing the tutorial for ages not getting anywhere with my skill. But then I played the actual maps. The forest is the best map because it‚Äôs fun and easy! After playing on the forest map for a short time I really got the hang of the controls and synched all the other maps including the carpark witch is apparently the hardest. The graphics are stunning when camera sound is off, terrific use of shadows. Overall the game takes a bit to get use to but if you keep persisting by playing the tutorial for an hour or two then move onto the forest map you‚Äôll be pro in no time! And this simulater is actualy helping me upskill with my IRL fpv drone.

It works with my Radiolink/KDS AT9 controller. I like the graphics (though there is room for improvement) and the maps compared to Freerider FPV. However I miss the fixed view (ground view) and I would find broader maps exciting to explore. I wish the best for the developers!

I fly quads myself and have a fleet of 4 4s racequads at home. Liftoff has enormous potential to become the best fpv simulator there is. As of right now it is a fun distration and something to get me through the winter.

Pro
- The ability to build custom quads with different lipos, props, motors, etc.
- physics - feels almost real
- graphics
- fpv noise
- fly the Vortex Pro

Contra
- workbench is still very limited with the best lipo being a nanotech 45c and the best prop being a 5045 Gemfan carbon fibre. I fly HQ triblades or HQ 6045 paired with 70c Thunderpower lipos, so there's a huge difference in power
- the physics of a damaged prop do not feel real at all. In reality a slightly damaged prop will be compensated by the flightcontroler and not make your quad almost impossible to control
- needs more models than just Vortex and Vortex Pro with different electronics

After latest update i can surely recommend this one.
It's pretty bare bones for now. Only 2 levels are playable and only acro mode is flyable. But flight dynamics already feel pretty good, a little bit easier than real life. If you are looking for a training sim, you can still spend hours on those 2 levels, and you can set up most things like power, rates, camera FOV/tilt.

Looking forward for new updates!

Really enjoying the game so far! I fly quads already but I'm trying to learn how to fly more aggressive racer quads. This game is helping me learn to fly with the tilted camera and with more power than I'm used to. The devs are very quick to fix any kind of problems and have improved the physics much since launch.

The physics overall feel pretty solid. It would be nice to see some wind or other factors that make the quad feel a little less on rails. It's not bad at all, though. Flying in the game feels pretty similar to real life.

I'm using the Taranis controller. Quick note: the game doesn't take negative inputs from the taranis, so make a new model, modify the curves to only be 50, and offset by 50. This means your left roll, for example, is really at what is normally the centerpoint (0) and your right roll is what is normally full right (100). You'll have to do this for all channels. In the guides section there's pre-made model files.
I've been flying quadcopters for 3 years now and this game simulates them very well! Love it!

IF YOU ARE HAVING ISSUES CONFIGURING YOUR TARANIS.. WHICH YOU SHOULD NOT..\
Make a new channel.
and change the throttle to have an offset of +100
and change your yaw, ali and pitch to have a weight of 50 and an offset of +50

Despite it being early days, this is a very good FPV quad sim.

I have been flying a real Vortex quad since June 2015, so I think I can judge quite well the quality of this sim and I'm pretty happy. It does feel like the gravity is a little off, and so throttle control is a little easier than in reality but I imagine this will be fixed quite soon.

The current three maps it comes with are quite good. The first map has proper sized racing gates, which is exactly what this kind of sim should have. The racing module is not yet there, but I have very high hopes considering how much fun I had doing laps of the field through the gates.

The pine wood map is also great fun, and I especially enjoyed this as I prefer to take my real Vortex into a pine wood quite often.

I would recommend this game especially to people that already own a quad, or are thinking about getting one. For everyone else, I'd probably wait till more features have been added, as it will be a very fun game when it's more complete, but for now it's a very good sim.
